questions.text: A 10-year-old boy complains of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in his fingers and toes which resolves on its own for the past 1 year. Which of the following conditions is he most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The features of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in fingers and toes with spontaneous resolution are suggestive of dactylitis (hand-foot syndrome), which usually occurs in sickle cell anemia.

The sickled RBCs have a sticking tendency towards the endothelium of the small venules. These abnormalities provoke unpredictable episodes of vaso-occlusion. Dactylitis is characterized by severe pain affecting the bones of the hands, feet, or both. It is often the first symptom of sickle cell anemia in children.

Treatment - Administration of patient-controlled analgesia or a frequent fixed dose of opioids with rescue doses for breakthrough pain are preferred with frequent monitoring during the initial 48-72 hrs to prevent unexpected death due to arrhythmias or pulmonary embolism.

Other manifestations include:

  • Splenic autoinfarction - repeated splenic microinfarcts 
  • Acute splenic sequestration - venous obstruction, needing emergency transfusion/splenectomy
  • Painful ischemic crises - vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal tissue
  • Renal papillary necrosis leading to isosthenuria
  • Cerebrovascular strokes
  • Chronic lower leg ulcers
  • Priapism in males

α-thalassemia (Option A) and β-thalassemia (Option B) are characterized by pallor, jaundice, growth failure, hepatosplenomegaly, characteristic thalassemic facies, and hair-on-end appearance of the skull.

Option D: Von Willebrand Disease is characterized by predominantly mucosal bleeding symptoms like excessive bruising and epistaxis.

questions.text: A patient was found to have a 3 cm adenocarcinoma of the body of the pancreas invading into the superior mesenteric artery. All of the following chemotherapeutic agents can be utilized for the management of this patient except:
questions.solution:
MVAC regimen (methotrexate, vinblastine, adriamycin, and cisplatin) is not used in the management of this patient. MVAC regimen is used in advanced bladder carcinoma.

Chemotherapy in pancreatic cancer is indicated in patients with unresectable tumours and lymph node metastasis. Agents used in chemotherapy are:

  • Gemcitabine
  • Gemcitabine with capecitabine
  • Albumin bound paclitaxel (nab-paclitaxel)
  • FOLFIRINOX - a combination of fluorouracil, irinotecan, oxaliplatin, and leucovorin

However, there is only a 2–5 months increase in median survival with these regimens. No long-term cure is seen with chemotherapy or radiotherapy for pancreatic carcinomas.

questions.text: A man, presented with multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting containing undigested food particles within one-hour post meals. On physical examination, he was found to be anemic and cachexic. CECT abdomen revealed diffuse infiltration of a neoplastic growth into the stomach wall. What Bormann’s classification does this tumor belong to?
questions.solution:
The history and investigation findings are suggestive of gastric outlet obstruction caused by a diffusely infiltrating type of gastric carcinoma. This is commonly known as linitis plastica and it is classified as type IV in Bormann’s classification system. 

Related Pearl: Borrmann’s classification of stomach cancer

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man presents with bleeding gums for 20 days. He has gingival hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Investigations done are given below. Bone marrow biopsy shows 100% cellularity with many blasts cells that are peroxidase negative and non-specific esterase positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb: 11 g/dL

Platelet count: 95,000 platelets/mm3

WBC count: 45000 cells/mm3.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia-M5 (AML-M5) or acute monocytic leukemia.

The patients with AML - M5 develop organomegaly, lymphadenopathy, gingival hyperplasia, CNS involvement, and other tissue infiltration. The bone marrow aspirate shows 20% or more blasts. Monoblasts have folded or lobulated nuclei, lack Auer rods, and are nonspecific esterase positive.

Myeloperoxidase is present in the azurophilic granules of neutrophils and their precursors. It is positive in AML M1, M2, M3, M4 and negative in AML M0. Monoblasts and monocytes may be negative or positive. When positive, the granules are smaller than in neutrophils and diffusely scattered throughout the cytoplasm.

The image given below shows bone marrow aspirate in AML - M5.

Related Pearl: FAB classification

M1-without maturation -

  • Bone marrow fibrosis (increased PDGF)

questions.text: All of the following are pillars of primary health care except:
questions.solution:
Health education is an element of primary health care, not a pillar.

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: 1,3 beta D- glucan is helpful for identification of?
questions.solution:
1,3 beta D- glucan is helpful for the identification of Invasive candidiasis (invasive fungal infections).

1-3 beta D-glucan assay test detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi except

  • Cryptococci
  • Zygomycetes
  • Blastomyces dermatitidis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is given below. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is also known as the lambda sign or delta sign.

In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening membrane.

 

Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Number of placental masses - 2
  • Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign
  • Thickness of intervening membranes ≥ 2mm

The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following structures vibrates when the stapes footplate is moved?
questions.solution:
The movement of the stapes footplate causes vibration in the scala vestibuli. This is because the scala vestibuli, which opens at the oval window, is closed by the footplate of stapes. 

The scala tympani opens at the round window.

Image depicting the transmission of sound:

questions.text: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of
questions.solution:
The given slide is pathognomonic for measles. This is a slide of a lymph node biopsy showing a Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies.

The lymphoid organs typically have marked follicular hyperplasia, large germinal centers, and randomly distributed multinucleate giant cells (Warthin-Finkeldey cells) which have eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

These are pathognomonic of measles and are also found in the lung and sputum.

questions.text: In which of the following tissues does gluconeogenesis take place?
questions.solution:
The liver and kidney are the two major locations where gluconeogenesis takes place.

During short periods of fasting, most gluconeogenesis takes place in the liver, while the remaining takes place in the kidneys. However, during periods of prolonged fasting, the kidneys become a major site of gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors. It occurs in cytosol and mitochondria of the liver and kidney. Significant substrates are glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.

Lactate generated in various tissues is transported to the liver and is converted back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis. This pathway is referred to as Cori’s cycle. The Glucose-alanine cycle is referred to as the Cahill cycle.

Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis since it lacks glucose-6-phosphatase.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

Enzymes Reaction and site Cofactors
Pyruvate carboxylase

Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate

mitochondria

Biotin, ATP

Activated by acetyl-CoA
Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase Oxaloacetate → PhosphoenolPyruvate (cytosol) GTP
Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate → fructose-6-phosphate (cytosol)

Citrate(+ve)

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (-ve)
Glucose-6-phosphatase Glucose-6-phosphate → glucose Endoplasmic reticulum  

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: A young patient is admitted to hospital with acute psychosis. He wakes up and asks for his wife even while she is there in the same room right next to him. Upon pointing her out, he states that this is not his wife and someone else is masquerading as his wife. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
According to the given scenario,

A stranger has taken the guise of Wife (Family person)

This is characteristic of Capgras syndrome.

Capgras syndrome

The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter

Fregoli’s phenomenon

  • Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Intermetamorphosis

  • A very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Doppelganger

  • A person feels he has his own impostor (duplicate) – Delusion of subjective doubles

Othello syndrome

  • It is a rare psychiatric condition marked by morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy.
  • Eg : Suspecting a faithful partner of infidelity, with accompanying jealousy.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 20-year old woman presented with generalised weakness and lightheadedness for 2 weeks. Her peripheral smear showed RBC fragments and blood investigations were notable for decreased haemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin and LDH. Which of the following isoenzymes of LDH is likely to be raised?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman with fragmented RBCs and decreased RBCs is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. LDH1 and LDH-2 isoenzymes are expressed in the RBC and particularly raised during hemolysis. 

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H-isoform (Heart) and M-isoform (Muscle)

LDH Type  Composition Location
LDH-1 HHHH Heart and RBC
LDH-2 HHHM RBC and kidney
LDH-3 HHMM Lungs, Spleen, Brain, Lymphatic tissues, Platelets
LDH-4 HMMM Liver and skeletal muscle
LDH-5 MMMM Liver and skeletal muscle

questions.text: A  9-year-old girl was run over by a car and was admitted to the hospital with obvious swelling and deformity of the left thigh. Her X-ray showed the following findings. What will be the preferred treatment in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The preferred treatment in children of ages 5-10 years with fracture shaft of the femur is elastic intramedullary nailing.

The image given below shows fracture shaft of femur treated with elastic intramedullary nailing.

Related Pearl: Age wise treatment of fracture shaft of femur

   Age group    Management
0 - 6 months Pavlik harness
6 months - 5 years Spica casting
5 - 10 years

Flexible intramedullary nails as they cannot tolerate prolonged immobilization by spica cast
>10 years Locked intramedullary nail

Gallows traction can be used in displaced fractures of the femoral shaft in children less than 2 years of age and weight less than 12kgs.

questions.text: Diamox is given to a patient with glaucoma. It is a non-competitive inhibitor of the carbonic anhydrase enzyme. Which of the following would be the effect of this drug?

choices.text: Decrease in both Km and Vmax

questions.solution:
Non-competitive inhibitors cause a decrease in Vmax.

In non-competitive inhibition:

  • The inhibitor binds to the adjacent site and not the catalytic site of the enzyme
  • The catalytic property of the enzyme is reduced and hence Vmax is decreased
  • The affinity of the enzyme is not altered and hence Km is unaltered

questions.text: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. On examination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
A slowly progressive swelling, with a variable consistency, lifting the ear lobe, is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign salivary gland tumor, primarily affects the parotid gland, particularly its superficial lobe. It is also referred to as a mixed tumor due to its combination of epithelial and mesenchymal components. This tumor most commonly occurs in females around the age of 40.

Clinical features:

  • Painless, slow-growing swelling
  • Lobulated, firm, variable in consistency
  • Lifts the earlobe
  • No facial nerve involvement
  • Curtain sign positive - cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone.
  • In case of deep lobe involvement, tonsils, and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.
  • Features of malignancy - a sudden increase in size, ulceration of the overlying skin, facial nerve palsy (involvement of facial nerve), painful swelling, and restriction of jaw movements.

Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the investigation of choice in diagnosing pleomorphic adenoma. Open biopsy is contraindicated due to the chances of injury to the facial nerve.

All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy. Radical parotidectomy is performed for malignant pleomorphic adenoma.

Other options:

Option A: Adamantinoma is a low-grade malignant tumor that usually presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling since it most commonly affects the tibial diaphysis.

Option B:  Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:

  1. Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development.
  2. Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct
  3. Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma
  4. Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)

Option D: Sebaceous cysts are retention cysts of the sebaceous glands that present as smooth, non-tender, non-transillumination swelling with a punctum (in 70% of the patients). 

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Veress needle is used to produce pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery. 

A blunt trocar is passed through the sharp needle.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger. Since the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or a penetrating towel clip to elevate it away from the underlying structures. 

Option A: An aneurysm needle (shown below) is used to catch small vessels and nerves.

Option C: Tracheal dilator is used to keep the tracheostomy open.

Option D: Urethral dilator is used to dilate urethra.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child develops hematuria after 4 days of severe diarrhea. Peripheral smear shows fragmented RBCs and thrombocytopenia. Ultrasound reveals the enlargement of both kidneys. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal vein thrombosis secondary to dehydration.

Hematuria in children following diarrhea can be due to the following:

  Hemolytic uremic syndrome Renal vein thrombosis
Onset 5-10 days after diarrhea Depends on severity of dehydration
 Renal failure Present Present
Hematuria + +
Peripheral smear  fragmented RBCs + +
Platelets Decreased Decreased
USG kidney Normal Enlarged due to congestion by renal vein thrombosis (bilateral in 67% cases)

Henoch-Schonlein purpura would present 1-3 weeks after an upper respiratory infection. It causes hematuria, non-blanching rash over the buttocks, and abdominal pain.

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy was diagnosed with tumour lysis syndrome. She was administered rasburicase. Which group does this drug belong to?
questions.solution:
Rasburicase is a recombinant urate oxidase which converts uric acid into soluble and inactive allantoin. It is more effective in reducing the urate level than allopurinol.

Recombinant uric acid oxidase is available as rasburicase and pegloticase. It is produced by genetically modified Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain. They are indicated in gout only for chronic refractory gout. It is primarily indicated for hyperuricemia associated with tumor lysis syndrome.

Pegloticase is a recombinant pegylated uric acid oxidase that is indicated for treatment of severe, treatment-refractory, chronic gout and also prophylaxis of gout.

questions.text: According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India, states are classified based on which of the following parameters?
questions.solution:
The annual parasite incidence (API) is used in classifying states/UTs according to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India. 

The Annual Parasite Incidence is calculated as: (Cases in one year ×1000) / (Population under surveillance).

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male comes with complaints of an intensely pruritic lesion that started 6 days back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing a single, intensely pruritic lesion with sharp margins and central resolution is suggestive of tinea corporis.

Central resolution is a frequent but not exclusive finding. Multiple lesions may be present.

Option B: Pityriasis rubra pilaris is a salmon-red dry scaly plaque with a nutmeg grater appearance.

Option C: Pityriasis versicolor presents as hypo or hyperpigmented macules with fine scaling.

Option D: Piedra has black or white nodules present superficially on the hair shaft.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with dyspnea, cough, and chest pain. His blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg and SpO2 was 90%. Chest X-ray is shown below. Echocardiography revealed reduced LV ejection fraction (LVEF). Which of the following will you not use in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray showing batwing appearance along with the given symptoms and reduced LVEF is suggestive of acute decompensated heart failure with pulmonary edema. Digoxin has no role in the management of this condition.

The management of acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema consists of:

  • Oxygen therapy and positive pressure ventilation
  • Reduction of preload:
    • Diuretics: Furosemide is the diuretic of choice
    • Nitrates: sublingual nitroglycerin is the first-line therapy. If pulmonary edema persists, IV nitroglycerin is administered.
    • Morphine: It is a transient venodilator that reduces preload, thereby reducing dyspnea and anxiety.
    • ACE inhibitors: They reduce both preload and afterload and are recommended for hypertensive patients.
    • Nesiritide: It is an IV recombinant BNP which is a potent vasodilator with diuretic properties.
    • Inotropic and inodilators:
      • Dopamine, dobutamine-inotropic agents.
      • Milrinone- stimulates myocardial contractility and promotes peripheral vasodilatation.
  • Intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation- or LV assist devices are used in cardiogenic shock and end-organ failure.

questions.text: The following are the mechanisms of action of methylxanthine in bronchial asthma except:
questions.solution:
Deactivation of histone deacetylase-2 is not a mechanism of action of theophylline.

Theophylline activates Histone deacetylase. The recruitment of histone deacetylase-2 by Glucocorticoid receptors (GRs) switches off inflammatory genes. Through this mechanism, theophylline enhances the anti-inflammatory effects of corticosteroids.

Theophylline is a non-selective PDE inhibitor. Its other actions include: 

  • Adenosine receptor antagonism
  • Increased IL-10 release
  • Decrease in gene transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines
  • Promotes apoptosis of granulocytes.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with heart failure with an ejection fraction < 40%. What is the treatment of choice in this patient after the euvolemic status has been achieved?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors + beta-blockers are the treatment of choice in patients with heart failure with an ejection fraction of <40% after euvolemic status is achieved using diuretics.

The first-line drugs used in congestive heart failure with reduced ejection fraction are ACE inhibitors + diuretics. Once the euvolemic status is achieved, ACE inhibitors + beta-blockers are the drugs of choice.

Beta-blockers that improve survival in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction are carvedilol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about the standard normal distribution?
  1. It has a mean of 1.0
  2. It is bell shaped
  3. It has a standard deviation of 0.0
  4. It has a variance of 1.0
  5. Standard deviation = variance
questions.solution:
A standard normal distribution is a type of normal distribution. It is bell-shaped, has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1. Thus the variance, the square of standard deviation is also 1 = the standard deviation.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: A pregnant teacher presented with complaints of difficulty concentrating at work. Investigations revealed normal MCV with blood picture as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of microcytic hypochromic RBCs indicates iron deficiency anemia, and hyper segmented neutrophils indicate anemia due to folic acid or vitamin B12 deficiency. This is also known as dimorphic anemia.

Blood picture in iron deficiency anemia:

  • Microcytic hypochromic RBCs
  • Typical photo pencil cells
  • Presence of poikilocytes (pre-erythrocytes)

Blood picture in folic acid/vitamin B12 deficiency anemia:

  • Hyper segmented neutrophils - earliest change
  • Macrocytic RBCs

questions.text: A dermoscopy examination in a patient who presented with alopecia revealed the following finding. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The image shows hyperkeratosis and plugging of the follicular ostia with keratotic material, otherwise known as the carpet tack sign or tin- tack sign, or cat's tongue sign, seen in discoid lupus erythematosus.

In cutaneous lupus erythematosus or discoid lupus erythematosus, the skin lesions present as well-defined erythematous patches with adherent scaling and peripheral hyperpigmentation. When the scale is removed its undersurface shows horny plugs that have occupied dilated pilosebaceous canals. This is called the ‘tin‐tack’ sign.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is posted for laparoscopic appendectomy. Which of the following inhalational agents is preferred for induction?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane is preferred for induction as it is the agent of choice in pediatric anesthesia.

Option A: Although both halothane and sevoflurane provide a smooth induction, sevoflurane appears to have a greater therapeutic index than halothane and hence is the preferred agent for inhaled induction in pediatric anesthesia.

Options B and D: Isoflurane and desflurane are airway irritants. Hence they are not used for induction of anesthesia as they can precipitate laryngospasm. These agents are used only during the maintenance of anesthesia.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice: 

Indication Anesthetic gas
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Daycare surgery Sevflurane>Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac surgery Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane 
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

 

Feature Drug
Most potent       Methoxyflurane > Halothane 
Least potent      Nitrous oxide > Desflurane 
Most epileptogenic   Enflurane
Most nephrotoxic Methoxyflurane 
Most hepatotoxic Halothane

questions.text: You are a junior resident in the ENT department asked to examine a patient’s larynx. The patient has complete paralysis of vocal cords following a total thyroidectomy procedure. What is the expected position of the vocal cords?
questions.solution:
Intermediate (cadaveric) position is seen in complete paralysis of the vocal cord.

  • This is a neutral position of the cricoarytenoid joint.
  • Abduction and adduction take place from this position.
  • It is not always seen in cadavers (misnomer).

Related Pearl: Positions of the Vocal Cord

Position Distance from median Seen in
Median 0 During speech/ swallowing
Paramedian 1 mm Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Intermediate/ Cadaveric 3 mm Complete paralysis
Slight abduction 7 mm Normal respiration
Full abduction 9 mm Strained respiration

questions.text: Rideal-Walker co-efficient is employed for the assessment of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The Rideal-Walker coefficient helps in assessing the power of a disinfectant relative to phenol.

It assesses this by determining the phenol coefficient (PC). A PC value of > 1 indicates that it is more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to phenol and vice versa. Traditional organisms used to test the power of the disinfectant include S. aureus and Salmonella enteric subtype typhi.

Phenol coefficient = The dilution of test disinfectant which kills microorganisms in a given time ÷ The dilution of phenol which kills the microorganism in the same time under identical conditions.

Other tests that are used for disinfectants are as follows:

  • Chick Martin test - modification of the Rideal-Walker test where disinfectants act in the presence of organic matter like feces or yeast to simulate natural conditions
  • Kelsey-Skyes test (capacity test) - tests the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when used repeatedly.
  • In-use test - determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital use

Joseph Lister first introduced phenol (carbolic acid) as an antiseptic to sterilize surgical instruments and  clean wounds. Lister's work led to a reduction in postoperative infections and made surgery safer for patients, distinguishing him as the 'Father of Modern Surgery' and 'Father of Antiseptic Surgery'.

questions.text: Which of the following transformations is seen in spermiogenesis?
questions.solution:
Spermiogenesis or spermateleosis is the process of maturation of spermatids to spermatozoa. It is the final stage of spermatogenesis.

The major events occurring during spermiogenesis include:

  • Nuclear morphogenesis and condensation
  • Formation of tail
  • Formation of acrosome
  • Rearrangement of organelles (mitochondria, centrioles, etc.)
  • Shedding off excess cytoplasm

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not responsible for an exacerbation of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Levothyroxine is not implicated in exacerbations of psoriasis.

Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  • Beta-blockers
  • Synthetic antimalarials
  • NSAIDS
  • Lithium
  • ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Interferon alpha
  • Tetracycline
  • Terbinafine
  • Gemfibrozil

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. Immunohistochemistry staining revealed the findings as shown in the image below. Which among the following adjuvant treatments will you provide for this patient?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry staining shown in the above image is ER+, PR+, and HER2+, which is triple positive or luminal type B. The adjuvant treatment of choice for this patient is endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab.

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors, hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor, hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2:

 

The adjuvant treatment modalities currently in practice include:

  • Endocrine treatment such as tamoxifen or ovarian suppression. It is given to patients with tumours that are hormone receptor-positive (either ER+ or PR+).
  • Anti-HER2 therapy with trastuzumab (humanized monoclonal antibody). It is given to patients with tumours that are HER2 overexpressing.
  • Chemotherapy as per the American Society of Clinical Oncology guidelines should be considered for patients with positive lymph nodes, HER2-positive disease, tumors >5 mm, triple-negative tumors, or with lympho-vascular invasion.

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy was undergoing treatment for CTEV with a POP cast for the past 6 months. However, his deformities have not improved. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The next best step, in this case, is posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR), also known as Turco's procedure.

By 1 year of age, posteromedial soft tissue gets contracted. This causes difficulty in the manipulation of the joint. Therefore, PMSTR is done and tight soft tissue structures (tendons, ligaments, capsule) on the posterior and medial side of the foot are cut.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: Which of the following is false about atrophic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Atrophic rhinitis is mostly a bilateral condition.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: Which among the following is false about droplet transmission?

choices.text: All droplets can travel only as far as 3 feet
Droplets are usually larger than 5 microns
It is a type of direct transmission
Basic ventilation decreases the potential for this type of transmission

questions.solution:
Droplet nuclei can travel as far as 6 feet, whereas a droplet (particle > 5μm) travels <30-60cm, as recent studies have shown.

Droplets are a mode of direct transmission of infectious agents. They are formed from saliva and nasopharyngeal secretions released during coughing, sneezing, or speaking into the surrounding atmosphere. The expelled droplets may impinge directly upon the conjunctiva, oro-respiratory mucosa or skin of close contact. This mode of transmission is seen in common cold, diphtheria, etc.

Proper basic ventilation and prevention of overcrowding reduce the potential for this type of transmission.

Related Pearl: Modes of Transmission of Communicable Diseases

Direct

Indirect

Direct contact

Droplet infection

Contact with soil

Inoculation into skin or mucosa

Vertical (transplacental)

Vehicle-borne

Vector borne – mechanical or biological

Air borne – droplet nuclei or dust

Fomite borne

Unclean hands and finger

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with a history of uncontrolled, chronic hypertension was rushed to the casualty after he had an episode of coughing out frank blood. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of posterior epistaxis, secondary to hypertension, was made. What is the site of the blood vessel most likely to be involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The most common cause for posterior epistaxis is arterial and the vessel involved is the sphenopalatine artery. It is located in the posterior end of the middle turbinate.

Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus located in the posterior end of the inferior turbinate and is also sometimes implicated in epistaxis associated with systemic conditions such as hypertension and coagulopathy. However, it only accounts for about 5-10% of all nose bleeds.

Note: Most common vessel involved in both anterior and posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatine artery and not Woodruff's plexus.

questions.text: Verocay bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it. Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles.

Palisading of nuclei is common and “nuclear-free zones” that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies.

  • In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix that may be associated with microcyst formation.

questions.text: A newborn baby has respiratory distress in the delivery room. Attempts to pass a nasogastric tube through both the nares are unsuccessful. Genital and ear abnormalities are also noted on the preliminary examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Inability to pass the nasogastric tube through both the nares along with the presence of respiratory distress, suggests choanal atresia. The presence of ear and genital anomalies along with choanal atresia suggests the diagnosis of CHARGE syndrome.

It consists of

  • Coloboma of the eye
  • Heart anomaly
  • Choanal Atresia
  • Retardation
  • Genital anomalies
  • Ear anomalies

VATER syndrome: Vertebral defects, imperforate anus, tracheoesophageal fistula, as well as radial and renal dysplasia.

Potter's sequence: Renal agenesis, oligohydramnios, and pulmonary hypoplasia

Pierre–Robin syndrome: Micrognathia, retrognathia, and glossoptosis.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a cancellous screw.

Cancellous screws have a larger thread and high pitch. Compression is produced by partial threading with a blunt tip.

A malleolar screw is a modified cancellous screw with a sharp-pointed tip.

Cortical screws have a smaller thread and low pitch. Compression is produced by over-drilling the proximal cortex.

questions.text: One eye surgeon can cater to how many CHCs according to Indian Public Health Standard norms?
questions.solution:
One ophthalmologist is recommended by the IPHS for 5 CHCs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty ward with high fever and pain abdomen.  He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. His past history was negative for long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. 

Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations. It is usually associated with ulcerative colitis as indicated by history of chronic bloody diarrhoea. 

It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics which interfere with gut motility. Features of secondary bacterial infecton and sepsis may be present. It can be complicated by intestinal perforation.

It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, and bowel rest) and medical therapy which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Indications for urgent surgery include: 

  • Frank intraperitoneal peritonitis, secondary to perforation
  • Life-threatening hemorrhage or increasing transfusion requirements 
  • Worsening systemic toxicity 
  • Worsening colonic dilatation 

Other options:

Option B: Volvulus occurs when the air-filled segment of the colon twists around the mesentery. The sigmoid colon is the most commonly involved part of the large intestine (90%). The patient can present with abdominal distension, nausea and vomiting. X-ray abdomen shows a bent inner tube or coffee bean appearance. 

Option C: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as colonic pseudo-obstruction is a functional disorder with colonic dilatation without mechanical obstruction. It occurs commonly in hospitalized patients and is associated with narcotics, bed rest and comorbid disease. X-ray shows dilatation of the colon (predominantly transverse colon) with absent mechanical obstruction.

Option D: Pneumatosis intestinalis is the presence of gas within the bowel wall seen in any part of the GI tract but most commonly in the jejunum. It is a pathognomic feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. X-ray of the abdomen will show intramural gas in the bowel.

questions.text: Examination of a child with otorrhea revealed two discharging sinuses. One was present on the floor of the left external auditory canal and the other on the left neck just below the angle of the mandible. Which of the following structures is abnormal here?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario is suggestive of a collaural fistula, and the first branchial cleft is abnormal here. 

The fistula has two openings:

  • One situated in the neck just below and behind the angle of mandible and
  • The other one in the external canal or the middle ear.

The track of the fistula traverses through the parotid in close relation to the facial nerve.

questions.text: The flow-volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:
questions.solution:
The given flow-volume curve shows decreased lung volumes (total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume) with normal shape, suggestive of a restrictive pattern. The curve is a miniature version of the normal curve with shift towards the right. It is seen in myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis presents with ventilatory restriction due to reduced respiratory muscle strength.

Asthma, emphysema, and endobronchial neoplasms present with obstructive flow patterns. 

Related Pearl: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text: Which of the following forms the trabeculated part of the right ventricle?
questions.solution:
The trabeculated part of the right ventricle is formed from the proximal 1/3rd of the bulbus cordis.

The heart tube begins to bend by day 23. This bending creates the cardiac loop. The fate of various structures formed as a result of this bending is as follows:

Given below are the heart tube and their derivatives:

 Part of the heart tube Derivative structure in the heart

Bulbus cordis

  • Proximal 1/3 
  • Middle 1/3 (conus cordis)
  • Distal 1/3 (truncus arteriosus)

 

  • Trabeculated part of Rt.ventricle
  • Outflow tract of Rt. and Lt.ventricles
  • Root and proximal portions of aorta and pulmonary artery
Primitive ventricle
  • Trabeculated part of the Lt.ventricle
Primitive atrium
  • The common atrium that splits to Rt. and Lt.atrium

questions.text: A man presents with rashes around the neck, as shown in the image below. Dietary history reveals that he has consumed jowar for a long duration. Which vitamin is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient with high intake of jowar and characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern rash is most likely suffering from pellagra. It is caused due to a deficiency of vitamin B3, known as niacin.

Pellagra, or niacin deficiency, presents with 3 classical Ds - dermatitis (photosensitive), diarrhea and dementia. Patients often have the Casal collar or Casal necklace. It is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4). If left untreated, pellagra leads to the 4th D of death. 

Jowar (sorghum) has high leucine content. This inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme responsible for the synthesis of niacin from amino acid tryptophan. Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can also cause pellagra due to their low levels of niacin and tryptophan.

questions.text: Two days after penicillin administration, a patient developed antibodies that resulted in hemolysis. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Development of antibodies resulting in hemolysis after penicillin administration is an example of a type II reaction. This is a drug-induced type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Penicillin in high doses can result in immune-mediated hemolysis via the hapten mechanism. In this, the drug attaches to surface of RBC membrane. Antibodies are produced that are targeted against this combination of penicillin and RBCs. 

Complement is activated by the attached antibody leading to the removal of red blood cells by the spleen.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A radiologist observes the following finding on a patient's  X-ray. Which condition is it seen in?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows inferior rib notching. It is seen in coarctation of aorta.

The most common location of the coarctation is just beyond the origin of the left subclavian artery. The following radiograph findings are seen in this condition:

  • Inferior rib notching (Roesler sign):
    • It occurs due to erosion of inferior margins of ribs by dilated intercostal collateral vessels that are formed to bypass the coarctation 
    • It is a late feature and is unusual in patients < 5 years of age
    • Ribs 4-8 are commonly notched and ribs 1-2 are usually spared
  • Figure of 3 or reverse 3 sign refers to an abnormality in the contour of the aorta, as shown below.

Causes for inferior rib notching (Roesler sign) are:

  • Unilateral:
    • Subclavian artery occlusion.
    • Coarctation of aorta involving left subclavian or anomalous right subclavian artery
  • Bilateral:
    • Coarctation of aorta, occlusion, aortitis
    • Takayasu’s disease and atheroma of subclavian artery
    • Pulmonary oligemia (ToF, pulmonary atresia, stenosis)
    • SVC or IVC obstruction
    • AV malformation
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. (intense pink color)

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in older adults, with a peak incidence in 30–50 years and a male:female ratio of 2:1.

It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.

It can be primary (75% of cases) or secondary (associated with systemic diseases/identifiable etiologic agents).

Microscopy:

  • Light microscopy: diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes projecting from the basement membrane are best seen with silver stains.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes
 
Image: The silver stain of the glomerulus highlights the proteinaceous basement membranes in black. There are characteristic "spikes" of basement membrane between the immune deposits of membranous nephropathy. The black basement membrane material shown here appears as projections in the capillary loops.

questions.text: A patient with cardiomyopathy in congestive heart failure has undergone a heart transplant. You observe that the following machine was used for the same. How will it be sterilized?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a a heart-lung machine. It is sterilized by ethylene oxide gas.

Ethylene oxide gas diffuses through many types of porous materials and readily penetrates some plastics and is used for sterilizing machines.
