questions.text: In a patient with a Well's score of 1.5, which of the following should be the initial investigation?
questions.solution:
A patient with Well's score of 1.5 has a low probability of pulmonary embolism. The initial investigation should be the measurement of D-dimer levels.

In a patient with a high probability of pulmonary embolism, the initial investigation is CT pulmonary angiography.

questions.text: A patient on lithium therapy is diagnosed to be hypertensive. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs is contraindicated here?
questions.solution:
Thiazides are contraindicated in patients who are on lithium therapy.

Thiazide diuretics cause significant reductions in Li+ clearance that result in toxic levels.

The K+ sparing diuretics have modest effects on lithium excretion, with a mild increase in serum levels. 

Loop diuretics have a limited impact on Li+ serum levels.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident (RTA) with chest trauma. He is conscious and speaks single words. He has a respiratory rate of 44 cycles per min and a BP of 90/40 mmHg. There is a hyper-resonance on percussing the right side of his chest. What will be your next, immediate step?

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chest trauma with a hyper resonant note on the right side suggests pneumothorax. Hemodynamic instability in this patient suggests tension pneumothorax and this is managed by immediate decompression by insertion of a needle in the appropriate place.

Pneumothorax refers to the presence of excess air in the pleural space. Entrapment of air occurs by:

  1. Primary spontaneous pneumothorax - Due to the spontaneous rupture of apical pleural blebs or cystic spaces immediately below the visceral pleura. 
  2. Secondary pneumothorax - Due to the rupture of dilated cystic spaces in lung diseases like chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) 
  3. Tension pneumothorax - Due to a one-way valve mechanism that directs airflow into the pleural space leading to a higher than atmospheric pressure environment. This leads to the affected lung being unable to expand appropriately and leads to hemodynamic instability. 


Tension pneumothorax is a surgical emergency and the excessive pressure has to be immediately relieved. A chest X-ray is not required before emergency decompression as it is a clinical diagnosis, but an X-ray should be done following chest tube insertion (option D). Tension pneumothorax is managed by immediate needle decompression in the 5th ICS (adults), followed by definitive management with a chest tube inserted in the same space.

Other options:

Option A: Intubation is performed when the patient is unresponsive post chest tube insertion. 

Option C: While IV fluids are a part of the resuscitation protocol, the management of tension pneumothorax takes higher precedence as the next immediate step.

Note: According to ATLS 10th edition

  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Virchow's triad?
questions.solution:
Hyperviscosity is not part of Virchow’s triad. However, hyperviscosity states as in polycythemia vera may, in turn, cause small vessel stasis that may cause thrombosis.

Virchow's triad in thrombosis:

  1. Injury to endothelial cells can alter local blood flow and affect coagulability.
  2. Abnormal blood flow (stasis or turbulence), in turn, can cause endothelial injury.
  3. Hypercoagulability of blood

These factors may promote thrombosis independently or in combination.

questions.text: Which of the following findings in a healthy term child would warrant further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Buphthalmos is not a normal finding in a newborn; it is suggestive of congenital glaucoma and should, therefore, be investigated.

The sclera and cornea are more elastic in early childhood and an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), therefore, leads to an expansion of the globe and the development of buphthalmos (“ox eye”).

Recommended screening for eye diseases at birth:

  • Buphthalmos
  • Cataract
  • Ophthalmia Neonatorum
  • Developmental anomalies - Microphthalmos, Anophthalmos
  • Nystagmus
  • Squint
  • Retinopathy of prematurity

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prescriptive screening?

choices.text: Screening of immigrants for yellow fever

questions.solution:
Screening of infants for phenylketonuria is an example of prescriptive screening.

Screening of disease is done to detect unrecognized disease or defect, in apparently healthy individuals, by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations, or other procedures.

The difference between prospective and prescriptive screening is given below:

  Prospective screening Prescriptive screening
Definition People screened for others benefit People screened for their own benefit
Essential purpose Disease control Case detection
Request for screening Specific request from the authority Request from physician
Example
  • Immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis syphilis, yellow fever, etc;
  • HIV screening during antenatal visits, sex workers.
  • Screening of blood donors.
  • Neonatal screening for hypothyroidism.
  • Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.
  • Testing of urine sugar for diabetes mellitus.

Note: Most common neonatal disease to be screened for is neonatal hypothyroidism.

questions.text: All of the following act through cell surface receptors except____
questions.solution:
Cortisol is a steroid hormone and acts on intracellular (cytoplasmic) receptor.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hepatitis, progressive neurological degeneration, and the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The initial step regarding investigations done for the diagnosis is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels.

Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring is a golden to greenish-brown ring of deposition of copper in the Descemets membrane of the peripheral cornea. Patients with neurological manifestations manifest with KF ring in >95% of cases.

Lab investigations in Wilson's disease would show:

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑  (>100 μg/24h)  Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

The gold standard technique for diagnosis of Wilson’s disease is percutaneous needle liver biopsy for measurement of hepatic copper levels >200 μg/g of dry weight.

Option B: The role of total serum copper in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is limited. Measurement of serum ceruloplasmin and urinary copper is preferred.

Option C: ATP7B enzyme assays have shown promise in early studies as a neonatal screening test for Wilson's disease. However, it is not yet part of routine clinical practice.

Option D: Karyotyping is done for every asymptomatic 1st and 2nd degree relative of a patient with Wilson’s disease. This helps differentiate the carriers (heterozygous) from the patients (homozygous) and can lead to early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.

questions.text: While examining a patient’s pulse, you note a tapping impulse when you raise his arm above his head. Which of the following conditions would you not suspect in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of water hammer pulse, which is not seen in left-sided heart failure.  

Collapsing pulse/Watson’s water hammer pulse is a rapidly rising pulse that collapses suddenly. This is because arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole. It is also called Corrigan's pulse.

The various causes of the collapsing pulse include

  • Physiologically, it can be present in fever and pregnancy. This is attributed to the combination of increased cardiac output and the reduction in systemic vascular resistance. 
  • Cardiac lesions such as aortic regurgitation, patent ductus arteriosus, systolic hypertension, marked bradycardia, aneurysm of sinus of Valsalva
  • High-output states such as anemia, cor pulmonale, thyrotoxicosis, arteriovenous fistula, Paget's disease, beriberi, and liver cirrhosis (secondary to chronic alcoholism)

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: Surfactant is composed mainly of_____
questions.solution:
Major surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine i.e Lecithin. Sphingomyelin is a minor surfactant.

The surfactant is a surface-active agent in water, which means that it greatly reduces the surface tension of water.

Pulmonary surfactant is produced by type 2 pneumocytes.

Most important components are

  • Phospholipid - dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) also known as Dipalmitoyl Lecithin. Lecithin is the most abundant lipid in surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol- minor component
  • Surfactant apoproteins
  • Calcium ions.
  • 4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: surfactant protein (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

Clinical relevance:

  • Tests to assess fetal lung maturity:
    • L/S ratio i.e. Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio: Ratio ≥ 2 is considered normal.
    • Shake test/Bubble test/Clement test: Formation of stable foam in the presence of surfactant.
    • Phosphatidylglycerol levels in Amniotic fluid
  • Autosomal dominant familial interstitial lung disease has absent surfactant protein SP-C.
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis - Autoantibody against GM-CSF which is involved in clearance of surfactant.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, with oliguria for 3 days. He also complained of feeling drowsy and confused while working. He also complains of episodes of breathlessness and chest pain. On examination, swelling around the eyes and both ankles was noticed. RFT was done and serum creatinine was found to be 2.28 mg/dl(Normal 0.7-1.3 mg/dl). A diagnosis of AKI was made. The patient comes under AKI staging ______.
questions.solution:
The patient comes under acute kidney injury stage 1 of the KDIGO classification as the serum creatinine is increased 1.75 times the normal value.

KDIGO criteria classify AKI on the basis of an increase in serum creatinine and/or decrease in urinary output.

  • Stage 1 – Increase in serum creatinine to 1.5 to 1.9 times baseline, or increase in serum creatinine by ≥0.3 mg/dL or reduction in urine output to <0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6 to 12 hours.
  • Stage 2 – Increase in serum creatinine to 2.0 to 2.9 times baseline, or reduction in urine output to <0.5 mL/kg/hour for ≥12 hours.
  • Stage 3 – Increase in serum creatinine to 3.0 times baseline, or increase in serum creatinine to ≥ 4.0 mg/dL or reduction in urine output to <0.3 mL/kg/hour for ≥24 hours, or anuria for ≥12 hours, or the initiation of renal replacement therapy.

questions.text: You are visiting a rural area for a vaccination drive conducted under the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. Which of the following vaccines would you not administer in this vaccination drive?
questions.solution:
Typhoid vaccine is not a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. 

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme has been introduced to ensure full immunization (>90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (VPDs) (updated from the 7 that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th-13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage.

questions.text: A patient, who is on treatment for hypertension came to the OPD for follow up. Which of the following drugs must be preferably avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors are preferably avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis.

Diuretics, beta blockers and calcium channel blockers are antihypertensive drugs that can be used in bilateral renal artery stenosis.

Note: Although it has been classically considered that bilateral renal artery stenosis is an absolute contraindication to the use of ACE inhibitors, recent studies have shown that these drugs can be used as long as the patient is carefully monitored. And therefore ACE inhibitors and ARBs are not contraindicated in bilateral artery stenosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with complaints of pruritus, easy fatiguability, and right upper quadrant discomfort. Laboratory investigations show elevation of GGT & ALP and the presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A perimenopausal age group female presenting with fatigue, pruritus, elevated GGT & ALP, and antimitochondrial antibody positivity points to a diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). 

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is characterized by chronic, non-suppurative inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It shows strong female preponderance. Most of the patients are asymptomatic; symptomatic patients present with fatigue out of proportion to the extent of liver disease or the age of the patient. Pruritus is another common complaint. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease such as hepatosplenomegaly and ascites may be seen, but may not be common. 

Laboratory findings show a cholestatic pattern of liver enzyme elevation, with increased levels of GGT and ALP. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are present in 95% of the patients with PBC. A liver biopsy is relevant in the setting of AMA-negative disease and would demonstrate florid duct lesions/ granulomas. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line treatment early in the disease course. It has been shown to slow the progress of the disease. Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for patients with decompensated liver disease due to PBC.

Other Options:

Option B: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by the presence of p-ANCA, not A anti-mitochondrial antibody.

Option C: Autoimmune Hepatitis may present with fatigue, pruritus, ⬆️ AST, ⬆️ ALT. It is often positive for anti-smooth muscle antibodies.

Option D: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis involves the fatty infiltration of the liver in non-alcoholics and usually presents with elevated liver enzymes (⬆️ AST, ⬆️ ALT) in obese individuals.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

  Primary Biliary Cholangitis Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
Antibodies

Antimitochondrial antibodies positive in most patients

Antinuclear antibodies positive

Antimitochondrial antibodies /AMA typically negative

p-ANCA-positive
Age group 40–60 years 30-45 years
Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
 Associated with

Sjogren syndrome

Hashimoto's thyroiditis 

CREST syndrome

Rheumatoid arthritis

Celiac disease

 Ulcerative colitis
Diagnosis Biopsy MRCP/ERCP-strictures 
Biopsy findings  Florid duct lesion (granuloma) Concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis    
Long-term complication Cirrhosis

Cirrhosis

Cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following study designs would you prefer for calculating the incidence of a disease?
questions.solution:
The study designs which can be used to calculate incidence are cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A study was planned to find out the effect of iron supplementation during pregnancy on the birth weight of newborn children. Two groups, one with iron supplementation and the other without, were compared. Birth weights of newborns were recorded as means + SD. Which statistical test is appropriate for the comparison of birth weights between the two groups?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, we aim to compare only the birth weights of the two groups, which is a quantitative data, and thus an unpaired t test is most appropriate.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: If correlation is given by the equation y = a + bx, what would be the nature of the graph?
questions.solution:
The equation, y = a + bx indicates a straight line. 

Related Pearl: Regression

When two variables are correlated, the value of one of the variables can be predicted from the value of the other using regression techniques.

  • Independent variable: The variable from which the other variable is calculated.
  • Dependent variable: The variable for which the value is calculated.

Types of regression:

1. Simple linear regression

  • In this, the value of one variable (y) is used to predict the value of another variable (x).
  • The regression equation is used for this purpose. It gives a straight-line relationship between the two variables.
  • It is given by the equation y = a + bx, where, a is a constant called the intercept constant and b is the regression coefficient.
  • The intercept constant is the point where the Y-axis is intercepted by the regression line. 

 2. Multiple linear regression

  • In this, more than one variable is used to predict the expected value of another variable (y).
  • Here, the expected value of y = a + b1x1 + b2x2…..bnxn where b1 and b2…..bn represent different regression coefficients and x1, x2…….xn represents the known variables.

 3. Logistic regression

  •  In some situations, we are not interested in a numerical outcome (like risk, etc) but we want a nominal or categorical one (like death/survival, developing a disease/not developing a disease)
  • Here, the relationship between the variables will not be a linear one as the outcome from survival to death in relationship with the risk factor can change suddenly. Thus these outcomes are represented by 0 and 1.
  • Using a mathematical logistic function we can transform linear regression data, such that the values of a variable y are limited to the range of 0 to 1, which would give us the probability of y occurring for the given values of variable x.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant who has not been previously vaccinated is brought to the OPD. The mother is however adamant and is allowing you to inject the baby with only one vaccine. Which of the following vaccines would you choose to administer in this situation?
questions.solution: In this situation, measles vaccine should be administered subcutaneously because, at 9 months of age, it is a priority to give the measles vaccine. OPV and vitamin A should be given orally.

questions.text: What is the culture media used to differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli?

choices.text: Thiosulphate citrate Bile salt sucrose medium

questions.solution:
Sorbitol-MacConkey agar is used to differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli.

E. coli O157:H7 does not ferment sorbitol and produces pale colonies on Sorbitol-MacConkey agar. All other strains of E. coli ferment sorbitol. Thus they produce pink colonies on Sorbitol-MacConkey agar.

O157:H7 strains do not contain β-glucuronidase and so are unable to use the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide(MUG). Thus, they give a negative MUG test.

questions.text: A 10-year old boy presents with the following type of hair loss. Which of the following is the most likely expected nail finding?

choices.text: V-shaped nicks on the distal edge

questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests alopecia areata in which geometric fine-stippled pitting of the nail is the most likely expected finding, as shown below.

Option B: Thinning of the nail with dorsal pterygium is seen in lichen planus.

Option C: V-shaped nicks on the distal edge of the nail are a feature of Darier disease.

Option D: Green nails are associated with Pseudomonas infection.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with suspected heavy metal poisoning is as shown below. What is the mechanism responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The given image shows basophilic stippling, which occurs due to inhibition of pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase.

Basophilic stippling in red blood cells occurs due to impaired clearing of cellular RNA degradation products (due to inhibition of pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase).

This finding is seen in the following:

  • Lead toxicity
  • Arsenic toxicity
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Thalassemias

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with AIDS presents to the local clinic complaining of fever, nausea, vomiting and confusion. A lumbar puncture is performed and the microscopic appearance of India ink-stained CSF specimen is given below. Which of the following drugs is most beneficial in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the India ink preparation demonstrating clear halos is suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. Flucytosine and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of this condition.

C. neoformans spreads from inhalation of the yeast cells in pigeon feces, causing infection in HIV/AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. It causes influenza-like respiratory infection in immunocompetent persons. In immunocompromised individuals, it disseminates to CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and patients may complain of headaches, neck stiffness, and disorientation, as in this case. Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of yeast cells or cryptococcal antigen in CSF. India ink stain is used to demonstrate capsulated budding yeast cells in CSF as they have a distinctive appearance because their capsules exclude ink particles. Rapid detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF and blood can also be done. Colonies develop within a few days on most media at room temperature or 37°C. Media with cycloheximide should be avoided as it inhibits Cryptococcus.

Combination therapy of amphotericin B and flucytosine has been considered the standard treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

Other options: 

Ketoconazole is usually used for chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Nystatin is also used for mucocutaneous forms of candidiasis.

Miconazole is used for topical fungal infections like oral thrush, and vaginitis.

questions.text: A young boy with a bony swelling at his knee is diagnosed to have an osteochondroma. Which of the following suggests malignant degeneration of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Malignant degeneration in an osteochondroma is suggested by the thickness of the cartilage cap exceeding 2 cm.

The cartilage cap overlies a bony stalk. It is irregular and usually cannot be seen on radiographs. Occasionally, calcification within the cap may be seen on X-rays.

Other features suggestive of malignant change in an osteochondroma are:

  • Persistence of tumor growth after skeletal maturity
  • Irregularly scattered flecks of calcification within the cartilage cap
  • Spread into the surrounding soft tissue

Malignant degeneration of an osteochondroma may lead to development of chondrosarcoma.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries gives rise to the cremasteric artery?
questions.solution:
The inferior epigastric artery, a branch of the external iliac artery gives rise to the cremasteric artery.

The cremasteric artery travels along with the spermatic cord to supply the cremaster muscle and other coverings of the cord. 

When the testicular artery is interrupted, there will be formation of collaterals from the cremasteric and deferential arteries. This will prevent the ischemia of the testis.

Note: The Fowler-Stephens orchidopexy done for undescended abdominal testis is based on this collateral formation. In the first stage, testicular vessels are clipped laparoscopically to promote the collateral formation along the vas deferens. In the second stage, the testis along with collaterals and vas deferens are mobilized to the scrotum.

Related Pearl: Transition of layers from abdominal wall to scrotum

Layers of the abdominal wall

Corresponding layers of the scrotum

Skin

Skin

Superficial fascia

(Camper and Scarpa)

Colles’ fascia and dartos muscle

External oblique muscle

External spermatic fascia

Internal oblique muscle

Cremasteric fascia and muscle

 Transverse abdominus muscle

Does not continue

Transversalis fascia

Internal spermatic fascia

Extraperitoneal fat

Extraperitoneal fat

Parietal peritoneum

Tunica vaginalis

questions.text: The function of which of the following factors is not screened by the partial thromboplastin time assay?
questions.solution:
The partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay screens the function of the proteins in the intrinsic pathway. As factor VII is only a part of the extrinsic pathway, it cannot be assessed by this test.

The factors assessed by the PTT assay are XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, and II and fibrinogen.

In this assay, clotting of plasma is initiated by the addition of negatively charged particles (e.g., ground glass) that activate factor XII (Hageman factor) together with phospholipids and calcium, and the time to fibrin clot formation is recorded.

Related Pearl: Coagulation Pathways and its Abnormalities

Test results Inherited causes Acquired causes

Prolonged PT 

Evaluates extrinsic pathway factors

Normal PT: 11-13 seconds

 Factor VII deficiency 

Mild vitamin K deficiency

Liver disease

Warfarin

Prolonged aPTT

Evaluates intrinsic pathway factors

Normal aPTT: 25-35 seconds

Factors VIII, IX, XI deficiency

Factor XII, prekallikrein, or HMW kininogen deficiency

von Willebrand disease

 Heparin, lupus anticoagulant, acquired von Willebrand disease

Prolonged PT + prolonged aPTT

Evaluates common pathway factors

Prothrombin (II), fibrinogen (I), factors V and factor X deficiencies

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Severe liver disease

Severe vitamin K deficiency

Direct thrombin inhibitor-argatroban, dabigatran

Direct factor Xa inhibitor-rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban

Fondaparinux

questions.text: An X-ray skull of a patient with marked hypercalcemia is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with his diagnosis?

choices.text: High alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
High alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, hypercalcemia along with the skull demonstrating typical 'punched out' lesions is characteristic of multiple myeloma. Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR are consistent with multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray. The lesions are purely osteolytic with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal. The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple myeloma is the vertebral column.
  • Electrophoresis: M spikes
  • Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasma cells

Related Pearl: International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady abruptly develops high-grade fever with myalgia and bone pain, 18 hours after penicillin treatment for early latent syphilis. Which of the following statements is incorrect about her condition?

choices.text: Penicillin can be used in future
Fever usually comes down within 8 hours
She must be treated with steroids

questions.solution:
A febrile reaction occurring within 24 hours of penicillin therapy for syphilis is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer's reaction. Corticosteroids are only indicated in pregnant women and patients with neurosyphilis in whom the reaction can be more serious and life‐threatening sequelae.

Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction is self-limiting and is due to lipoprotein release from the dying treponemes, which trigger cytokine release.

The patient presents with flu-like symptoms and exacerbation of skin lesions. Fever rarely lasts more than 8 hours.  Symptoms may be controlled by antipyretics. It is not a contraindication for penicillin use in the future.

Penicillin allergy is a contraindication for further use. JH reactions must be differentiated from penicillin allergy. Allergic reactions can be early or late as follows:

  • Early type- anaphylaxis within 1 hour of the first dose.
  • Late type- rash after several doses of penicillin

questions.text: Which of the following pathological changes is represented by the marked structure seen on histopathology of a liver specimen?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman or acidophil bodies. They represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis.

Councilman bodies are commonly seen in acute viral hepatitis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl complains of lower abdominal pain. History reveals she has mild pain around the time of ovulation every month and the pain subsides within a few hours. Pelvic examination is normal. How will you manage the condition?
questions.solution:
Acute lower abdominal pain around ovulation that typically subsides within a few hours indicates ovulatory pain or Mittelschmerz syndrome. It is treated conservatively with rest and NSAIDs such as acetaminophen.

The pain has been hypothesised to be due to the following reasons:

  • Swelling of the ovarian follicles around the time of ovulation
  • Disruption of the ovarian surface epithelium during ovulation
  • Irritation of the peritoneum by blood from ruptured Graafian follicle
  • Contraction of ovarian smooth muscle and ligaments
  • Contraction of the fallopian tube

The pain may be one sided or bilateral. When one sided, it can be used to predict the ovary involved in ovulation.

questions.text: A child with recurrent urinary tract infection undergoes voiding cystourethrogram. It shows reflux of urine into the pelvis and calyces, without dilation of the ureter. What is the grade of vesicoureteric reflux?
questions.solution:
Reflux of urine into pelvis and calyces without dilatation is Grade II vesicoureteric reflux (VUR).

VUR is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract. VUR is a common clinical entity. The investigation of choice for VUR is micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

VUR is graded as follows:

 GRADE DESCRIPTION
I Reflux into a non-dilated ureter
II Reflux into the pelvis and calyces without dilatation of the ureter
III Reflux is associated with mild to moderate dilatation of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces, with minimal blunting of the fornices
IV Moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces
V Gross dilatation of the ureter, pelvis, and calyses; loss of papillary impressions; ureteral  tortuosity

questions.text: A 15-year-old child has been recurrently hospitalized for infections, since 2 years of age. After a detailed evaluation, a diagnosis of Kartagener's syndrome was suspected. All of the following are components of the Kartagener triad except _____.
questions.solution:
Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad.

Kartagener’s syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesiacharacterized by the classical triad of:

  • Situs inversus
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.

As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen. Its absence, will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality.

Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary bile acid?
questions.solution:
Deoxycholic acid is not a primary bile acid. It is a secondary bile acid.

The primary bile acids are cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid synthesized from cholesterol in the liver. They are next conjugated with glycine and taurine in the liver peroxisomes to form glycocholic, glycochenodeoxycholic, taurocholic, and taurochenodeoxycholic acids.

The secondary bile acids are formed in the intestine as the primary bile acids are deconjugated and dehydroxylated by the intestinal bacteria to form deoxycholic and lithocholic acid.

These are absorbed in the ileum and returned to the liver by enterohepatic circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sesamoid bone?
questions.solution:
Os trigonum is an accessory bone, not a sesamoid bone. 

Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures. 

Examples of accessory bones:

  • Os trigonum - Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as lateral tubercle of the talus.
  • Os vesalianum - Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon. Also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady is diagnosed with Lambert- Eaton syndrome. Radioimmunoassay reveals the presence of serum antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels. Which of the following process will be affected as a result of this pathology?
questions.solution:
Exocytosis of neurotransmitters at the nerve terminals will be affected as a result of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels.

After an action potential reaches the terminal endings of a nerve, the influx of Ca2+ via voltage-gated calcium channels leads to the fusion of intracellular vesicles with cell membranes. This results in the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic space. This process will be impaired in the case of Lambert-eaton syndrome.

Exocytosis is the extrusion of membrane-bound vesicles. In exocytosis, intracellular vesicles move to the cell membrane, fuse with it and then release their contents to the extracellular fluid. Solute and water can be released from the cell via vesicles by the process of exocytosis.

Exocytosis can be:

Constitutive exocytosis:

  • Involves prompt transport of proteins to the cell membrane in vesicles, with little or no processing or storage
  • Examples
    • Goblet cells in the intestine continuously to release mucus
    • Fibroblasts in connective tissue release collagen

Regulated/ Non constitutive exocytosis:

  • Here the proteins from golgi apparatus initially enter the secretory granules, where the processing of prohormones to mature hormones occurs before exocytosis
  • Examples
    • Endocrine cells, hormones are stored in secretory vesicles and released in response to a signal from outside the cell.
    • To insert proteins into the cell membrane like aquaporin insertion

Note:

  • The term ‘regulated exocytosis’ is misleading because even constitutive exocytosis is regulated.
  • Exocytosis involves two families of proteins: Rabs, which help vesicles dock onto the membrane, and SNAREs, which facilitate membrane fusion.
  • This is Ca2+ -dependent process
  • Exocytosis, like endocytosis, requires energy in the form of ATP.

questions.text: Following an outbreak of a disease, you are asked to calculate the secondary attack rate (SAR). What is the denominator you would use?

choices.text: All people having history of contact with a case
All people susceptible in the entire area
All the people in contact with the primary case
All the close or exposed contacts those are susceptible

questions.solution:
The denominator used for calculating SAR is all the close or exposed contacts that are susceptible.

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period.

It is calculated by the formula:

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible)

Primary cases are usually excluded from the numerator and denominator.

Secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease.

questions.text: A village has a population of 30,000 people. 500 of them contracted a disease X, out of which 75 died. What is the case fatality rate?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is given by the formula:

The total number of cases of disease X= 500

The total number of deaths= 75

Hence the case fatality rate= 75/500 x 100 = 15%

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
questions.solution:
The phonocardiogram given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic stenosis. It is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc.

 Clinical findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Pulse - slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. A carotid thrill may also be palpated over these arteries.
  • Apical impulse - A double apical impulse may be recognized, and in the later stages, it may be displaced laterally.

Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Early systolic ejection sound - heard in early stages, disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid
  • Paradoxical splitting of S2 - With worsening of stenosis, delayed closure of the aortic valve occurs. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, leads to paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • S4 and S3 - heard in severe cases
  • Ejection systolic murmur - starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2. It radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver.

The image below shows phonocardiograms of normal and abnormal heart sounds.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the hospital due to extremely aggressive behaviour towards his family. His family members also say that he has become forgetful and has developed urinary incontinence. Which of the following lobes is likely to be involved in his disease process?
questions.solution:
Antisocial behavior, urinary incontinence, and impaired memory in this patient are suggestive of frontal lobe involvement.

Features of frontal lobe lesions:

  • Disinhibition
  • Lack of initiative
  • Antisocial behavior
  • Impaired memory
  • Incontinence
  • Grasp reflexes
  • Anosmia.

questions.text: A patient undergoing a dental extraction develops breathing difficulty, swelling of lips, and a diffuse rash following local anesthetic administration. Which of the following agents is commonly implicated?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicts the development of an allergic reaction to a local anesthetic agent. Allergic reactions are common with the use of procaine, an aminoester compound.

questions.text: A medical student receives a booster dose of Hepatitis B vaccination. A few hours later, she develops weakness in the abduction and lateral rotation of that arm. Which nerve is most likely to have been injured?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve or surgeon's nerve is frequently injured during inadvertent intramuscular (IM) injections. 

The course of axillary nerve:

  • It is a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus in the axilla
  • It exits the axilla through the quadrangular space to enter the arm
  • In the arm, it winds around the surgical neck of the humerus and gives cutaneous supply to the lower part of the deltoid (upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm)

Injuries to the axillary nerve can be caused by:

  • Fracture of surgical neck of humerus
  • Inferior dislocation of the humerus
  • Inadvertent IM injection

Test for axillary nerve involves testing sensations of skin over the lower part of the deltoid. In the case of axillary nerve lesions, there is a loss of sensations over this region. It is called regimental badge anesthesia.

Named nerves of the upper limb are:

  • Laborer’s nerve - median nerve
  • Musician’s nerve - ulnar nerve
  • Surgeon’s nerve - axillary nerve
  • Nerve of Bell - long thoracic nerve

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is peroral endoscopic myotomy done?
questions.solution:
Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is used in achalasia cardia.

Treatment options: 

  • Pneumatic dilatation
  • Laparoscopic myotomy
  • POEM (per-oral endoscopic myotomy)

With the use of an operating endoscope, the mucosa of the esophagus is divided around the mid to the distal third, and a submucosal tunnel is created. 

Through this tunnel, the muscular layer of the distal esophagus, lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and cardia are visualized and divided, effectively performing an endoscopic myotomy.

The major downside of POEM is that an effective anti-reflux valve cannot be created, exposing the patient to a 40%–50% risk of post-procedural gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text: Congenital nephrotic syndrome (Finnish type) is associated with the mutant protein __________.
questions.solution:
Congenital nephrotic syndrome (Finnish type) is associated with the mutant protein: Nephrin, coded for by the NPHS1 gene.

Nephrin is present in the podocyte slit diaphragm. Its mutation causes extensive podocyte effacement, resulting in severe, steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome at birth.

 

Related Pearl: Inherited causes of nephrotic syndrome

Gene involved

Protein

  Disease Phenotype Inheritance Pattern

NPHS1  (Ch.19q)

Nephrin

Autosomal recessive

Podocin

TRPC6

ACTN4

FSGS: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

NOTE: Inherited forms of nephrotic syndrome are invariably resistant to immunosuppressants (steroid resistant)

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is being evaluated for a history of recurrent seizures and abdominal discomfort. Examination reveals the following nail findings. Which of the following should she be screened for?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing periungual fibromas are strongly suggestive of tuberous sclerosis. This condition is associated with renal angiomyolipomas (present in 25–50% of cases).

Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder that has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

The clinical features of tuberous sclerosis include:

  • Skin lesions -
    • Hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules 
    • Periungual fibromas or Koenen tumors (small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or toenails)
    • Shagreen patch- roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, primarily in the lumbosacral region
    • Facial angiofibromas
    • Confetti skin lesions 
  • Neurological features -
    • Epilepsy and intellectual disability (due to cortical tubers)
    • Autism spectrum disorder
    • Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas
  • Other tumors -
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
    • Renal angiomyolipomas, renal cysts
    • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis

Angiomyolipoma is a benign renal neoplasm (hamartoma) originating from perivascular epithelioid cells (PEComa). It consists of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat in variable proportions. They are highly susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage.

The histological image of renal angiomyolipoma is given below:

questions.text: A patient presents with a painful aphthous ulcer at the tip of the tongue. Which of the following nerves gives rise to the branch carrying this sensation?
questions.solution:
Pain sensation at the tip of the tongue is carried by the lingual nerve which is a branch of the mandibular nerve.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with dull pain and heaviness over the right lower abdomen for two months. Imaging reveals a right-sided multiloculated cystic ovarian mass and cystic dilation of the appendix, with mural calcification. Which among the following conditions is most likely associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei?
questions.solution:
The condition most likely to be associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei among the given options is a mucinous ovarian tumor.

Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to abundant mucoid or gelatinous material surrounded by a thin fibrous capsule in the pelvis or abdominal cavity that results from an ovarian mucinous carcinoma with ascites. 

Mucinous ovarian tumors are predominantly true epithelial tumors and are mostly undetected primary intestinal cancers of the appendix or colon. Ovarian mucinous tumors associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei are usually metastatic tumors.

Well-differentiated type of mucinous tumors resembles those that originate from the intestine or endocervix. These are mucin-secreting adenocarcinomas. Advanced mucinous ovarian tumors have the worst prognosis. 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: A 35-year-old man working as a clerk in an office presents with the following lesion in his elbow. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of olecranon bursitis. It is also known as Draughtman's elbow/student's elbow/ miner's elbow.

Olecranon bursitis is a chronic inflammation of the olecranon bursa, as a result of repetitive minor injuries. It is seen in people who tend to keep their elbow rubbed against the desk. The constant friction against the olecranon bursa can lead to the development of bursitis.

Culture and aspiration of the bursa fluid are done to rule out infection. Most cases can be managed conservatively with NSAIDs and local steroids. A chronically enlarged bursa will require excision.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin

Golfer's elbow

Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the out-patient with complaints of diminished vision along with floaters and flashes. The ophthalmologist uses the following instrument to assess the retinal lesions. Which of the following statements is true regarding the ophthalmoscopy done using the instrument shown in the image below?

choices.text: Area of field in focus is 2 disc diameters.
The image produced is real and inverted.

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is an indirect ophthalmoscope, and the procedure is known as indirect ophthalmoscopy.

An indirect ophthalmoscope produces an inverted, or reversed, real image of 2 to 5 times magnification.

The area of field in focus is about 8 disc diameters.

It is a binocular, self-illuminated device where the condensing lens is usually required, and stereopsis is present.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect ophthalmoscopy

questions.text:
A 20-month-old child diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is receiving treatment in your clinic. Given below are five statements regarding the treatment. Pick out the incorrect statements.
  1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started from day 1 of admission.
  2. The stabilization phase would ideally include the first seven days of treatment.
  3. Vitamin A is given daily to overcome micronutrient deficiency.
  4. F-75 feeds can be initiated in split portions.
  5. Promote skin to skin contact with mother to avoid hypothermia.
questions.solution:
Vitamin A is not given daily in the treatment of SAM. It is given on day 1, day 2 and day 14.

The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.

Mnemonic: SHIELDED

  • Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia) 
  • Hypothermia
  • Infection
  • ELectrolyte imbalance
  • DEhydration
  • Deficiency of nutrients

Rehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks.

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL.  After 3 days, transition to F100 feeds is made which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important factor in determining the prognosis of a child with Wilms tumor?

choices.text: Age less than 1 year at presentation

questions.solution:
The most important prognostic factor in Wilms tumor is the histology of the tumor.

Wilms tumor (WT) is characterized by abnormal proliferation of the metanephric blastema, with no differentiation into tubules or glomeruli. It usually arises from three tissue elements (triphasic tumor):

  1. Blastema (poor prognosis if the blastemal component is more)
  2. Epithelium 
  3. Stroma

Wilms tumors lacking anaplasia (presence of atypical, polyploid mitotic figures, large nuclear size, and hyperchromasia) are designated as having “favorable histology".

questions.text: Which proton pump inhibitor should be avoided in a patient on warfarin anticoagulation?
questions.solution:
Omeprazole should not be used in a patient on warfarin therapy as it decreases the metabolism of warfarin. 

All PPIs are metabolized by hepatic P450 cytochromes, including CYP2C19 and CYP3A4, and may interfere with the metabolism of the other drugs. It inhibits the metabolism of clopidogrel, diazepam, and phenytoin.

Note: There is disagreement among different authors regarding the PPIs and their interactions with the metabolism of other drugs.

  • Goodman and Gilman mention that lansoprazole and rabeprazole along with omeprazole and esomeprazole interact with the metabolism of warfarin.
  • Katzung and various online sources agree that lansoprazole and rabeprazole do not or minimally interact with warfarin metabolism.
  • All of them agree that pantoprazole does not or minimally interacts with warfarin metabolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a history of severe chest pain radiating to the back and difficulty in breathing following several episodes of vomiting. PR- 110bpm and  BP- 80/50 mm of Hg. On examination, there is palpable crepitus over the chest wall. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Most common in lower third of esophagus
Iohexol is used as contrast agent
Cervical esophagostomy and gastrostomy is done in early presentation
Most common cause of mortality is mediastinitis

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to Boerhaave's syndrome. Primary closure is done in stable patients presenting within 24 hrs and not cervical esophagostomy with gastrostomy.

Boerhaave syndrome is the spontaneous perforation of the esophagus caused due to episodes of vomiting. During vomiting, the pressure in the esophagus rises rapidly and the esophagus ruptures at the weakest point. They usually have a history of heavy meal intake and alcohol abuse.

Clinical features include Mackler's triad:

  • Retching
  • Chest pain 
  • Subcutaneous emphysema 

The diagnosis is made by contrast esophagogram(iohexol) in unstable patients or contrast-enhanced CT scan, in stable patients.

Treatment includes primary closure within 12 hours of the injury for a better prognosis. If the patient is unstable or presents late, the perforated part is resected and cervical esophagostomy is performed. A T-tube is placed into the esophagus along with appropriately located drains and a feeding jejunostomy or gastrostomy is performed for nutrition.

Most common cause of mortality in Boerhaave syndrome is mediastinitis (40% to 50%).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman who is taking OCPs presents with weakness and fatigue. Her laboratory investigations and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 5 gm%

TLC - 1200 cells/mm3

Platelet count - 60,000/μL

MCV - 102 fl

MCH - 40 pg/cell
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to the following reasons:

  • History of OCP use
  • Hemogram shows decreased hemoglobin and increased MCV
  • Peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, macroovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: Which of the following DNA repair mechanism is defective in Lynch syndrome?
questions.solution:
Mismatch repair is defective in Lynch syndrome also called Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer(HNPCC).

It is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers including endometrial cancer(second most common).

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after sustaining injuries in a fight. He was able to talk but was disoriented and confused. He could open his eyes spontaneously and also responded to pain by localizing it. What is his Glasgow coma scale score?
questions.solution:
For the given scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 13.

To arrive at this the following clinical clues have to be considered:

  • Eye response: The patient is able to spontaneously open his eyes = 4.
  • Verbal response: The patient is able to speak but is confused = 4
  • Motor response: The patient is able to localize a painful stimulus = 5

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented to the hospital with malaise, pain abdomen, and blood in the stools. On examination, the patient also has foot drop. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, elevated ESR, and negative ANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is polyarteritis nodosa. The presence of foot drop is highly suggestive of mononeuritis multiplex. Mononeuritis multiplex in combination with malaise, pain abdomen, blood in the stools, anemia, elevated ESR, and negative ANCA is highly suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa.

Polyarteritis nodosa is necrotizing arteritis involving medium-sized vessels. It may present insidiously with fever, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia, myalgia, or neuropathy. Mononeuritis multiplex is most commonly seen as a foot drop. Patients also develop symptoms related to vasculitis of a particular organ system. Cutaneous manifestations are skin ulcers, digital gangrene, and livedo reticularis. Renal involvement is common and manifests as hypertension or renal failure. GI involvement presents as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, bleeding, bowel infarction, and perforation.

There are no specific serologic tests. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, leukocytosis, elevated ESR. Patients with classic polyarteritis nodosa are negative for ANCA. Diagnosis is confirmed only by confirming vasculitis on biopsy.

Other options:

Option B: Takayasu arteritis is an inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium- and large-sized arteries- usually aortic arch and its branches. It is suspected in a young woman with decreased or absent peripheral pulses, blood pressure discrepancies, and arterial bruits. There is elevated ESR, mild anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels. Diagnosis is confirmed with arteriography.

Option C: Cogan's syndrome is characterized by interstitial keratitis and vestibulo-auditory symptoms. Vasculitis of aorta and aortic valve may also be associated.

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis is a granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tracts with glomerulonephritis. Laboratory findings include a markedly elevated ESR, mild anemia, leukocytosis, hypergammaglobulinemia, elevated rheumatoid factor. ANCA is usually positive.
