questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and histological image are suggestive of Barrett’s esophagus.

The histological image above shows the transition between normal squamous epithelium and the mucin-filled glands, indicating intestinal-type metaplasia with plenty of goblet cells.

Barrett’s esophagus, which is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa. It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Hence, patients diagnosed with Barrett’s esophagus must be subjected to a regular surveillance endoscopy annually or with 2-year intervals, provided no dysplasias have been detected. The presence of dysplasia is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer affected segment length, increased patient age, and caucasian race.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visits a gynecologist with complaints of irregular and infrequent menstrual cycles. She is also upset that she has gained 12 kg over the past few months. Her face appears as shown in the image below. Her blood pressure at this visit is 144/98 mm Hg and she has multiple purple striae over her abdomen. Which of the following investigations should you advise this patient?

choices.text: Serum testosterone levels and abdominal USG

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing moon facies with acne and hirsutism are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome. It can be diagnosed with the help of a single midnight serum cortisol measurement.

Option A: Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison's disease.

Options C and D: Serum testosterone, abdominal USG, and LH: FSH ratio, are used to confirm a diagnosis of the polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Though PCOS can present with similar features, it is not typically associated with moon facies, purple striae, or hypertension.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: Charcot’s triad includes all the following except:
questions.solution:
Altered mental status is included in Reynold’s pentad and not in Charcot’s triad.

Related Pearl: Charcot and Reynold's Triad

Charcot's triad - in acute cholangitis

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Fever with chills
  • Jaundice

Reynold's pentad - in acute suppurative cholangitis

  • Charcot’s triad + Altered mental status + Hypotension

questions.text:
Match the following specialized macrophages with the tissues they are found in.
Cell Tissue
I. Hofbauer cells A. Kidney
II. Histiocytes  B. Placenta 
III. Kupffer cells  C. Connective tissue 
IV. Microglia D. Liver 
V. Mesangial cells  E. Brain
questions.solution:
The correct answer is I-B; II-C; III-D; IV-E; V-A.

Cell  Tissue 
I. Hofbauer cells B. Placenta 
II. Histiocytes  C. Connective tissue 
III. Kupffer cells  D. Liver 
IV. Microglia E. Brain
V. Mesangial cells  A. Kidney

Macrophages can be divided into:

1. Blood macrophages (monocytes) are the largest of the myeloid cells found in the peripheral blood. They survive for 3 days. 
2. Tissue macrophages present in different organs. They survive for months. 
The main functions of macrophages are phagocytosis and antigen presentation.

The specialised (tissue-specific) macrophages present in different tissues are listed below: 

  1. Peripheral blood: Monocytes
  2. Placenta: Hofbauer cells
  3. Liver: Kupffer cells
  4. Brain: Microglial cells
  5. Kidney: Mesangial cells
  6. Lungs: Alveolar macrophages
  7. Bone: Osteoclasts
  8. Connective tissue: Histiocytes

questions.text: What is the normal angle of the neck of the femur to the shaft?
questions.solution:
The normal angle of the neck of the femur to the shaft is approximately 125°. This is known as neck-shaft angle or angle of inclination.

This facilitates the movement at the hip joint, enabling the limb to move freely.

  • When the angle is > 135°, the condition is known as coxa valga
  • When the angle is < 120°, the condition is known as coxa vara

The image given below shows the normal neck-shaft angle of femur.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with Willis-Ekbom disease (WED), what would you prescribe as a first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug of choice for Willis-Ekbom Disease (restless leg syndrome) is ropinirole.

Restless leg syndrome (Willis-Ekbom Disease) is characterized by the following:

  • Subjective sensation creepy-crawly feeling in the limbs, and irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep.
  • When the individual is lying in bed and relaxing, he or she is disturbed by these sensations.
  • Then he or she moves the legs and again tries to fall asleep.
  • This cycle sometimes continues for hours and results in profound insomnia.

Treatment modalities include:

Pharmacological:

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine

Non-pharmacological:

  • Avoiding alcohol use close to bedtime
  • Massaging the affected parts of the legs
  • Taking hot bath
  • Applying hot or cold to the affected areas
  • Engaging in moderate exercise

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling which moves with deglutition as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A thyroglossal cyst is the only midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition. This is because the thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid. 

Thyroglossal duct cyst:

It is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection. It represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline. The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through, or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. 

Clinical features of thyroglossal cyst:

  • Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. 
  • Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), nontender, mobile, often transilluminant.
  • Thyroid fossa is empty, if there is no thyroid in the normal location.

Complications of thyroglossal cyst:

  • The most common complication is infection.
  • Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which bursts open or due to inadequate removal of the cyst.
  • 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%).
Neck swellings that move with deglutition are:
  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis 
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

However, only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This is because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of the tongue to the isthmus of the gland. 

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves the excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following symptoms is Nesbitt’s procedure done?

choices.text: Penile deformity, painful erection and palpable penile plaques
Downward directed stream of urine with bending of penis
Popping sound during sexual intercourse, painful and flaccid penis

questions.solution:
Penile deformity, painful erection, and palpable penile plaques are features associated with Peyronie's disease. Nesbitt’s procedure is the most common procedure done for this condition. 

Peyronie's disease is caused due to injury to tunica albuginea resulting in microhemorrhages. This leads to excess collagen deposition, calcification, and penile plaques. Hence, the penis bends towards the side of the plaque. This causes difficulty during sexual intercourse. It is also associated with Dupuytren's contracture.


Nesbitt's procedure corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis. This procedure is done once the active phase subsides as the bend increases during the active phase (18-24 months).  

Option B: Downward directed stream of urine with bending of the penis are symptoms of hypospadias.

Option C: Persistent erection lasting longer than 4 hours is called priapism.

Option D: Popping sound during sexual intercourse, painful and flaccid penis is suggestive of fracture of the penis. There will be bluish discoloration of the penis and scrotum due to extensive bruising (eggplant deformity). Management is mainly surgery for evacuation of hematoma and repair of corpora.

The image below shows eggplant deformity in fracture of the penis:

questions.text: The CT scan image of a 50-year-old female with backache is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the classical polka dot sign(on axial section) and the Corduroy sign /jailhouse appearance(on vertical section). These are seen in vertebral hemangioma.

These signs are the result of the replacement of normal cancellous bone by thickened vertical trabeculae.

The corduroy sign is shown in the following image.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of low mood for the past 2 weeks, reduced socialization, decreased appetite, and inability to sleep for the past 3 months. She also complains of frequent backache and headache, with early morning awakening. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of low mood for the past 2 weeks along with reduced appetite, reduced interest in socialization, somatic symptoms, and disturbed sleep, points towards a diagnosis of depression (major depressive disorder). 

The diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period. Atleast one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupa­tional, or other important areas of functioning.

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

D. The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaf­fective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

Other Options:

Option A: Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced and the gain obtained is primarily psychological. 

It can be associated with depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, and somatization disorders. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. Anesthesia and paresthesia of the extremities, abnormal movements, and gait disturbance are the other features commonly seen. 

Option B: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months. It equally affects men and women and is commonly seen in the third decade of life. It is associated with poor insight. Patients believe that they have a serious disease that has not yet been detected and they can­not be persuaded otherwise. Their convictions persist despite negative laboratory results, the benign course of the alleged disease over time, and reassurances from doctors.

Option C:  Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. It is distinguished from major depressive disorder by the fact that patients mention that they have always been depressed. There will never be an episode of mania/hypomania in this condition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back between the scapulae. The CT of this patient is given below. What is the major risk factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the CT finding of a second column of blood after an intimal tear is the classic presentation of an aortic dissection. The major risk factor for aortic dissection is hypertension.

Dissection occurs when blood enters into the media to form a blood-filled channel between the laminar planes of the media. It usually occurs due to a tear in the intima which allows blood in the lumen to flow into the media. It may also occur due to the rupture of vasa vasorum.

It occurs due to:

  • Hypertension
  • Connective tissue defects like Marfan syndrome 
  • Iatrogenic trauma during coronary catheterization or cardiopulmonary bypass

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. What would be the most likely pathology?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of the patient presenting with pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye following trauma by a vegetative matter is suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer.

Fungal corneal ulcer also known as mycotic keratitis is usually caused by trauma from vegetative matter such as branches of trees, leaves and animal tails. Injudicious use of topical steroids and antibiotics increases the predisposition to develop secondary fungal keratitis.

Mycotic keratitis can be caused by

  • Filamentous fungi such as Aspergillus and Fusarium
  • Yeasts such as Candida and cryptococcus
  • Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma and Blastomyces

Typically in fungal corneal ulcers, the signs are more prominent than the symptoms. The symptoms of fungal keratitis are similar to that of bacterial ulcers which include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, blurred vision, and redness of the eyes.

A typical fungal ulcer has the following signs:

  • Greyish white looking dry corneal ulcer with rolled out margin.
  • Feathery finger-like extensions into the corneal stroma under intact epithelium
  • Wessley ring which is a sterile immune ring that occurs due to the deposition of immune complexes
  • Multiple small satellite lesions around the ulcer
  • Hypopyon: The hypopyon in fungal ulcer is immobile and unsterile unlike bacterial ulcer (sterile hypopyon)
  • Perforation is rare
  • Corneal vascularization is usually absent.

A diagnosis of fungal ulcer is made by a typical history of trauma with vegetative matter followed by clinical examination and KOH mount or SDA agar cultures from corneal scrappings.

The image below depicts a fungal corneal ulcer with the arrowhead indicating a satellite lesion.

Other options:

Option A: Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris up to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. Infectious uveitis can be caused by the exogenous entry of the organisms following penetrating injuries, perforation of corneal ulcer, and post-intaocular operations.

Acute anterior uveitis presents with symptoms of pain, photophobia, lacrimation, blurring of vision and redness of the eye. Signs of anterior uveitis include: 

  • Aqueous flare -  It is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis, it occurs following the leakage of protein particles into the aqueous humor.
  • Keratic precipitates(KP) - These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. They are proteinaceous cellular deposits at the back of the cornea arranged in a triangular fashion. These include mutton fat KP's as seen in granulomatous uveitis and granular KP's of non granulomatous uveitis.
  • Iris nodules: typically occur in granulomatous uveitis. Koppe's nodules are at the pupillary border and Busacca's nodules are situated near the collarette.

Option C: Conjunctivitis is the inflammation of the conjunctiva of which the bacterial conjunctivitis is the most common. Acute bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by marked conjunctival hyperemia, swelling of the conjunctiva(chemosis), edematous eyelids, sticking together of lid margins and mucopurulent discharge from the eye.

The image shows a patient with bacterial conjunctivitis.

Option D: Corneal laceration: Partial corneal laceration or lamellar corneal laceration occurs from a blunt trauma and is treated by patching and antibiotics.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.solution:
The above image is Ayre's T piece, which is a type of Mapleson's E circuit.

Ayre's T piece

Suitable for use in neonates and children due to low dead space and low resistance.

questions.text: A mother brought her 8-year-old son to the OPD with complaints of refusal to eat and poor weight gain. The child complained that food often gets stuck in his throat. Endoscopy revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing multiple stacked esophageal rings are characteristic of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Differentiating features between eosinophilic esophagitis and GERD:

Factors Eosinophilic esophagitis GERD
Dominant symptoms Dysphagia Heartburn and regurgitation
Food impaction Common Uncommon
Gender Male predominance Male = female
Age Children, young adults Middle age

  • Multiple stacked rings (feline esophagus) and longitudinal furrows
  • Punctate exudates
  • Strictures and narrow-caliber esophagus
  • Crepe-paper esophagus
Normal findings in <10% patients
  • Erosions and ulcers
  • Strictures
  • Barrett's esophagus and adenocarcinoma
Normal findings on endoscopy in majority of patients

Histology ≥15 eosinophils/hpf <7 eosinophils/hpf
Etiology Atopic or immune-mediated, acid reflux is not prominent Acid reflux

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs)

questions.text: A patient presents with the following skin finding. You would advise supplementation with which of the following?

choices.text: Vitamin B complex and vitamin K
Safflower oil and vitamin B complex

questions.solution:
The image shows rough, dry skin suggestive of phrynoderma. It is treated by supplementation of safflower oil (rich in essential fatty acids) and vitamin B complex.

Phrynoderma or toad skin is a type of follicular hyperkeratosis. It is caused by a deficiency of vitamin E, B, A, C, and essential fatty acids.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy.

The changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are:

Increase

Decrease

Unaffected
  • Tidal volume
  • Inspiratory capacity
  • Minute O2 uptake
  • Minute ventilation
  • Functional residual capacity
  • Expiratory reserve volume
  • Residual volume
  • Total lung capacity
  • Respiratory rate
  • Vital capacity
  • Inspiratory reserve volume 

(Mnemonic: TIMM increases in pregnancy)

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 39 weeks of gestation. On examination, you notice the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor.

This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.

This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.text: Chyme is propelled forward in small intestine by_______
questions.solution:
Chyme is propelled forward in the intestine by the peristaltic movement.

Chyme is a thick semifluid mass of partially digested food and digestive secretions that is expelled by the stomach into the duodenum.

Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Segmentation consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward. 

It is the small intestine’s primary method of motility during digestion of a meal.

Migrating motor complexes (MMC) are the peristaltic motor patterns that occur during fasting. They migrate from the stomach to the distal ileum.

Haustrations are the characteristic saclike segments seen in the large intestine.

Related Pearl: Types of gastrointestinal motility

questions.text: A pregnant woman delivered a baby with the normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half an hour she started bleeding per vaginal. On examination, she was hypotensive and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. USG showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The reason for the postpartum hemorrhage in the given patient is likely due to the succenturiate lobe being torn away and left behind at the time of placental delivery, as seen with cases of Placenta succenturiata.

Placenta succenturiata refers to the abnormal placenta where an additional lobe/lobes of placental tissue are located a few centimeters away. The ancillary lobes are smaller in size when compared with the main placental tissue (note: Bilobed placenta has two lobes of equal sizes).These lobes have vessels that course through the membranes connecting them to the main placental tissue.

Placenta succenturiata can be associated with complications like vasa previa (fetal hemorrhage), postpartum hemorrhage due to retained placental tissues, infection such as endometritis, Subinvolution of uterus and Placental polyp formation.

An image of this variant is given below where L1,2,3 depicts smaller lobes, UC is the umbilical cord, and M is the intervening membrane. 

The below given image shows a Bilobed or Bipartite or duplex placenta which is different from placenta succenturiata. The lobes in bilobed placenta are nearly equal in size. The umbilical cord is attached into a connecting chorionic bridge or into the interven­ing membranes in between the two placental lobes.

Other options:

Option A: Placenta membranacea is an unduly large and thin placenta that develops from both the chorionic frondosum and the chorion leave. It is associated with an increased risk of placenta previa or accreta and retained placenta and its complications.

Circummarginate placenta (option C) and Circumvallate placenta (option D) are a type of extrachorial placentation.

In extrachorial placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate.The chorionic plate does not extend upto the placental margin. The membranes (amnion and chorion) are rolled back upon themselves to form a ring leaving a rim of bare placental tissue (extrachorial portion)

Circummarginate placenta-A thin fibrous ring is present at the margin of the chorionic plate where the fetal vessels appear to terminate.

Circumvallate placenta - The fetal surface is divided into a central depressed zone surrounded by a thickened ring which is composed of a double fold of amnion and chorion. Vessels radiate from the cord insertion as far as the ring and then disap­pear from the view.

Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are preterm delivery, abortions, growth retardation, antepartum hemorrhage, retained placenta, and hydrorrhea gravidarum.

A specimen of circumvallate placenta is shown below:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G3P2L2, with a history of LSCS, is brought to the ER with complaints of abdominal pain, hematuria, and vaginal bleeding. On examination, the patient is hypotensive along with foetal bradycardia and non-reassuring foetal heart rate tracing. Which of the following is the preferred IV induction agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemodynamic compromise secondary to uterine scar dehiscence. Ketamine is the preferred induction agent in this patient.

Ketamine is the preferred induction agent for patients with hemodynamic compromise as it helps maintain arterial pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output due to sympathetic stimulation and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition.

Other properties of ketamine are:

  • Dissociative anesthesia with profound analgesia
  • Preserves laryngeal and pharyngeal reflex
  • Does not depress respiration
  • Bronchial dilatation

Options A and B: Propofol and thiopentone cause hypotension following induction. 

Option D: Etomidate, although cardiostable causes a mild reduction in peripheral vascular resistance that is responsible for a slight decline in arterial blood pressure.

questions.text: In the post-op recovery room, a patient who had undergone a thyroidectomy suddenly experienced dyspnea with stridor. He was immediately sent back to the OT. What is the most likely cause for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Development of a hematoma post-thyroidectomy may lead to venous edema of the larynx. This can cause airway obstruction and respiratory distress. It is evacuated promptly at bedside or through surgical re-exploration.

Complications of thyroidectomy:

  • Haemorrhage - most common complication overall
  • Nerve injury 
    • External laryngeal nerve - hoarseness (more common)
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - hoarseness if unilateral, life-threatening aspiration and aphonia if bilateral
  • Respiratory obstruction
    • Laryngeal edema - most common cause of respiratory obstruction
    • Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
    • Laryngomalacia
    • Tension hematoma
  • Hypoparathyroidism - infarction of parathyroids
  • Thyroid storm - inadequately prepared for surgery
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Recurrent thyrotoxicosis
  • Wound infection, stitch granuloma, keloid 

Option C: Venous embolism typically occurs after a prolonged period of immobilization.

questions.text: A forensic expert is assisting the police in investigating the death of a woman. On examination, he notices the Kevorkian sign. What is the estimated time since the death?
questions.solution:
The Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels. It lasts for about 1 hour.

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized by using an ophthalmoscope as shown below.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea - dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to falling in intraocular pressure. IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death
  • Tache Noir: A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye. It appears within 3-4 hours of death
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous - linear increase up to 100 hours following death. It is helpful in determining the time since death

questions.text: After assessing a young child treated for unilateral retinoblastoma, you note significant delays in the cognitive and fine motor domains. The baby can stand without support and creep well. Normally, the highest fine motor skill a baby of this age is expected to have is ________
questions.solution:
A baby that stands without support is most likely to be 12 months. The highest fine motor skill she is expected to have is mature pincer grasp (12 months).

Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months. Immature pincer grasp is seen at 9 months. Child begins to scribble after 15 months.

Fine motor development is critically linked with hand-eye coordination. Children who have disease-related loss of vision in early infancy develop difficulties in visuomotor integration and lags behind in fine motor milestones.

The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that children be screened at 18 and 24 months or whenever a parent or provider has a concern. Milestone tracker apps are being used by the parents to monitor the development of their child.

questions.text: A patient is given a set of 20 pictures similar to the one shown below and asked to give his interpretation of the same. Which of the following is being assessed by this test?
questions.solution:
The picture given is employed for personality assessment in the thematic apperception test (TAT). It is a projective test intended to evaluate a person's personality through their responses to ambiguous pictures.

The TAT consists of a series of 20 pictures that depict individuals of both sexes and of different age groups involved in different activities. The stories that the patient makes up concerning the pictures reflect the patient's own needs, thoughts, feelings, and view of the future.

Related Pearl: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 

 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)

 

 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)

The image given below is the first card, drawn by Christiana D. Morgan. It is a recreation of a photograph taken by Samuel Lumiere of violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, in 1928.

 

Sentence Completion Test

Uses Characteristics
Used to identify worries and problems using verbal associations

Projective test

Patients complete sentences started by the examiner

questions.text: The dose-response curves of four different drugs are shown here. Which of the following drugs is the most potent?
questions.solution:
Drug 2 is the most potent among the other given drugs.

The potency and efficacy of a drug are represented by the dose-response curve.

The potency of the drug is defined as the concentration of the drug which produces half of the maximal effect. The drug which produces half of the maximum effect in the least concentration is said to be more potent. The more the curve is towards the left, the more the potency.

Efficacy is the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. If the response is more, the drug is said to be more efficacious. Drug 4 is most efficacious.

questions.text: Fast vibration sense is mediated by ______.
questions.solution:
Fast vibration sense is mediated by Pacinian corpuscles. 

Pacinian corpuscle is the most sensitive mechanoreceptor in the somatosensory system. It is responsive to high-frequency (30–500 Hz) vibratory stimuli and pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors.

Option A: Merkel's disc sense touch and sustained pressure. They are slow adapting receptors. Present in epidermis.

Option B: Meissner's corpuscle sense tap and flutter. They are present in dermal papillae. They are rapidly adapting receptors. 

Option D: Ruffini endings sense skin stretch and fluttering vibration.

The following image shows Merkel's disc and Meissner's corpuscle being more superficial (reponsive to touch) than Ruffini endings and Pacinian corpuscle (which are deeper in the dermis and responsive to pressure).

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: A 52-year-old man diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis requires second-line agents for his therapy. However, he is found to have a creatinine clearance of  50 ml/min. Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be started in this patient without dosage adjustment?
questions.solution:
Moxifloxacin is metabolized predominantly by the liver and hence can be used safely in patients with decreased renal function without dose adjustment.

Fluoroquinolones, especially moxifloxacin, may be used as part of multiple-drug regimens for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis.

Most of the available fluoroquinolones are cleared predominantly by kidneys and dosage needs to be adjusted in patients with renal failure. But fluoroquinolones such as moxifloxacin and pefloxacin undergo hepatic elimination and so should be used carefully in patients with liver disease.

questions.text: You want to prescribe a drug that increases uveo-scleral outflow while treating a patient with open-angle glaucoma. Which of the following drugs would you choose?
questions.solution:
The class of anti-glaucoma drugs which act by increasing the uveo-scleral outflow are prostaglandin analogues.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a ceramic factory. What particle size of the dust inhaled would you be most concerned about?
questions.solution: Inhalation of dust particles in the size range of 0.5 to 3 microns is considered to be the most dangerous. It can lead to various occupational lung diseases called pneumoconioses.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the area marked on the image of the visceral surface of the spleen?
questions.solution:
The area marked on the given image of the visceral surface of the spleen is related to the left kidney.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.

Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rod-like kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.

questions.text: Which of the following, is the rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Phosphofructokinase (PFK-1) is the rate limiting enzyme in glycolysis.

Mg2+ serves as the co-factor for the enzyme. This step is the committed step of glycolysis.

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-month-old infant to the ENT department with complaints of difficulty in breathing. On examination, you notice  biphasic stridor. Rigid bronchoscopy shows subglottic hemangioma. Which of the following is not included in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is of congenital subglottic hemangioma. Embolization is not preferred in congenital laryngeal conditions. All congenital laryngeal conditions tend to regress with growth.

The principal management is conservative as many hemangiomas involute spontaneously. Depending on the status of the airway, treatment can involve:

  • To wait and watch
  • Steroid therapy
  • Tracheostomy and observation

If the condition does not regress with time, the modalities of treatment include:

  • LASER excision
  • Laryngofissure and excision
  • -pexy and -plasty procedures (epiglottopexy, supraglottoplasty, etc)

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to the OPD with complaints of weakness for the past 3 months. She is diagnosed to have microcytic hypochromic anemia. The stool microscopy reveals the following. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of iron deficiency anemia and the stool microscopy showing the egg is suggestive of infection by Ancylostoma duodenale.

Eggs of both Ancylostoma duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator americanus (new world hookworm) are identical. The hookworm eggs are oval or elliptical in shape, colorless, and non-bile stained. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. The ovum is segmented with 4 to 8 blastomeres. There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and eggshell. Eggs float in the saturated salt solution.

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin or subcutaneous tissue. The larvae are then carried in the venous circulation to the heart and lungs, where they may cause mild transient pneumonitis or bronchitis. They migrate up the respiratory tract to the pharynx, are swallowed, and reach the small intestine producing epigastric pain, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. 

A. duodenale or N. americanus ingest blood, secrete anticoagulants, and interfere with the absorption of iron, vitamin B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition resulting from blood loss. The average blood loss of the host per worm per day is 0.2 mL with Ancylostoma duodenale and 0.03 mL with Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 50-year-old housewife with diabetic nephropathy and receiving dialysis weekly comes to your clinic with an accidental burn on her left hand. On examination, 2nd-degree burns are seen. Which of the following opioids should not be prescribed to her for analgesia?
questions.solution:
Pethidine (meperidine) should not be prescribed to her as it is contraindicated in patients with renal failure.

In renal failure, there is an accumulation of its metabolite norpethidine which causes excitatory syndrome consisting of hallucinations, tremors, muscle twitches, and convulsions. Therefore, pethidine is avoided in renal failure patients.

Methadone, alfentanil, and fentanyl primarily undergo hepatic metabolism.

Related Pearl: Anaesthetic drugs in patients with reduced renal function

Inhaled anaesthetics:

  • Safe- halothane, isoflurane, desflurane
  • Unsafe- methoxyflurane, enflurane, and sevoflurane

 Intravenous anaesthetics:

  • Safe- Propofol, Ultrashort acting barbiturates like thiopental, methohexital
  • Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

 Opioids:

  • Safe- Remifentanil> Fentanyl > Alfentanil > Sufentanil
  • Unsafe:
    • Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)
    • Meperidine (metabolite normeperidine is excreted through the kidney)
    • Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

 Muscle relaxants:

  • Safe- Atracurium, Cisatracurium
  • Unsafe- Rocuronium, Mivacurium

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with epistaxis, easy bruising and menorrhagia. There is no history of drug intake. Physical examination shows scattered petechiae and a normal-sized spleen. Her lab investigations are given below. Antibodies against which of the following can lead to this condition?

Platelet count - 37,000/μL

Bleeding time - 16 minutes

PT - 13 seconds

aPTT - 30 seconds

Peripheral blood smear - megathrombocytes
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Autoantibodies seen in ITP are most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion due to the following findings:

  • Bleeding tendency - petechiae
  • Low platelet count, elevated bleeding time
  • Presence of megathrombocytes in the peripheral smear - a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis
  • Female preponderance
  • Absence of splenomegaly

 Note: Prothrombin time (PT) is normal in ITP.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found to be positive for SARS-CoV-2. On contact tracing, 30 people have been identified as close contacts but none of them shows any symptoms or signs. What is the time duration for which they must be quarantined?
questions.solution:
Quarantine is the limitation in freedom of movement of healthy contacts of cases, who have been exposed for a period that lasts as long as the maximal incubation period of the disease.

It is a primary level of prevention and falls under specific protection measures. The various types of quarantine are:

  • Absolute - Complete limitation of movement
  • Modified - Selective partial limitation of movement
  • Segregation - Observation of a group of persons in a population after separation

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with a history of repeated pain over the medial canthus and chronic use of nasal decongestants presents to the OPD with high-grade fever and chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On further history, it is noted that the proptosis began in the right eye, and a few days later, the left eye was also affected. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Pain over the medial canthus and use of nasal decongestants indicate that the patient was suffering from sinusitis, which can spread to cause orbital cellulitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis, or panopthalmitis.

The differentiating feature here is the presentation pattern and bilaterality of the proptosis.

In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through intercavernous communication. Also, cavernous sinus thrombosis presents with high-grade fever with chills, rigor, and headache.

On the other hand, orbital cellulitis and panophthalmitis are unilateral conditions.

Differential diagnosis of acute inflammatory proptosis:

Clinical features Cavernous sinus thrombosis Orbital cellulitis Panophthalmitis
Laterality Initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral Unilateral Unilateral
Vision Not affected in early stage affected Complete loss of vision 
Cornea and anterior chamber Clear Clear Hazy
Edema in the mastoid region Present (Pathognomonic of cavernous sinus thrombosis) Absent Absent
General symptoms with fever and prostration Marked Mild Mild

questions.text: A man inspires 1000ml from a spirometer. The intrapleural pressure was -4cm H2O before inspiration and -12cm H20 at the end of inspiration. What is the compliance of lungs?(ml/cm H20)?
questions.solution:
Compliance is change in volume per unit change in pressure.

  • C= ΔV/ΔP

In this case,

ΔV= 1000 mL

ΔP= -12-(-4) = -8 cm of H2O

The minus sign indicates that the pressure has fallen by 8cms of H20 at the end of inspiration

Therefore the compliance is,

C= 1000/8= 125 mL/cm of H2O

questions.text: In the Lac operon model, how does the presence of lactose activate transcription?

choices.text: Lactose binds to the operator region and blocks the attachment of RNA polymerase to the promoter
Lactose binds directly to the promoter region and activates transcription
Lactose binds to repressor protein and inactivates it

questions.solution:
In the Lac operon model, lactose binds to the repressor protein and inactivates it, thus activating transcription. 

When lactose is present in abundance, a small amount of lactose is converted to allolactose. This compound binds to the repressor protein of the lac operon and creates a conformational change. As a result, the repressor cannot bind to the operator and transcription of the structural genes occurs. This is an example of negative regulation.

This can only occur when glucose is absent. In the absence of glucose, adenylyl cyclase is active. This generates sufficient quantities of cAMP which bind to catabolite activator protein (CAP).The cAMP–CAP trans-acting complex binds to the CAP-binding site, another regulatory region present upstream of the structural genes of the operon. This causes RNA polymerase to more efficiently initiate transcription at the promoter site. This is an example of positive regulation. 

Related Pearl: Operon system

Control of operon/ Regulation of gene expression  Type of operon Metabolite Final outcome Examples

Negative control

(an active repressor inhibits transcription)

 

Inducible operons

(repressor bound to operon)

 binds to repressor and inhibits its binding to the operon by causing a conformational change Transcription lactose operon

Repressible operons

(repressor unable to bind to operon)

 binds to repressor and induces its binding to the operon by causing a conformational change No Transcription Tryptophan operon

Positive control

(an active activator/ regulator promotes transcription)

 

Inducible operons

(activator unable to bind to operon)

 binds to activator and induces its binding to operon by causing a conformational change Transcription cAMP-CAT operon

Repressible operons 

(activator bound to operon)

 binds to activator and inhibits its binding to operon by causing a conformational change  No Transcription

questions.text: A P1A1 woman with a history of obstructed labor is being evaluated for a contracted pelvis. CT pelvis shows both sacral alae are absent. What is the type of pelvis seen here?
questions.solution:
The type of pelvis seen here is Robert's pelvis. In it, the pelvis is transversely contracted and the ala on both sides are absent and the sacrum is fused with the innominate bones.

Option A: In Naegele's pelvis, there is arrested development of one ala of the sacrum.

Option C: Kyphotic pelvis occurs secondary to the kyphotic changes of the vertebral column either following tuberculosis or rickets.

Option D: In rachitic pelvis, due to softening of bones, flattening of the pelvis occurs.

questions.text: A newspaper editor discloses the identity of a victim of rape without prior permission. He would be tried under which of the following sections?
questions.solution:
Section 72 of BNS (IPC Section 228A) deals with punishment for disclosure of the identity of the victim of rape.

Other options:

Option A: Section 71 BNS (IPC 376E) deals with repeat offenders.

Option C: Section 73 BNS (IPC 228A (3)) deals with printing or publishing any matter relating to court proceedings without permission.

Option D: Section 74 BNS (IPC 354) deals with the assault or use of criminal force on a woman with intent to outrage her modesty.

Related Pearl: Sexual Offences

questions.text: An infant was admitted with failure to thrive. His reports show hypoglycemia, high glutamine, and uracil levels in urine. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated and the child became comatose.  Parenteral dextrose was given after which the child recovered in 24 hours. What is the likely enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
This infant with failure to thrive, hypoglycemia, elevated levels of glutamine and uracil levels most likely has hyperammonemia type 2. This condition occurs due to the deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase.

There is an accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which then enters into pyrimidine synthesis producing orotic acid and uracil and leading to orotic aciduria and high uracil in blood and urine. Since the ammonia from glutamine is not converted into urea, its level increases. Glutamate is not regenerated. Since glutamate is not available for transamination, amino acids cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Hence, the glucose level drops in the blood.

Treatment:

  • Reducing intake of ammonia - Dietary protein, a metabolic source of ammonium, is restricted and caloric intake is provided by glucose and fat.
  • Increasing excretion of ammonia - Addition of phenylbutyrate, which scavenges nitrogen by combining with amino acids to form a more water-soluble product. This can be easily excreted by the kidneys.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Which among the following is true about denaturation of proteins?

choices.text: Biological property of the protein is retained.
It mostly renders the protein insoluble.

questions.solution:
Denaturation mostly renders the protein insoluble.

Protein denaturation results in the unfolding and disorganization of the secondary and tertiary structures of protein. Thus, the biological property of the protein is lost. However, there is no hydrolysis of peptide bonds, which form the primary structure.  

Denatured proteins are often insoluble and precipitate from the solution. This process may be reversible under ideal conditions, such that the protein refolds into its original structure when the denaturing agent is removed.

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: A patient with calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals in the urine is diagnosed with ethylene glycol poisoning. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Fomepizole is the drug of choice for the treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning.

Treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning:

  • Fomepizole (preferred) or ethanol (if fomepizole is unavailable) - inhibits the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Sodium bicarbonate - correct systemic acidosis
  • Hemodialysis - for elevated toxic alcohol levels, severe acid-base derangements, or evidence of end-organ toxicity
  • Co-factors (folic acid, thiamine, and pyridoxine) - optimizes non-toxic metabolic pathways for the elimination of parent alcohol or its metabolites

questions.text: What is basiliximab?
questions.solution:
Basiliximab exhibits a high affinity towards IL-2 receptor and inhibits it. It is an anti- CD-25 monoclonal antibody.
It has a short plasma half-life of 1 week. It is used to prevent transplant rejection reactions. Its adverse effects are anaphylactic reactions & opportunistic infections.

questions.text: The novel free-radical scavenger  approved for use in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is
questions.solution:
Edaravone is a free-radical scavenger newly approved for use in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

Edaravone is a free radical scavenger that is thought to reduce oxidative stress, which has been implicated in the pathogenesis of ALS. Edaravone was found to slow functional deterioration in some patients with ALS. 

It is recommended as an adjunct to riluzole for all patients with ALS.

questions.text: Which of the following patients will have metabolic alkalosis?

choices.text: A patient with chronic renal failure who is recommended dialysis
A patient who was diagnosed with hyperaldosteronism
A patient who took a whole bottle of aspirin to get rid of the headache

questions.solution:
Metabolic alkalosis is seen in patients with hyperaldosteronism.

In hyperaldosteronism: increased aldosterone levels cause increased H+ secretion by the distal tubule and increased reabsorption of HCO3- → Metabolic alkalosis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with myocardial infarction underwent PCI and stenting with paclitaxel coated drug-eluting stent. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Paclitaxel binds specifically to beta-tubulin and promotes the polymerization and inhibits the disassembly of this cytoskeletal protein, resulting in the arrest of the cell cycle in M-phase.

The first generation drug eluting stents used in PCI were coated with paclitaxel or sirolimus as an anti-proliferative agent. Second-generation drug-eluting stents use newer agents such as everolimus, biolimus, and zotarolimus.

Related Pearl: Microtubule stabilising vs polymerisation inhibiting agents

Mnemonic

Taxes stabilise economy

  • Taxanes stabilise microtubules

Vinca alklaoids

  • Polymerisation inhibiting agents

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Hypertension with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis is seen in Liddle's syndrome.

Liddle's syndrome (pseudo aldosteronism) is an autosomal dominant condition that is caused due to the increased activation of ENaC channels. This causes increased reabsorption of Na+ exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension, and there is also a loss of H+ ion with K+, leading to metabolic alkalosis. It is associated with low renin and low aldosterone levels.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A 15 years old girl has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years ago. Now she presents with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago. She should now be given?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.solution:
The girl should be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone

She presented with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago and she has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years back, which comes under Category B of Tetanus Immunization.

According to the recommendations of the CDC:

Vaccination History Clean Minor Wounds All other wounds
Unknown or fewer than 3 doses Tdap/Td Tdap/TD + TIG
3 or more doses Tdap/ Td Only if > 10 years Tdap/TD Only if > 5 years

Tdap - Tetanus, Diptheria, and Pertussis

Td - Tetanus and Diptheria

Tdap for children and Td for adults but Tdap is preferred to Td for adults who have never received Tdap.

 

Categories of Tetanus immunization:

  • Category A - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within past 5 years
  • Category B - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past > 5 years < 10 years.
  • Category C - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past >10 years
  • Category D - Not taken a complete course of TT/booster or immunity status not known.

 

Note:

WHO recommends a 3-dose primary vaccination series with tetanus-diphtheria containing vaccine followed by 3 booster doses. Ideally, there should be at least 4 years between booster doses.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of lateral wall MI and possible posterior wall MI.

ST-elevation is present in the high lateral leads (I and aVL) and in V5 and V6.

Reciprocal ST depression is seen in the inferior leads (III and aVF) with associated ST depression in V1, V2, and V3 (which could represent posterior wall MI).

This pattern is consistent with an acute infarction localized to the superior portion of the lateral wall of the left ventricle (high lateral STEMI).

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: Which of the following is not a selective medium for Corynebacterium diptheriae?
questions.solution:
Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is not a selective medium as other organisms can also grow on this medium.

The selective media for Corynebacterium diphtheria are potassium tellurite agar, Tinsdale medium and McLeod's medium (tellurite blood agar). Tellurite inhibits the growth of other bacteria. C. diphtheria reduces the tellurite to metallic tellurium, giving its colonies a grey black colour. On 

On Loeffler's serum slope, colonies appear as small white opaque discs that may acquire a yellow ting. The advantages for growing C. diphtheriae on Loeffler's serum slope are rapid growth in 6-8 hrs and that its the best medium for metachromatic granules production. The disadvantage of using this medium is that on incubation beyond 6-8 hrs, it supports the growth of commensals as well.

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of diminution of vision. She has bipolar disorder and has been on antipsychotic therapy for the past 8 months. Ophthalmic examination revealed the finding seen in the below image . What drug was she most likely on?
questions.solution:
The image shows a whitish opacity in the pupillary region and this in combination with the presenting features are suggestive of cataract. This is an adverse effect seen with the use of quetiapine which is an atypical antipsychotic. 

Related Pearl: Non extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. On examination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.

Vernal conjunctivitis is also called spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis. It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years. It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Classical features of the conjunctiva in VKC:

Palpebral VKC - Cobblestone papillae are present in the upper tarsal conjunctiva associated with ropy discharge. Maxwell–Lyon sign is present which is a pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal VKC - Horner – Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

The image given below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

Treatment of this condition is with topical steroids and mast cell stabilizers such as cromolyn sodium. Topical cyclosporine can be used in patients who do not respond to first line treatment modalities.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5 yrs back. His present ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a man with history of coronary artery disease developing syncope. The ECG shows wide QRS complex (> 0.12 s) tachycardia with a single QRS morphology suggestive of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). The most appropriate treatment of VT in a hemodynamically unstable (systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg) patient is DC cardioversion.

VT can be casued by structural heart disease, scar-related reentry, cardiomyopathies, or abnormalities in the conduction pathways. VT is said to be sustained if it lasts for at least 30 seconds or requires intervention for termination.

Rapid VT can lead to hypotension and syncope, especially in patients with ventricular dysfunction. Patients with normal cardiac function may tolerate sustained VT, presenting with palpitations. Monomorphic VT associated with structural heart disease can progress to ventricular fibrillation (VF) and sudden cardiac arrest.

QRS synchronous electrical cardioversion is performed for unstable patients. Intravenous amiodarone is the preferred drug for stable VT associated with heart disease.

After restoring sinus rhythm, further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying heart disease. Treatment options include antiarrhythmic medications, catheter ablation, or implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) for recurrent or high-risk VT. ICDs are commonly used for secondary prevention of sudden death in patients with sustained VT and structural heart disease.

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoma cervix is undergoing the treatment modality in the image given below. Which of the following elements is most commonly used in this?
questions.solution:
The given image shows brachytherapy being used to treat carcinoma cervix. Cesium is the most common radioactive agent used for the same.

In the majority of these treatments, radiation applicators are placed within a cavity of the body such as the bronchus (airway) in the lung, esophagus, vagina, cervix of the uterus.

Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor. It can be either a low-dose or high-dose rate system. The primary advantage of internal radiation is the ability to deliver a higher radiation dose while the normal tissues receive less radiation since the radiation sources are placed within the tumor. Both Iridium and cesium have been used as radioactive sources to give internal radiation.

Dosage is calculated with respect to the amount of radiation received at two arbitrary points A and B (image below).

Location 2cm above and 2cm lateral to the external os 2cm above and 5cm lateral to the external os
Structure present crossing of the ureter and uterine artery Obturator lymph node
Dose of radiation 7000-8000 cGy 6000 cGy

One vaginal plaque

questions.text: During the post-mortem heart examination of a patient, the resident palpates a muscular ridge, which is the site of origin of pectinate muscles. In which of the following chambers is the resident palpating this structure?
questions.solution:
The structure being palpated by the resident is crista terminalis. It is present in the right atrium.

It is a muscular ridge that runs anteriorly along the atrial wall from the opening of the superior vena cava to the opening of the inferior vena cava. It corresponds externally to sulcus terminalis. It is the site of origin of pectinate muscles. 

It divides the right atrium into a smooth posterior part and a rough anterior part. Both the vena cavae empty into the posterior smooth part.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman was diagnosed with a malignant tumor in the superolateral quadrant of the breast. A blue dye was injected to map the sentinel lymph node for evaluation of metastasis. Which of the following lymph nodes would most likely be removed for biopsy?
questions.solution:
Lymphatics from the upper outer quadrant of the breast drain first into the anterior axillary lymph nodes (sentinel nodes).

A sentinel node is the first lymph node that receives lymphatic drainage from the tumor. It is identified so that it can be removed during the surgery. The lymph node is sent for histopathological analysis to detect metastasis.

The axillary nodes receive more than 75% of the lymph from the breast.

Surgical classification of nodes:

Nodes are described in relation to pectoralis minor:

  • Level 1 (Low nodes) - below pectoralis minor
  • Level 2 (Middle nodes) - behind the muscle
  • Level 3 (Apical/upper nodes) - between the upper border of the pectoralis minor and the lower border of the clavicle

There may be nodes between pectoralis minor and major; this interpectoral group of nodes is also known as Rotter’s nodes.

questions.text: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates severe sensorineural hearing loss as a consequence of untreated suppurative labyrinthitis and Rinne's test is a false negative in this case.

Initially, the patient had a positive fistula test, which implies that the labyrinth is still functioning. Rinne's test is positive which could be due to normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss.

Currently, the patient has a negative fistula test which implies that the labyrinth is dead. This is an example of severe sensorineural hearing loss and here, Rinne test is a false negative.

If intermittent pressure applied to the external ear produces vertigo and nystagmus, it is a positive fistula test. The pressure changes in the external ear are transmitted to the labyrinth. This is suggestive of abnormal communication between the middle ear and the inner ear. 

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: Which of the following is an ion channel receptor?
questions.solution:
Nicotinic cholinergic receptors (both Nm and Nn) are of ligand-gated ion channel type.

The binding of ligand alters the permeability of ion channels directly and brings about biological action.

Muscarinic cholinergic, beta-adrenergic, and opioid receptors are G protein-coupled receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following combination of skeletal trauma - nerve injury is wrongly matched?
questions.solution:
Wrist injury is associated with damage to the median nerve, not the anterior interosseous nerve.

Nerve injuries can be associated with closed fractures or open fractures:

  • Closed fractures are less commonly related to nerve injury and spontaneous recovery within 4 months is observed in 90% cases. The nerve is explored if recovery is delayed beyond the expected time, or when nerve conduction studies do not demonstrate any evidence of recovery.
  • Open fractures are more likely to cause the nerve to be completely severed. The nerve is explored and repaired at the time of debridement or during wound closure.

questions.text: An orthopedic resident has removed a K-wire from the fractured olecranon of a 13-year-old boy. Where should he discard this?
questions.solution:
Metallic body implants are disposed of in cardboard boxes with blue-colored markings.

The contents of the blue box are sent to Common Biomedical Waste Treatment and Disposal Facility (CBWTF). In the facility, these items are sterilized by autoclaving or microwaving and then sent for recycling.

 

In case of delay in sending the waste to the treatment facility, 2% sodium hypochlorite solution can be used for pre-treatment storage until the contents of the blue bag can be picked up by the CBWTF operator.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic man with history of recent international travel presents with a complaints of fever, cough and difficulty in breathing for the past 3 days. Laboratory reports are positive for COVID-19. What is the symmetry of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which is a coronavirus. It shows an enveloped helical symmetry.

Coronaviruses are enveloped RNA viruses. They contain a genome of unsegmented, linear, single-stranded and positive-sense RNA and have a helical nucleocapsid.

questions.text: An orthopedic resident is applying a cast for a 6-year-old child with the following fracture. What should be the position of the child's forearm during the procedure?
questions.solution:
The x-ray shows a fracture at the junction of the middle and distal 1/3 of both radius and ulna. The elbow should be flexed at 90° and the forearm should be in mid-pronation position while applying the cast. 

Forearm fractures in children are managed conservatively by applying a POP cast. In adults, surgery is preferred (open reduction and internal fixation).

Fracture site on the forearm Position of forearm (with elbow flexed)

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. What is the reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm?

choices.text: B  fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.solution:
The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

Sleeping for a long period with the arms under the head puts pressure on a nerve. It leads to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact. A-fibers (includes the motor fibers) are affected.

The susceptibility of the nerve fibers to pressure is A>B>C.

This is responsible for Saturday night or Sunday morning paralysis.

Controversial: There is a difference in the opinion quoted by various standard textbooks and authors.

According to Katzung pharmacology 14th edition page no. 465,  B=C > A delta > A gamma > A beta > A alpha

Hence, the correct answer would solely depend on the reference book the examiner referred to while making the question.
