questions.text: A patient presented to the PHC with a deformity as shown in the image below. He fractured his left elbow a few months back which he left untreated. Which of the following features is most likely to be associated with this deformity?

choices.text: Anesthesia over tip of the little finger

questions.solution:
The given image shows cubitus valgus deformity on the left side. It can lead to late-onset ulnar palsy (tardy ulnar nerve palsy) leading to anaesthesia at the tip of the little finger. 

Cubitus valgus deformity is a late complication of non-union of fracture of lateral condyle of the humerus. 

Related Pearl: Dermatome of upper limb

questions.text: A woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility, and underwent an endometrial biopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the proliferative phase of the endometrium. 

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely; proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below:

Proliferative phase

  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiralled.
  • The endometrium is thick, the stoma is compact and short straight glands are present.

The image below shows proliferative endometrium

Secretory phase 

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • Subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity)
  • Corkscrew-shaped glands

The image below shows secretory endometrium

Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: While performing a modified radical neck dissection, the surgeon preserves the structure marked below. Which of the following is supplied by this structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked above is the spinal accessory nerve. The spinal accessory nerve enters the posterior triangle passing deep to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and runs in an oblique direction within the triangle to supply the trapezius.

Option A: Phrenic nerve is seen related to the anterior surface of scalenus anterior, and supplies the diaphragm. 

Option C: The greater auricular nerve supplies the skin over the angle of the jaw, skin over the mandible, and lower 1/3rd of the auricle, greater auricular nerve (C2,3). 

Option D: The suprascapular nerve (C5, C6) arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. It supplies the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles

Clinical note:

There are three types of modified radical neck dissection (MRND). Structures preserved are:

  • MRND 1 - Only spinal accessory nerve 
  • MRND 2 - Accessory nerve and internal jugular vein
  • MRND 3 i.e., functional neck dissection - Accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid, and internal jugular veins.

questions.text: While doing the Raygat's test, an unrespired lung may float due to:
questions.solution:
In Raygat's test, an unrespired lung (stillbirth) may float due to gases of decomposition, as seen in putrefaction.

It is also known as the floatation test/ Breslau’s first life test/ hydrostatic test. It is done to determine whether the newborn has respired or not:

  • If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration has taken place, indicating a live birth
  • If the pieces sink, respiration has not taken place, signifies stillborn

A respired lung (live birth) may sink in water in the following conditions:

  • Lung edema
  • Lung collapse
  • Pneumonia (consolidation)
  • Congenital syphilis

Other tests to determine if respiration has taken place or not are: 

  • Fodere’s test: Weight of lungs before respiration - 30-40g, after respiration - 60-66g
  • Ploucquet’s test: Weight of lungs before respiration - 1/70 of body weight, after respiration - 1/35 of body weight 
  • Wredin’s test: Assesses the changes in the middle ear. The gelatinous substance in the middle ear is replaced by air if respiration has taken place.

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: A registered medical practitioner is requested by a survivor of sexual violence to examine her. Within what time must the practitioner take a vaginal swab to look for the presence of spermatozoa?
questions.solution:
A vaginal swab of a rape victim demonstrates spermatozoa if the vaginal swab is taken within 72 hours after an assault.

However, a vaginal swab can be taken within 96 hours to demonstrate semen. 

Evidence on the outside of the body and on materials such as clothing can be collected even after 96 hours.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for a young lady with fibroids posted for open myomectomy. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Doyen myoma screw.

It is used to perform an open myomectomy. The handle present in this can be used to distinguish it from a laparoscopic myoma screw which also has a similar tip.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a suspected prolactinoma is planned for a brain MRI. What size would the tumor have to be to call it a microadenoma?
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenomas < 10 mm are called microadenomas.

Asymptomatic pituitary tumors can be discovered incidentally on imaging. They must also be suspected in patients with features of hormone hypersecretion or mass effect. In such cases, MRI with contrast is the best investigation to detect the tumor, as shown below. 

Levels of pituitary hormones must also be measured to rule out both hypersecretion and hyposecretion.

questions.text: In compound myopic astigmatism, with parallel rays of light entering the eye in relaxed accommodation, the image(s) formed is/are __________.

choices.text: One focal point in front of the retina
Two focal lines in front of the retina
Two focal lines behind the retina
Two focal lines, one behind and the other in front of retina

questions.solution:
In compound myopic astigmatism, parallel rays of light entering the eye in relaxed accommodation form two focal lines in front of the retina.

Option A: One focal point in front of retina describes myopia.

Option C: Two focal lines behind the retina describes compound hypermetropic astigmatism.

Option D: Two focal lines, one behind and one in front of the retina describes mixed astigmatism.

questions.text: You are examining a week-old male infant who was severely cyanotic at birth in the post-operative ward. He has undergone balloon atrial septostomy following prostaglandin E1 administration. Post-surgery there was a marked improvement in cyanosis. The most likely diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
Cyanosis at birth, prostagladin E1 administration, and septostomy to improve oxygenation are typical features of transposition of great vessels (TGA).

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:

  • At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)
  • At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus

Chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic “egg-on-string appearance”), and normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. The narrow pedicle of the heart is because of the malposition of the great vessels.

Treatment: Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulations.

questions.text: Identify the layers marked as A, B, and C, respectively, in the image of the definitive placenta.

choices.text: Rohr's layer, Langhan's layer, Nitabuch's layer
Langhan's layer, Rohr's layer, Nitabuch's layer
Langhan's layer, Nitabuch's layer, Rohr's layer
Nitabuch's layer, Langhan's layer, Rohr's layer

questions.solution:
The structures marked in the above image are (A) Langhan's layer, (B) Rohr's layer, and (C) Nitabuch's layer.

The definitive placenta consists of the chorionic plate on the fetal aspect and a basal plate on the maternal aspect with the intervillous space between them.

The structures of the definitive placenta are shown in the image below:

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is present in skeletal muscles, but absent in a smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle. But troponin is absent and calmodulin is present in smooth muscle.

questions.text: Identify the condition
questions.solution:
The image shows Duane’s retraction syndrome type 1.

Paradoxical innervation of LR where it gets innervated by some fibres of III nerve instead of VI nerve. On impulse for abduction via VI nerve there is no abduction limitation. On impulse for adduction via III nerve both LR and MR contract thus causing retraction of globe (as the antagonist LR instead of relaxation, starts to contract)

Duane’s retraction syndrome (DRS) is a cause of restrictive squint

There is a failure of innervation of the lateral rectus by a hypoplastic sixth nerve nucleus, with anomalous innervation of the lateral rectus by fibers from the third nerve. Retraction of the globe on attempted adduction. Widening of palpebral fissure on attempted abduction

Classification by Huber:

  • Limitation of abduction- type 1
  • Limitation of adduction- type 2
  • Limitation of both- type 3

Note: DRS is an exception to Sherrington's law of reciprocal innervation.

questions.text: Double diffusion in two dimensions is called as ___________.
questions.solution:
Double diffusion in two dimensions is called the Ouchterlony procedure. Ex: Elek’s test for testing toxigenicity in diphtheria bacilli. 

The images below show the different types of immunodiffusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a  component of MELD  score?
questions.solution:
In MELD (model for end-stage liver disease) score, urea is not one of the components.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: What is the best imaging study for earliest diagnosis of cerebral infarct?
questions.solution:
The best imaging modality for the early diagnosis of cerebral infarction is diffusion-weighted MRI (DWI), which can detect infarcts as early as 30 minutes of onset and identify cytotoxic oedema within a few hours of ischemic stroke.

However, the initial investigation in suspected stroke cases is non-contrast CT due to its rapid acquisition time, widespread availability, and cost-effectiveness. It helps quickly rule out hemorrhagic stroke and facilitates the timely administration of intravenous tPA in eligible patients.

Acute MCA territory infarct on CT is shown below:

The image below is of a DWI MRI of a patient clearly showing the extent of the infarct.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is treated using gamma knife?
questions.solution:
The arterio-venous malformation is treated using a gamma knife. 

Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse or cannot tolerate surgery. Here, beams are modified and focused only to concentrate on the tumor and have little effect on surrounding tissue. It can be done by using: 

  • X-knife using a linear accelerator (LINAC)
  • Gamma-knife using Cobalt 60 
  • CyberKnife - image-guided linear accelerator using real-time image guidance to deliver radiation from multiple angles.

The patient wears a specialized helmet that is surgically fixed to the skull. Gamma knife aims gamma radiation through a target point in the patient’s brain. An ablative dose of radiation is thereby sent through the tumour in one treatment session while surrounding brain tissues are relatively spared. 

SRS has been used in the treatment of almost every intracranial lesion but is commonly used in the treatment of acoustic schwannoma, pituitary adenoma, meningioma, and trigeminal neuralgia but not glioblastoma. 

The image below is an illustration of the principle of gamma-knife therapy:

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady develops severe anterograde amnesia. On further evaluation, a suprasellar craniopharyngioma invading adjacent structures is seen on T1-weighted MRI. Compression of which of the following structures can explain her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Compression or a lesion affecting the mammillary body will cause anterograde amnesia.

The Hippocampus, mammillary body and mammillothalamic tract are the primary structures involved in the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory. Any lesion involving this pathway will affect the ability to convert short-term memory to long-term memory, leading to anterograde amnesia.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient came with complaints of easy fatiguability and palpitations. On examination, she had pallor. Methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine was estimated as a part of evaluation. This can be utilized to assess the nutritional status of which vitamin?
questions.solution:
The above scenario suggests anemia and methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine can be utilized to assess the nutritional status of vitamin B12.

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme. The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine.

There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

Note: Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level

questions.text: Psuedo isomorphic phenomenon can be seen in a patient with ________________
questions.solution:
Pseudo-isomorphic/pseudo-Koebner phenomenon can be seen in patients with warts as the new lesions occur due to the seeding of infection.

Koebner phenomenon or true Koebnerisation is typically seen in psoriasis, vitiligo, and lichen planus.

Koebner/isomorphic phenomenon refers to the appearance of new skin lesions on healthy skin at the site of cutaneous injury, in the presence of a pre-existing dermatosis. They are typically linear, as they follow the route of the injury.

Koebner phenomenon is diagnosed clinically using the following characteristics:

  • Linear lesions developing at the site of cutaneous injury on a previously healthy skin
  • Lesions have the same clinical and histological features as the underlying dermatosis
  • Lesions are not due to seeding of an infectious agent, allergic reaction or skin breakdown

The exact cause of such a response is unclear. Theories involving T-cell mediated response, involvement of dermis, and microvasculature are considered. Various triggers for Koebner phenomenon have been identified:

  • Trauma: Insect and animal bites, burns including thermal and electric, excoriation, friction, shaving, lacerations, cryotherapy, pressure sores, and orthotics
  • Chemical irritation: Tattoo associated skin reaction, BCG vaccination, tuberculin skin test, hair dye allergy
  • Diseases: Urticaria, inflammatory dermatoses
  • Others: Phototherapy, sunburn, withdrawal of methotrexate therapy

Other features of Koebner phenomenon include:

  • Graded response to trauma: Intensity of response to trauma is unique to each patient and the underlying disease.
    • No Koebner response to injury
    • Abortive Koebner response: Lesions appear, but spontaneously vanish after a few weeks
    • Minimal Koebner response: Lesions develop at the site of trauma
    • Maximal Koebner response: Wide spread lesions develop across the entire site of trauma
  • All or nothing response: Patients who develop Koebner phenomenon in response to one type of injury, may develop a similar response due to other types of injuries as well. In case, a patient does not exhibit Koebner phenomenon to one type of injury, it is unlikely that it is exhibited after any other type of injury.
  • Time taken to develop the skin lesions is unique to the patient and the specific dermatosis. It may vary from 3 days to 2 years, normally taking around 10-20 days.

Koebner phenomenon can be classified into:

  • True Koebnerisation: New skin lesions seen with the clinical features mentioned above, as seen in vitiligo, psoriasis and lichen planus.  
  • Pseudo-Koebnerisation: Appearance of similar skin lesions at the site of injury in infective lesions like plane warts and molluscum contagiosum, due to the spread of the infective agent (virus) to the new site by seeding, especially due to scratching.

The image below shows Koebner phenomenon seen in a psoriatic patient at the site of trauma.

Koebner phenomenon is also seen in other diseases like:

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Lichen nidatus
  • Necrobiosis lipodica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Hailey-Hailey disease
  • Darier disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Other phenomena associated with cutaneous trauma are:

  • Reverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of skin lesions after trauma to the area, which is seen in psoriasis after dermabrasion or surgery.
  • Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon: Spontaneous repigmentation is seen in distant patches after autologous skin graft surgery in vitiligo.
  • Wolf's isotopic response/isotopic phenomenon: Emergence of new dermatosis at the site of a previous unrelated dermatosis as seen in granuloma annulare developing at the site of herpes zoster and psoriasis developing at the site of contact dermatitis.
  • Pathergy: Occurance of non-specific papules and pustules secondary to heavy neutrophilic infiltrates after an injection or venipuncture, as seen in pyoderma gangrenosum and Behçet disease.
  • Renbök/inverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of an existing skin condition after the onset of a new dermatosis at the same site, as seen in retention of hair follicles on the psoriatic plaques on the scalp while hair loss was present in unaffected areas of alopecia areata.

questions.text: A juvenile delinquent was sentenced by the court to be placed in a center under the care of a doctor and psychiatrist. Which of the following fulfills this requirement?
questions.solution:
A remand home is an establishment where children are placed under the care of a doctor, psychiatrist and other trained personnel.

An orphanage or shelter home is an institution where children who have no home or parents or for some reason can’t be cared for are placed.

Foster homes are arrangements where a family or a couple takes care of a child on a temporary basis.

Borstal is a place that falls between a certified institution and a prison. It is where boys > 16 years who have misbehaved or are too difficult to handle are sent.

questions.text: An infant born to a diabetic mother develops difficulty in breathing within 30 minutes of birth. Within a few hours, cyanosis becomes evident. Fine rales are heard over both lung fields. A chest x-ray film shows ground-glass picture. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: It is associated with respiratory failure and poor prognosis despite treatment
There is deficiency of surfactant produced by type II alveolar cells
Increased corticosteroid release lower the risk of developing RDS
On microscopy, hyaline membranes with fibrin and necrotic cell debris are seen

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is characteristic of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) or hyaline membrane disease. With treatment, it rarely leads to respiratory failure and has a good prognosis. 

The fundamental defect is a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, produced by type II pneumocytes. 

Microscopically, the hyaline membranes are largely made up of fibrin admixed with necrotic cell debris. Grossly, the lungs are of normal size, solid, airless, reddish-purple, and they usually sink in water.

Corticosteroids help in surfactant production and are given prophylactically to at-risk pregnant women.

Related Pearl: Pulmonary surfactant

It lowers the surface tension of the water layer at the alveolar surface, which increases lung compliance, thereby making it easier for the lungs to expand. It is secreted by type II alveolar cells. It is a mixture of phospholipids and protein.

4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: Surfactant proteins are (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

  • SP-A - Regulation of the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveolar epithelial cells that secrete it.
  • SP-B & SP-C - Key protein members of the monomolecular film of surfactant.
  • SP-D - Organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

A deep breath increases its secretion by stretching the type II cells. Its concentration decreases when breaths are small.

In the fetus, surfactant synthesis is variable. The surfactant may be present as early as gestational week 24 and is almost always present by gestational week 35.

questions.text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious discharge from the nose is suggestive of Hurler's disease.

It is the severe form of mucopolysaccharidoses type 1 (MPS 1), an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in α-L iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. The child usually presents between 6 and 24 months with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features (shown below), corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.

Most patients have recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and persistent copious nasal discharge. Radiograph shows skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex - thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged and trabeculated diaphyses of the long bones with irregular metaphysis and epiphysis.

Macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella, premature closure of lambdoid sagittal sutures, and shallow orbits are seen with disease progression. Obstructive airway disease, cardiac complications, and respiratory infections are the common causes of death. 

The image below shows the radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpal and phalanges. 

Other options:

Option B: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, and renal anomalies. It is associated with an increased risk of Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, neuroblastoma, and adrenal cortical carcinoma.

Option C: Proteus syndrome is a disturbance of cellular growth involving ectodermal and mesodermal tissues, caused by mutation in the AKT1 gene. They present with hemimegalencephaly, asymmetric overgrowth of the extremities, verrucous cutaneous lesions, thickening of the bone, and excessive growth of muscles.

Option D: A child with untreated congenital hypothyroidism may have stunted growth, short extremities, narrow palpebral fissures, swollen eyelids, depressed nasal bridge, thick broad protruded tongue, and short and thick neck, dry and scaly skin. 

Related Pearl: MPS and Their Respective Enzyme Deficiencies

questions.text: A 55 year old woman, presents to the pre-anaesthetic clinic. She has been advised to undergo an elective laparoscopic hysterectomy. On further evaluation, her BMI is calculated to be 31 and she has a Mallampatti class III airway. The anaesthetist then decides that a Proseal laryngeal mask airway would be ideal for this patient. Identify the false statement about this device?

choices.text: Single use second generation airway device
Gastric drainage tube to remove secretions
Can be used in surgery requiring prone position

questions.solution:
Proseal laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a re-usable second-generation supraglottic airway device, not a single-use device. 

It also has an integrated bite block, a drainage tube to remove gastric secretions, and an improved cuff design. This reduces the risk of aspiration. 

Hence it may be suitable in non-supine positions (e.g., lateral, prone), laparoscopic surgery (e.g., cholecystectomy, gynaecological surgery), and in patients who are obese.

 

All these features are also present in LMA Supreme, except that it is a single-use second generation supraglottic device.

questions.text: A patient with AIDS was treated with zidovudine, lamivudine, indinavir, ketoconazole and cotrimoxazole. He developed nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia and insulin resistance. Which of the drugs could have been the cause?
questions.solution:
Indinavir, a protease inhibitor causes the above given adverse effects.

Patients being treated with protease inhibitors (e.g., indinavir) develop a syndrome involving the derangement of lipid metabolism. This causes changes in body fat distribution. Type 2 diabetes mellitus has also been reported. This is called HIV/HAART-associated lipodystrophy.

It is typically seen after 6–12 months of protease inhibitor therapy.

 

Indinavir is also notable for its tendency to precipitate in the urinary tract, causing nephrolithiasis, unless the patient is maintained in a high state of hydration.

questions.text: What type of joint is an incudostapedial joint?
questions.solution:
The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type of joint.

In ball and socket type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head (male surface) fitting into a cup-shaped socket (female surface). These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

Note: The other joint between the incus and malleus (incudomalleolar joint) is a saddle joint. 

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: Which of the following factors maximally increases the risk of tubal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Prior tubal surgery for ectopic pregnancy has the highest risk of tubal pregnancy among the given options.

Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Prior ectopic pregnancy
  • Prior tubal surgery for ectopic, recanalization of tube post-sterilization
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease - most common cause for ectopic pregnancy
  • Infertility
  • Artificial reproductive therapy
  • Endometriosis
  • Smoking
  • Maternal age >40 years
  • Contraceptive methods - intrauterine device, progesterone-only pills

questions.text: Which protein in the glomerular basement membrane is responsible for charge-dependent filtration?
questions.solution:
Charge-dependent filtration in the glomerular basement membrane is carried out by heparan sulfate. It is a negatively charged molecule that repels other negatively charged proteins. This prevents the loss of proteins in urine.

Collagen type IV, fibronectin, and entactin are structural components of the basement membrane.

questions.text: The following are true about the condition given in the image except:

choices.text: More common in people with history of atopy
Sago grain vesicles seen on palms and sides of hand
They are painful but not pruritic
Topical corticosteroids can be used for this condition

questions.solution:
The given image is that of pompholyx, a distinct type of hand eczema. It shows confluent vesicles that are painful and pruritic.

It is also called vesicular eczema of palms and soles. This gives a sago grain or tapioca vesicle appearance.

Predisposing factors:

  • Atopy
  • Naturally dry skin
  • Allergic or irritant dermatitis - chromate, epoxy glues, and rubber
  • Filaggrin gene mutations are predisposing factors

Treatment:

  • First-line - Hand care advice, irritant, and allergen avoidance
  • Second-line - topical corticosteroids
  • Third line:
    • Alitretinoin
    • PUVA
    • Azathioprine
    • Ciclosporin
    • Methotrexate

The image below shows pompholyx.

questions.text: A 69-year-old patient with hypertension has silver wiring, papilledema, and arteriovenous nipping visible on fundoscopy, but no other changes. How would you grade his disease?
questions.solution:
A patient with hypertension having "silver wiring," papilledema, and arteriovenous nipping visible on fundoscopy has Grade IV retinopathy.

Related Pearl: Hypertensive retinopathy

Hypertensive retinopathy describes the fundus changes that occur in a patient with systemic hypertension. It is graded as follows:

  • Grade 1 - Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing
  • Grade 2 - Focal arteriolar narrowing and deflection of veins at AV crossings (Salu's sign).
  • Grade 3 - Grade 2 changes with the following:
    • Copper-wiring of arterioles
    • Cotton wool spots, retinal hemorrhages (dot, blot, flame) or exudates (chronic retinal edema)
    • Bonnet’s sign: Banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings
    • Gunn’s sign: Tapering of veins on either side of the arteriovenous crossings 
      Macular star (Deposition of hard exudates around the fovea) may be present. 
  • Grade 4 - Severe grade 3 changes with optic disc swelling or papilledema (a marker of malignant hypertension) and silver-wiring of arterioles.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with abnormal movements of the limbs. A lesion of the globus pallidus is suspected. Which of the following did she most likely present with?
questions.solution:
This woman with a lesion at the globus pallidus most likely presented with athetosis: Slow, writhing movements of a hand/arm/the face. 

Condition Site of lesion Description 
Chorea Striatum

Flicking movements in the hands, face, and other parts of the body
Athetosis Globus pallidus

Spontaneous, continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, or the face
Hemiballusmus Subthalamic nucleus

Sudden flailing movements of an entire limb
Parkinsonism Substantia nigra

Severe rigidity, akinesia, and tremors

questions.text: A known diabetic with an HbA1c value of 9% should be classified under which ASA-PS classification?
questions.solution:
A patient with poorly controlled diabetes should be classified as ASA-PS Class III.   

ASA-PS Class III: A patient with severe systemic disease and substantial functional limitation. Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus or hypertension or complicated diabetes is included under ASA-PS Class III. 

Note: If the question was about well-controlled diabetes or mild diabetes without complications, the answer would be ASA-PS Class II.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes with a history of musculoskeletal pain. Which of the following suggests that the pain is non-articular?

choices.text: Pain in  both movement and at rest

questions.solution:
Non-articular disorders tend to be painless on passive movement.

Feature  Articular Non-articular
Structures involved Synovium, synovial fluid, articular cartilage, intraarticular ligaments, joint capsule, and juxta-articular bone Extraarticular ligaments, tendons, bursae, muscles, fascia, bone, nerves, and overlying skin
Pain Deep or diffuse Localized
Pain with movement Both on active and passive movement Only on active movement
Swelling  Present Absent
Crepitation Present Absent
Instability Present Absent
Deformity Present Absent
Examples

Osteoarthritis, infectious arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine examination reveals hematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Microscopic analysis of his renal biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following finding?
questions.solution:
The boy in this clinical scenario has characteristic features of Henoch–Schonlein purpura (HSP).

The renal biopsy in this patient will show mesangial proliferation with mesangial deposition of IgA

  • HSP is a common small-vessel vasculitis in childhood.
  • It is characterized by a purpuric rash and commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain.
  • About half the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.
  • The nephritis associated with HSP usually follows the onset of the rash
  • The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with molar pregnancy and underwent suction and evacuation. The resected specimen is shown below. Histopathological examination revealed thin-walled, cystic structures consisting of hydropic villi with extensive trophoblastic proliferation along its entire circumference. Immunohistochemistry was negative for p57. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: The genetic material is completely maternally derived
Embryo dies very early in development and therefore is usually not identified
It is associated with a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing grapelike vesicles are suggestive of a complete mole. It results from the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes, and as a result, the genetic material is completely paternally derived.

The pathogenesis of complete mole is as follows:

  • Androgenesis (most common) - 46XX karyotype stemming from the duplication of the genetic material of 1 sperm
  • Dispermy - 46XX or 46XY karyotype due to fertilization of an empty egg by 2 sperms

Microscopically, thin-walled, cystic, grapelike structures consisting of hydropic villi are seen. Trophoblastic proliferation involving the entire circumference of the villi is seen.

The embryo dies very early in development and, therefore, is usually not identified. Patients have a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma and a 15% risk of the persistent or invasive mole.

The following image shows the pathogenesis of molar pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement about the instrument given below?

choices.text: It measures the uterine cavity and the cervical length
It differentiates between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
It is used to diagnose cervical stenosis

questions.solution:
The given instrument is Simpson’s uterine sound. It is not used to retract the vagina for cervical examination. This is done using Sim's speculum.

The instrument is held like a pencil with the thumb and the first 2 fingers and introduced into the uterine cavity by keeping it in the midline and ensuring it is not forced.

The uses are given as follows:

  • To measure uterine cavity and cervical length
  • To diagnose cervical stenosis
  • To sound a polyp, IUCD or uterine septum
  • To break adhesions
  • To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp

questions.text: A  59-year old man presented with persistent wheezing, episodes of hemoptysis, and dry cough. Bronchoscopy revealed a mass occluding the left bronchus. Biopsy of the specimen revealed polygonal cells with fine stippled chromatin and eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in nests. The tumor was positive for CD 56, synaptophysin, and chromogranin. What is the cell of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchial carcinoid. Bronchial neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) arise from Kulchitsky cells.

WHO divides neuroendocrine neoplasms into four categories:

  • Typical carcinoid
  • Atypical carcinoid 
  • Large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma 
  • Small-cell carcinoma 

Carcinoid tumors are low-grade malignant epithelial neoplasms that represent 1% to 5% of all lung tumors. It is not related to smoking. Carcinoids may occur in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.

On gross examination, these tumors grow as fingerlike or spherical polypoid masses that project into the lumen of the bronchus or as collar button lesions, penetrating the bronchial wall to fan out in the peribronchial tissue.

Histologically, the tumor is composed of organoid, trabecular, palisading, ribbon, or rosette-like arrangements of cells separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. On electron microscopy, the cells exhibit the dense-core neurosecretory granules. 

Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for serotonin, neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, calcitonin, or other peptides.

10% of the cases may produce carcinoid syndrome.

Most carcinoids follow a relatively benign course and have good prognosis.

questions.text: Identify the correct insulin combination option.
questions.solution:
Detemir is a long-acting insulin and aspart is a rapid-acting insulin and matches with 1 and 2 respectively in the image showing basal-bolus regimen. 

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Inhaled insulin (2-3 hours)

  • Afrezza 

Rapid acting (3-4 hours)

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting (6-8 hours)

  • Regular

Intermediate acting (10-16 hours)

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting (12-24 hours)

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec (24-42 hours)

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with shortness of breath. He reports walking slower than his peers due to breathlessness. He has had two hospitalizations for similar complaints this year. His post-bronchodilator PFTs are FEV1/FVC < 0.55 and FEV1 55%.  Under what category would he be classified based on GOLD criteria?
questions.solution:
This patient belongs to moderate COPD, group E category.

The severity of COPD assessed by the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) is classified as:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

 

According to GOLD 2023 guidelines, COPD patients are classified into Group A, B, or E based on the severity of dyspnoea, frequency of exacerbations and hospitilization. Dyspnoea may be assessed using the modified MRC Dyspnoea scale or COPD Assessment Test (CAT score)

>=2 moderate exacerbations or >=1 leading to hospitalisation

Group E:
                         LABA+LAMA

consider LABA+LAMA+ICS* if blood eosinophil count >=300

 

0 or 1 moderate exacerbation (not leading to hospital admissions)

Group A: mMRC 0-1, CAT<10

                Bronchodilator

Group B: mMRC >=2, CAT >=10

          LABA + LAMA*

* single inhaler therapy maybe more convenient and effective than multiple inhalers

ICS - inhaled corticosteroids
LAMA - Long-acting Muscarinic Antagonists
LABA - Long-acting Beta Agonists

Modified MRC (mMRC) dyspnoea scale:

  • 0- Breathless only with strenuous exercise
  • 1- Breathless when hurrying on a level or walking up a hill
  • 2- Walks slower than peers or has to stop for breath when walking on level
  • 3- Stops for breath after walking about 100m or for a few minutes
  • 4- Breathless at rest

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with a past medical history of acute intermittent porphyria is planned for neurosurgery. Considering the risk of potential complications, the anaesthetist decides not to use barbiturates for induction.  What is the biochemical basis behind the worsening of porphyria by barbiturates?
questions.solution:
The biochemical basis of worsening of porphyria by barbiturates is due to de-repression of ALA synthase. De-repression is the removal of repression of an enzyme, or the induction of a blocked enzyme.

Barbiturates are metabolized by microsomal CYP450, a heme-protein oxidase system found in the liver. In patients with porphyria, barbiturates precipitate an attack of porphyria by the following mechanism:

questions.text: What is the best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of a Ryle's tube?
questions.solution:
The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube (RT) is sitting with neck flexion. The described position helps in directing the RT towards the esophagus and also prevents it from coiling in the oropharynx or entering the trachea.

RT, also known as nasogastric (NG) tube, measures 120-125 cm. It has 4 markings at 40cm (cardia), 50cm (body), 60cm (pylorus), and 70 cm (duodenum) to indicate the approximate position after the placement.

Indications for NG tube:

  • Feeding in patients with dysphagia, decreased appetite, or those who are nil per os (NPO) for medical or surgical reasons.
  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression in cases of intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome 
  • Bowel irrigation

The absolute contraindications for an NG tube are severe midface trauma, recent nasal surgery, and basilar skull fractures

Steps for the correct insertion of RT in an adult:

  1. Examination of the patient’s nostril for any anatomical abnormalities and then instillation with 10 ml of 1% lignocaine 
  2. NEX method is used to measure the length of the RT:  Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend the tube to the earlobe, and then to the xiphisternum.
  3. The patient is asked to sit upright with partial neck flexion. The tip of the Ryle’s tube is lubricated and passed along the floor of the nasal passage until a resistance is felt(corresponds to nasopharynx)
  4. The patient is subsequently asked to swallow water to guide the tube through the esophagus into the stomach until the marked length (based on the NEX method).
  5. NG tube is finally taped to secure it in place.


Confirmation of the correct position is done by:

  1. Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  2. X-ray chest to locate the lead markers
  3. Aspiration of contents and subsequently confirming gastric origin (pH <6 indicates gastric placement)

questions.text: Specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor occurs via which of these receptors?
questions.solution:
The specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor is by the envelope glycoprotein gp120. 

The drug maraviroc works by inhibiting interactions with the gp120. This is by binding to the CCR5 receptor on the lymphocyte.

Other options:

Option B : Cell fusion occurs via binding to gp41. Cell fusion is essential for infection to take place. Enfuvirtide is the drug that binds gp41, thus preventing viral entry. 

Option C, D: Binding to CD4 receptor requires the participation of a co-receptor CXCR 4 for T cell tropic HIV strains and CCR 5 for macrophage-tropic strains.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with thunderclap headaches and seizures. There is no history of trauma. Non-contrast CT was done and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a thunderclap headache and seizures with the given CT scan showing hyperdense areas corresponding to blood in the subarachnoid basal cisterns suggest a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. It usually occurs due to bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Most of the ruptured aneurysms are located at the circle of Willis.

Patients present with a sudden and severe headache referred to as thunderclap headache, which may be associated with vomiting, decreased consciousness, and seizures. Neck stiffness and photophobia may develop after a few hours.

Non-contrast CT scan is the imaging modality of choice if done within 12 hours. It shows an increased density of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces. A lumbar puncture should be done if there is a strong suspicion of SAH but negative CT findings. It is ideally done 12 hours later. This allows for red blood cell lysis to occur and bilirubin to be detected in the CSF.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: You are planning to start treatment in a middle-aged man diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. He has a history of chronic kidney disease and his current creatinine clearance is 25 mL/min. Which of the following drugs is least likely to require dose modification?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is the least likely drug to require dose modification in renal failure patients as it is metabolized in the liver and primarily excreted in bile. 

In patients with renal failure, the half-life of isoniazid will be prolonged, but its adverse effects are not significantly increased. Hence dose modification is not usually done for isoniazid in clinical practice as a reduction in dose may render the regimen ineffective and increase the chances of resistance.

Ethambutol and streptomycin are primarily excreted unchanged through the renal system and need dose modification in renal failure.

This is a controversial question. Upon thorough review, we found that both rifampicin and isoniazid do not require dose adjustment. However, rifampicin would be the single best answer as it has a safer profile in CKD patients.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: A focus of Klebsiella is detected in one of the ventilators during a routine quality and maintenance check in the NICU.  Sepsis protocol is enacted and a sepsis screen is ordered for all the neonates at risk.  Which of the following investigations is not sent as part of a neonatal sepsis screen?
questions.solution:
Absolute eosinophil count is not a component of neonatal sepsis screen.

The various components of the septic screen include:

  1. Total leukocyte count (TLC)
  2. Absolute neutrophil count (ANC)
  3. Immature: Total neutrophil ratio (IT),
  4. Micro-erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  5. C-reactive protein.

Blood culture: Gold standard for diagnosis.

All neonates suspected to have sepsis should have a septic screen to corroborate the diagnosis.

Note:

Most common fungus causing neonatal sepsis: Candida species.

questions.text: You are part of a research programme for COVID-19 and are asked to define the median incubation period. How will you define it?

choices.text: Interval between onset of symptoms in primary and secondary cases
Time required for 50% of cases to occur following exposure
Interval between exposure and the occurrence of the first symptom
Time required for the start of pathogenesis following exposure

questions.solution:
The median incubation period is the time required for 50% of the cases to occur following exposure. The median incubation period of COVID-19 of approximately 5 days.          

Incubation period is the time interval between invasion of the infectious agent and the appearance of the first symptom or sign in the body. It is termed as the latent period in non-infectious diseases.

Incubation period depends upon:

  • Generation time of pathogen
  • Portal of entry
  • Infective dose
  • Individual susceptibility

Incubation period is useful for :

  • Tracing the source of infection and contacts.
  • Determining the period of surveillance or quarantine.
  • Planning immunization.
  • Identification of point source or propagated epidemics.
  • Determining the prognosis.

questions.text: Most common cause of community acquired diarrhea
questions.solution:
The most common cause of community-acquired diarrhea is ETEC ( enterotoxigenic E.coli )

The most common cause of Hemolytic uremic syndrome(HUS) is EHEC. (enterohemorrhagic E.coli)

questions.text: For which of the following diseases is soil not a reservoir?
questions.solution:
The main reservoir of the coccobacilli belonging to the genus Brucella that cause brucellosis are animals like sheep, cattle, horses, goats, whales, and dogs.

A reservoir is the environment (e.g. soil, humans, animals, water, etc.) where the infectious agent grows and multiplies (natural habitat) and from where it can be transmitted to a susceptible host.

A source is an animal, object, human or substance which acts as an immediate mode of transmission and may or may not be a part of the reservoir.

Option A: Coccidiomycosis is also called Valley fever and the causative fungi belong to the Coccidiodes. The main reservoir of this organism is soil.

Option B: Bacillus anthracis is a soil commensal and is also found on the hides and dried skins of infected animals.

Option C: The natural reservoir for the fungi causing mycetoma is soil.

questions.text: Which of the following image shows the Duncan method?
questions.solution:
Image B shows the Duncan method of placental separation. 
 

Comparison between two types of placental separation methods:

Schultze method Duncan method
Separation begins from the center of the placenta to the periphery. Separation begins from the periphery to the center.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into the membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as the blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall.

Brandt Andrew's method or controlled cord traction is a manoeuvre of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labour. 

One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fingers over the anterior surface of the uterus. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backwards and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord.

Type III placenta previa is a type of incomplete or partial central placenta previa. Here, the placenta covers the internal os partially i.e. it covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated.

questions.text: A patient from a hilly area was referred with a partial small bowel obstruction confirmed on CECT. Conservative management was tried for a week, but he continued to deteriorate and was taken up for emergency laparotomy. On post-operative day 7, he developed atrial fibrillation. Investigations revealed elevated free T3 and free T4 levels. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the Jod-Basedow phenomenon, likely due to the administration of an iodine-containing contrast agent during CECT.

This phenomenon is characterized by hyperthyroidism due to enhanced thyroid hormone production following the administration of contrast agents and other iodine-containing substances. This occurs in:

  • Patients with autonomous thyroid nodules
  • Patients with pre-existing subclinical hypothyroidism (endemic iodine deficiency in hilly areas)

Option B: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is characterized by the transient inhibition of thyroid iodide organification by excess iodine, thereby decreasing thyroid hormone synthesis.

Option C: Basedow disease is another name for Graves' disease.

Option D: Plummer disease is another name for toxic multinodular goitre.

questions.text: What is the most common location of aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution: The most common location of aortic aneurysms is the infrarenal aorta.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with a single hypoaesthetic and a hypopigmented patch on the lateral aspect of the forearm. Microscopy of a biopsy sample from the lesion revealed granulomatous inflammation but acid-fast bacilli were not identified. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is tuberculoid leprosy.

On microscopic examination, tuberculoid leprosy has granulomatous lesions closely resembling those found in tuberculosis. Because of the strong host defense, bacilli are almost never found, hence the name paucibacillary leprosy.

Leprosy or Hansen disease is a slowly progressive infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae, mainly affecting the skin and peripheral nerves.
