questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to foscarnet

questions.solution:
Resistance to ganciclovir most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene. 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a beta-herpes virus. It is the most common congenital infection. In adults, its disease is mostly subclinical (option C). An apparent CMV infection resembles infectious mononucleosis (fever, sore throat, enlarged lymph nodes and splenomegaly). It is the most common infection in the donor organ seen 1-4 months after solid organ transplantation. In immunosuppressed hosts, it causes pneumonia and colitis. 

Diagnosis is by PCR assays. Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts (option B) and can thus be cultured in them, although the virus is often isolated from epithelial cells of the host. The cultured fibroblasts show owl-eye inclusion bodies after 2-3 weeks. 

UL54 (DNA polymerase) gene mutations can confer CMV resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir and foscarnet (option D).

questions.text: As you enter the OT, the senior resident asks you to administer Sugammadex to a patient being shifted to the post-op ward. Which muscle relaxant was likely to have been administered?
questions.solution:
Sugammadex is used for the reversal of rocuronium. 

Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It exerts its reversal effect by forming tight complexes in a 1:1 ratio with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium > vecuronium >> pancuronium).

It is eliminated unchanged via the kidneys.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image shows multiple vesicles & crusts clustered on an inflamed base around the lips which is characteristic of herpes labialis or cold sore.

It is commonly caused by herpes simplex virus type 1(HSV-1) and rarely by herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2). It begins with a prodrome of pain, burning, and tingling followed by the appearance of erythematous papules. The papules then become vesicular and may ulcerate. 

It is treated with oral acyclovir 200 mg and 5% topical acyclovir.

Option B: Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is commonly caused by the coxsackie virus.

Option C: Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by pearly white, wart-like umbilicated papules. It is caused by the pox virus.

Option D: Impetigo is characterized by golden yellow or honey-coloured crusts that form after the rupture of pustulating vesicles. Non-bullous impetigo is caused by both S. aureus and streptococcus. Bullous impetigo is caused by S. aureus.

Related Pearl: Clinical manifestations of herpes simplex virus-1

  1. Cutaneous lesions:
    • Fever blister
    • Herpetic whitlow
    • Herpetic gladiatorum
    • Eczema herpeticum: A generalised eruption caused by herpes infections in children suffering from eczema
  2. Mucosal (buccal mucosa is the most common site involved):
    • Gingivostomatitis
    • Pharyngitis
    • Recurrent herpes labialis
  3. Ophthalmic: 
    • Follicular conjunctivitis
    • Acute keratoconjunctivitis
  4. Nervous system:
    • HSV encephalitis
    • HSV meningitis

questions.text: A sexually active woman has been using Today sponge as a contraceptive. What does this contain?
questions.solution:
Today is a type of vaginal sponge that contains 9 – nonoxynol.

Today is a barrier contraceptive inserted vaginally. It has to be left in place for 6 hours after coitus. It can lead to toxic shock syndrome if left in place for more than 24 hours (rarely).

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with the following fetal presentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Breech type Description Presenting part
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia
Footling Both thighs and legs are partially extended Foot 
Knee  Thighs extended, Knee flexed Knee
Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed. Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: Aldosterone secretion is maximally stimulated by______
questions.solution: Hyperkalemia and activation of renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion.

questions.text: A woman with fever and breathlessness is admitted to the ICU. Her RT-PCR is positive for COVID-19. Which of the following statements is false regarding the organism causing it?

choices.text: It has club-shaped peplomers on its surface
It has a high rate of mutation
It acts by binding to ACE1 and TMPRSS4 receptors

questions.solution:
COVID-19 is caused by a the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2. The false statement is that coronavirus acts by binding to ACE1 and TMPRSS4 receptors.

Coronaviruses are a group of spherical or pleomorphic enveloped, positive sense ssRNA viruses. They have club or petal-shaped peplomers (option A). Coronaviruses are named for the crown-like spikes on their surface. Coronaviruses cause upper respiratory tract infections, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), and Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome (MERS). 

SARS-CoV-2 spreads through respiratory droplets produced by coughing or sneezing, and close personal contact (option B) such as touching the mouth and nose. It enters human cells when its spike protein binds to the ACE2 and TMPRSS2 receptors. The SARS-CoV-2 virus originated in China and caused a severe pandemic of COVID-19 in 2020. This virus is highly mutable (option C), thus making it difficult to produce vaccines against all serotypes. 

The recent emergence of OMICRON, a SARS-CoV-2 variant, has been classified as one of the variants of concern. Notably, fifteen of these mutations reside in spike glycoprotein's receptor-binding domain (RBD), which may alter transmissibility, infectivity, neutralizing antibody escape, and vaccine breakthrough cases of COVID-19.

questions.text: An anxious mother brought her 4-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. The girl was passing loose, bulky stools for the past 4 days. This was often associated with pain in the abdomen. The pediatrician ordered stool examination, which showed the following organisms. Which vitamin deficiency is the child at the greatest risk for?
questions.solution:
The stool examination (image) shows pear-shaped trophozoites having two nuclei and a flagellum, typical of Giardia lamblia. Giardiasis is associated with a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins like vitamin A.

Giardia lamblia is transmitted via contaminated drinking water.

Clinical features include acute infectious diarrhea or chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, and abdominal pain. Stools initially may be profuse and watery and later become greasy and foul-smelling. Stools do not contain blood, mucus, or leukocytes. It is associated with fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, iron deficiency, and growth stunting.

Diagnosis is done by stool enzyme immunoassay (EIA) or direct fluorescent antibody tests for Giardia antigens; EIA is superior to microscopy.

Treatment includes tinidazole and nitazoxanide.

questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of a newly built house.  Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
A child with acute abdominal pain, tingling sensation and weakness of limbs with history of eating paint likely has lead poisoning. It is characterized by impaired ALA dehydratase enzyme activity.

Lead is a potent inhibitor of both ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase/ heme synthase (option C). However, it has the greatest inhibitory action on ALA dehydratase. Lead poisonining thus leads to the buildup of protoporphyrin and ALA. Lead also substitutes for calcium in many fundamental cellular processes. It can cross red blood cell membranes as well as the blood-brain barrier and enter the neuroglial cells which support brain function. The fatal dose of lead is 20g of lead acetate and the fatal period is 1 to 2 days.

Other options: 

Option A: ALA synthase 2 defect causes X-linked protoporphyria. 
Option C: Heme synthase, or ferrochelatase, defect causes erythropoeitic protoporphyria. 
Option D: Coproporphyrinogen oxidase defect causes hereditary corproporphyria.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A patient presents to the E.R. with a history of a gunshot wound sustained while on a hunting trip. X-ray findings are as given below. Which of the following weapons is most likely to produce this type of lesion?
questions.solution:
The radiograph is suggestive of a close-range shotgun blast injury to the knee. Birdshot pellets are visible within and around the shattered patella, distal femur, and proximal tibia.

The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base. The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled.  The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator.  The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are ‘wads’ or pistons of felt, and cardboard or plastic discs, or both. Above these is the charge of shot (pellets), which varies greatly in number and size, finally covered by a card or plastic disc.

The image given below shows the entry wound in the case of a shotgun. There is a central round hole, with multiple pellet holes scattered around the central hole. This wound is most likely to have been caused by a shotgun from a range of 1-5 m.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Symptomatic intrauterine adhesions (also termed uterine synechiae) are known as Asherman syndrome. This condition occurs when the uterine cavity is obliterated by scarring due to filmy adhesions, dense bands. Endometrial damage can occur after curettage, infection due to an intrauterine device, uterine surgery, or rarely tuberculous endometritis. 

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, abortion, and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. And she is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain and on examination the right adnexal mass was palpable, non tender. On USG examination she has a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary. Which is the next step

choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualise the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.solution:
Doing a CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for Post-menopausal Ovarian cyst.

Initial steps in management include the following:

  • Estimate CA – 125 level
  • USG
  • Calculating Risk of Malignancy index
    • RMI = U x  M  x  Ca-125
    • U – Ultrasound score
    • M – Menopausal status
    • Ca 125 – Serum levels

Option B : CT scan is not recommended in initial evaluation.

Option C : Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size > 5 cm or RMI > 200.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, a known case of Parkinson disease on treatment for the past 10 years is complaining of hallucinations. From which of the following drugs, will the patient be benefited?
questions.solution:
Pimavanserin is an atypical antipsychotic approved for use in delusions and hallucinations associated with Parkinson’s disease.

It has a unique mechanism of action of antagonism and inverse agonism at 5-HT2A receptors with no action on dopamine receptors.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in labor is referred to a tertiary care center. On PV examination, the resident notes that the fetus is in brow presentation, and the largest diameter of the fetal skull is engaged. Identify this diameter.
questions.solution:
In brow presentation, the mentovertical diameter is engaged which is the longest diameter of the fetal skull. Normally, it measures 14 cm. 

The mentovertical diameter extends from the midpoint of the chin to the highest point on the sagittal suture.

Engaging diameters of the fetal skull vary with the attitude of the fetal head as given below:

Diameters Attitude of the head
Suboccipitobregmatic Complete flexion
Suboccipito-frontal Incomplete flexion
Occipitofrontal Marked deflexion
Mento-vertical Partial extension
Submentovertical Incomplete extension
Submentobregmatic Complete extension

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: A young adult presents with a deformed nose after falling from a ladder. The CT scan shows a displaced nasal fracture. What is the ideal time to reduce the fracture in this patient?
questions.solution:
The ideal time for reduction of fracture of the nasal bone is 5-7 days following injury, once the edema has subsided.

The presence of edema interferes with the accurate reduction of the fracture. In most cases, the deformity is due to edema. So, ice packs and head elevation are advised initially after injury. After 3-5 days, the edema would subside and the underlying deformity will be apparent on clinical assessment.

After 2 weeks it is difficult to reduce since the process of callus formation and the bony and fibrous union would have started.

questions.text: Purkinje fibers are inhibitory for _________.
questions.solution:
The input from the Purkinje cells to the deep nuclei is inhibitory.

However, the deep nuclei output is always excitatory.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to the ER with a history of a head injury following an RTA. CT head revealed a displaced fracture of the floor of the middle cranial fossa involving the pterygoid canal. Which of the following nerves are susceptible to injury?

choices.text: Lesser petrosal nerve and greater petrosal nerve
Greater petrosal nerve and deep petrosal nerve
Greater petrosal nerve and chorda tympani
Lesser petrosal nerve and deep petrosal nerve

questions.solution:
The involvement of the pterygoid canal can injure the vidian nerve, which is formed by:

  • Postganglionic sympathetic fibres of the deep petrosal nerve
  • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres of the greater petrosal nerve

Pterygoid canal (Vidian canal):

  • The pterygoid canal, also known as the Vidian canal, is a foramen in the base of the skull, located in the pterygoid process of the sphenoid bone, superior to the pterygoid plates, and inferomedial to the foramen rotundum. It transmits the Vidian artery and Vidian nerve from the middle cranial fossa to the pterygopalatine fossa 
  • It transmits the artery, nerve, and vein of the pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve and Vidian artery) into the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • The vidian nerve contains the preganglionic fibers of the pterygopalatine ganglion, which provide the secretomotor supply to the nasal mucous glands. Hence vidian neurectomy is indicated in vasomotor rhinitis and intractable rhinnorrhea which is refractory to other treatments.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is deficient in patients with Krabbe disease?
questions.solution:
Krabbe disease is due to the deficiency of galactosylceramidase.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

The aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels is the characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease.

Related Pearl: Lysosomal storage diseases

Lysosomal Storage Diseases Enzyme-deficient
Sphingolipidoses
Gaucher disease Glucocerebrosidase
Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A
Fabry disease α-galactosidase A
Krabbe disease

Galactocerebrosidase

(Galactosylceramidase)
Niemann-Pick disease Sphingomyelinase
Mucopolysaccharidoses  
Hurler syndrome α-L-iduronidase
Hunter syndrome Iduronate-2-sulfatase
Others:
Pompe disease Lysosomal acid α-1,4- glucosidase

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

S. No.

Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Lipid

Accumulating

Clinical Symptoms

1

Tay–Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A

Ganglioside

Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness

2

Sandhoff's disease

Hexosaminidase A and B

Globoside & Ganglioside

Similar to Tay–Sachs disease but also has hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal dysplasias

3

Fabry's disease

α-Galactosidase

Globotriaosyl-ceramide

Skin rash, kidney failure (full symptoms only in males; X-linked recessive)

4

Metachromatic leukodystrophy

Arylsulfatase A

3-Sulfogalactosyl-ceramide

Mental retardation and psychologic disturbances in adults; demyelination

5

Krabbe disease

β-Galactosidase

Galactosylceramide

Mental retardation; myelin almost absent

6

β-Glucosidase

Glucosylceramide

Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, mental retardation in infants

7

Sphingomyelin

Enlarged liver and spleen, mental retardation; fatal in early life

8

Ceramidase

Ceramide

Hoarseness, dermatitis, skeletal deformation, mental retardation; fatal in early life

questions.text: During your OBG posting, one of the senior residents asks you to induce labor in a primigravida admitted at 40 weeks of gestation. Identify the following device that you can use for this purpose.
questions.solution:
This is an image of cervidil vaginal insert. It is used for cervical ripening and improves the Bishop's score.

It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone designed to release at a rate of approximately 0.3 mg/hr over 10-hours.

questions.text: Which apoprotein do chylomicrons require in order to enter the lymph?
questions.solution: Each nascent chylomicron particle has one molecule of apolipoprotein(apo) B-48 with which chylomicrons are released from the cells into the lymphatic system and travel to the blood, where they receive apo C-II and apo E from HDLs.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV-seropositive man presents with raised violaceous plaques over the legs. Microscopy shows a lesion in the dermis with dilated, jagged vascular channels lined and surrounded by plump spindle cells. It contains red cells with marked hemorrhage, hemosiderin pigment, and mononuclear inflammation. Mitotic figures are also seen. Which organism is associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8). 

Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm, that is highly associated with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). It is the most common cancer seen in patients having AIDS. Though the incidence of Kaposi carcinoma reduced, it still occurs in 2-3% of HIV-infected individuals.

The pathogenesis of Kaposi sarcoma that is caused by HHV8 includes:

  • A virally encoded G protein that induces VEGF production, stimulating endothelial growth
  • The lytic infection caused by HHV8 increases the pro-inflammatory cytokines
  • HHV8 encoded proteins inhibit the p53 induced apoptosis

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

questions.text: The following instrument is used for:
questions.solution:
The given instrument with an arrowed blade and angled shank is a myringotome. It is used for myringotomy.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are stimulated by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are stimulated by acidic contents, not alkaline.

The duodenal factors that can initiate enterogastric inhibitory reflexes (enterogastric reflexes) are:

  • Distention of the duodenum
  • Presence of any irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  • Acidity of the duodenal chyme
  • Osmolality of the chyme - either hypotonic or hypertonic fluid initiate enterogastric inhibitory reflexes. Thus, the flow of non-isotonic fluids into the small intestine is regulated. This prevents rapid changes in electrolyte concentrations in the extracellular fluid during the absorption of the intestinal contents.
  • Presence of certain breakdown products in the chyme, especially proteins and to a lesser extent, of fats

questions.text: A 23-year-old-lady came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of hair loss and the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft as shown. There is no associated pruritis of the scalp. Which of the following could be the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft is suggestive of black piedra. The causative agent of this condition is Piedraia hortae.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types:

  • Black piedra: It is characterized by firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. Hair becomes brittle and breaks easily leading to complains of hair loss. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.
  • White piedra: It is characterized by soft, white or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.

Management involves shaving or cutting off the affected hair along with topical antifungals.

questions.text: What type of skull fracture is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a gutter fracture of the skull as part of the outer table is missing.

Gutter fractures form a furrow in the outer table of the skull, usually as a result of a glancing blow by a missile from a rifled firearm. They may also be associated with comminuted depressed fractures of inner table of the skull.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of patients with hydrargyrism?
questions.solution:
Hydrargyrism means mercury poisoning. Bowen's disease is associated with chronic low-level exposure to arsenic, not mercury.

Features of chronic mercury poisoning:

  • Tremors - most consistent manifestation. They are:
    • Danbury tremors - fine muscle fasciculations punctuated every few minutes by coarse shaking or jerky movements, intentional type. Progression of tremors is hands →lips→tongue→arms and legs.
    • Hatter's shakes - Severe impairment of daily activities involving delicate movements like shaving, writing, holding a tumbler or spoon.
    • Concussio mercurialis - most severe form, literally no activity is possible.
  • Erethism mercurialis - Shyness, memory loss, and change in personality
  • Nephrotic syndrome and renal tubular anomalies
  • Acrodynia (pink disease) - Seen in small children and characterized by a generalized rash; edema and erythema of the palms, soles, and face. 

Related Pearl: Mercury Poisoning

Features

Mercury
Source of exposure

Thermometers (elemental mercury)

Industries (inorganic mercury)

Fish (organic mercury) 
Route of absorption

Elemental - Respiratory tract (negligible through GI unless the mucosa is damaged) 

Inorganic - GI tract

Organic - GI tract
Mechanism of action

binds to sulhydryl groups of enzymes and affects

  • glutathione metabolism
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

Respiratory tract (elemental mercury)

GI tract (inorganic mercury)

Respiratory + GI tract (organic mercury)
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Renal (elemental mercury)

Renal (inorganic mercury)

CNS (organic mercury)
Characteristic clinical findings

 

Mnemonic: MEATS

M -

  • Mercuria lentis
  • Membranous colitis 
  • Minimata disease
  • Membranous glomerulopathy

E-Erethism (personality disturbance, insomnia, and loss of memory)

A-Acrodynia (Pink disease)

T-Tremors (Coarse tremors) - Include Danbury tremors, hatter’s or Glass blower’s shakes

S-Salivation (excessive salivation)
Diagnosis Blood and/or 24 hour urine mercury level
Treatment BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A resident was inserting a central venous line through the femoral vein. He accidentally injured the structure medial to the femoral vein, within the femoral sheath. Which structure is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The lymphatic vessels lie medial to the femoral vein and are likely to be injured in this case.

Femoral sheath is the funnel-shaped prolongation of the fascia which contains femoral vessels. Anteriorly it is made of transversalis fascia and posteriorly it is made of fascia iliaca.

It is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains:
    • Lymphatic vessels
    • Areolar tissue
    • Lymph node of Cloquet. 

The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure.

questions.text: A 40-year old female underwent total thyroidectomy and on the third postoperative day, the patient complains of numbness in her fingers and perioral area. Which of the following vessels would have been injured during the surgery?

choices.text: Anterior branch of superior thyroid artery
Posterior branch of superior thyroid artery
Superior branch of inferior thyroid artery
Inferior branch of inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of postoperative hypoparathyroidism due to injury to the superior branch of the inferior thyroid artery.

The parathyroid glands are small yellowish-brown structures lying between the posterior border of the thyroid gland and its capsule.  There are

  • Two superior parathyroid glands 
  • Two inferior parathyroid glands

These are supplied by the superior branch of the inferior thyroid artery. They secrete parathormone which helps in the regulation of the serum calcium, by the release of calcium from bones.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the labour room with lower abdominal pain. Her vitals are BP - 90/60 mmHg and PR - 120 bpm. Fetal distress was noted and she was taken up for a caesarean section. The uterus appears as shown below.  Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in revealed abruptio placenta
It is an indication for hysterectomy
It is a case of uteroplacental apoplexy

questions.solution:
The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severe forms of concealed abruptio placenta. 

There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, the uterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broad ligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity.

It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has come to your clinic. On examination, thelarche is absent. She has a normal stature, and her karyotype is 46XX. Which investigation would you prefer to perform first?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of primary amenorrhea. The first line of investigation in primary amenorrhea should be hormonal assay (LH, FSH, estrogen).

Following this investigation, USG pelvis and MRI pelvis can be performed to enable the anatomical assessment.

LH and FSH levels help to assess whether it is a hypogonadotropic or hypergonadotropic condition. The hormone replacement therapy is planned based on LH and FSH levels.

The various types of hypogonadism are as follows:

Type of Hypogonadism LH/FSH Estrogen Primary defect
Hypergonadotropic High Low Ovary
Hypogonadotropic Low Low Hypothalamus/Pituitary
Eugonadotropic Normal Normal Varied

Note: In a patient with primary amenorrhea with absent sexual characteristics, the first line of investigation is hormonal assay (LH and FSH levels).

questions.text: A P3 woman bleeds profusely after delivery of the placenta. You initiate oxytocin infusion. The patient continues to bleed and the uterus fails to contract despite bimanual compression. She becomes tachycardic and hypotensive. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Balloon tamponade is the next step in the management of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management and bimanual uterine massage. 

Option A: Tight intrauterine packing has become unpopular due to the dangers of concealed bleeding and infections. It can be used in low-resource settings while shifting the patient to tertiary care centers.

Option C: Uterine artery ligation is done when tamponade fails (Bakri balloon and compression sutures).

Option D: Hysterectomy is the last option when all the other treatment modalities fail. Usually, the uterus contracts and bleeding stops with ligation or embolization. However, hysterectomy is done sooner rather than later in cases of placenta accreta and uterine rupture.

questions.text: What is a disease imported to an area from another called?
questions.solution:
Exotic diseases are those imported into a country where they do not occur usually. E.g, rabies in the United Kingdom.

Enzootic diseases are those which are endemic in animals. E.g, anthrax, brucellosis.

Epornithic disease refers to an epidemic in birds. E.g, psittacosis.

Epizootic disease refers to an outbreak of a disease or an epidemic in animals with the implication that it may affect humans. E.g, Q fever, influenza.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is described as emotionally cold and self-absorbed. He likes to stay alone, detached from social relationships, and prefers solitary activities. What type of personality disorder is this?
questions.solution:
A young male who is alone by choice and emotionally cold comes under schizoid personality.

Schizoid personality is a markedly detached person, stays alone in introspection, and lives in his own fantasy world. This is associated with having a cold attitude.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: A 35 yr old man presents with hypertension, coarse facial features, frontal bossing, large hands and feet, mandibular enlargement and a large fleshy nose. His age-matched serum IGF-I levels are elevated. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acromegaly and is due to excess growth hormone (GH).

Acromegaly occurs when excessive GH is secreted after puberty (after fusion of long bone epiphysis). Features include

  • Prognathism (protrusion of jaw), hypertrophy of frontal bones
  • Acral enlargement in hands and feet (due to thickening of soft tissues)
  • Visceromegaly: Enlargement of most organs especially the tongue, thyroid, salivary gland, liver, spleen, kidney, and prostate

Serious complications include cardiomyopathy with arrhythmias, diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. Age-matched IGF-I levels are elevated.

questions.text: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for two years.  She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polyps with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissue biopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the following appearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Recurrent rhinitis, chronic nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockage, multiple ethmoidal polyps and the microscopic appearance of conical vesicles with conidia over two-thirds of the vesicle is suggestive of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis caused by Aspergillus fumigatus.

Aspergillus spp. can lead to the following types of sinusitis:

  1. Acute invasive sinusitis: It affects immunocompromised patients. They present with fever, nasal or facial discomfort, blocked nose and bloody nasal discharge. Pale, dusky or necrotic tissue will be present within the sinuses.
  2. Chronic aspergillus sinusitis:
    • Fungal ball of sinus: The maxillary sinus, most commonly, is filled with an aspergillus ball. No tissue invasion is present.
    • Chronic invasive sinusitis: There is slow destruction of the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses with bone destruction and localised spread. Patients present with chronic nasal discharge and blockage, loss of the sense of smell and persistent headache. Involvement of the orbit results in proptosis and blindness.
    • Chronic granulomatous sinusitis: Patients present with facial swelling and unilateral proptosis. Biopsied tissue shows granulomatous (not necrotic) reaction.
  3. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis: Patients present with chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. On microscopy, eosinophilia and Charcot-Leyden crystals can be seen.

On microscopic examination of the sinus or polyp tissue, hyaline, septate, acute branching hyphae of Aspergillus spp. can be seen. The various species can be differentiated based on the appearance of the conidiophores. In Aspergillus fumigatus, the vesicle is conical. Phialides are arranged in a single row. Conidia arise from the upper two-thirds of the vesicle and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus flavus has a globular vesicle. Phialides are arranged in one or two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option C: Aspergillus niger has a globular-shaped vesicle. Phialides are in two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black.

Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores (brush or broom appearance).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common clinical presentation in patients with craniopharyngiomas?
questions.solution:
Headache is the most common presenting symptom of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign, suprasellar cystic masses. They have a bimodal distribution, occurring predominantly in children but also between the ages of 55 and 65 years. It can present with the following clinical symptoms:

  • Headache
  • Hypopituitarism
    • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Central diabetes insipidus
  • Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Raised ICT - vomiting, papilledema, hydrocephalus

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The image depicts central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) showing the "splashed sauce" appearance.

Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterised by sudden visual loss. There is splashed sauce appearance on fundoscopy due to retinal hemorrhages. Risk factors include high intraocular pressure (IOP), hypertension and blood viscosity syndromes. 

CRVO is classified into two types:

  • Ischemic CRVO: Characterized by relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), markedly reduced visual acuity, and many cotton-wool spots
  • Non-ischemic CRVO: Characterized by normal pupillary reaction, reduced visual acuity, and few cotton-wool spots

Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of an ovarian mass sent to the pathology department revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is more common in women with low parity
The pathogenesis is related to family history and heritable mutations
High-grade tumors are associated with TP53 mutations

questions.solution:
The given image denotes Psammoma bodies which are a histopathological finding seen in ovarian papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma. These tumors are most commonly bilateral.

The majority of serous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline. But the serous carcinomas of the ovary include the most common malignant tumors of the ovary. 

Nulliparity, family history, and heritable mutations play a role in the development of these tumors. Mutations in the oncogenes KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 result in low-grade tumors, and mutation in TP53 is associated with high-grade tumors. 

There is a higher frequency of carcinoma in women with low parity. Women on oral contraceptive pills or those who have undergone tubal ligation are at a lower risk. The marker for ovarian tumors is CA-125.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the given otoscopy finding in a child with poor scholastic performance?
questions.solution:
The given otoscopic image shows a subtotal perforation. It involves all four quadrants of the tympanic membrane but is covered by remnant pars tensa/annulus all around.

Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is the single most important cause of hearing impairment in rural populations. Children with CSOM have poor academic performance. 

Related Pearl: Types of tympanic membrane perforation

questions.text: Cushing’s ulcers are seen in
questions.solution:
Cushing’s ulcers are seen in patients with head injury. They can also be seen in cases of space-occupying lesions, such as intracranial tumors. The most common areas affected are the acid-producing areas of the stomach (fundus and body).

Stress ulcers observed in severe burns patients are called Curling’s ulcers. They are usually seen in the duodenal mucosa and are related to reduced perfusion and ischemia.

Stress-related gastric ulcers are seen in patients with massive burns, severe shock, sepsis, or head injury. Inflammatory mediators released in these conditions result in gastric mucosal inflammation. The most common presentation is minimal GI bleeding.

questions.text: Which does 'I' stand for in the PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.solution:
The 'I' in the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) stands for iatrogenic causes.

AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:

  • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB.
  • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 3-6 months minimum.

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) 
    • Endometrial hyperplasia 
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
    • PCOD
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
    • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis 
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations 
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text: A gynecologist is performing the following procedure in a woman with postmenopausal bleeding. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The image depicts saline infusion sonography (SIS), also known as sonohysterography. It is usually done after a transvaginal ultrasound, to assess the detailed anatomy of the uterine cavity.

In this procedure, a balloon catheter is inserted through the cervix and the endometrial cavity is distended with 20-40ml of sterile saline. The balloon is inflated to block the backflow of the infused sterile saline and transvaginal ultrasound is performed to visualize the cavity. 

It is used:

  • To determine the endometrial thickness 
  • To determine the cause in cases of infertility
  • To identify Mullerian anomalies 
  • To visualize endometrial polyps and pedunculated fibroids

The image given below shows the appearance of the uterus on SIS.

Option A: Transvaginal ultrasound is the initial evaluation for postmenopausal bleeding.

Option B: In balloon endometrial ablation, a balloon is inserted into the uterus and inflated with glycine or 5% glucose. It is then heated up, and the endometrium is ablated by the tamponade effect.

Option D: In hysterosalpingography, contrast dye is inserted into the uterus via a catheter, and the uterine and fallopian tube anatomy is visualized.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL
Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

This is AIIMS pattern question. Detailed and thorough knowledge on cardiac cycle, pressures and volumes is a must for any entrance exam as it a frequently tested topic.

questions.text: A young nulliparous female who desires pregnancy comes to you with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding. On palpation, an abdominal mass corresponding to 14 weeks of gestation is felt. The mass is found to be a subserosal pedunculated fibroid on imaging. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice in this nulliparous female with subserosal pedunculated fibroid is myomectomy. Myomectomy is indicated if the uterus size corresponds to more than 12 weeks of gestation and the patient desires pregnancy.

Myomectomy refers to the removal of fibroids and preserving the uterus. It is indicated in fibroids which present with the following 

  • Persistent uterine bleeding despite medical therapy
  • Excessive pain or pressure symptoms
  • Size > 12 weeks, patient desirous to have a baby
  • Unexplained infertility with distortion of the uterine cavity due to fibroid
  • Recurrent pregnancy wastage due to fibroid
  • Rapid growth during follow up
  • Subserous pedunculated fibroid

Myomectomy can be performed by laparoscopy, hysteroscopy, or laparotomy. It is contraindicated in patients with an infected fibroid, pelvic or endometrial tuberculosis, suspected malignancy, and growth in post-menopausal and multiparous women where hysterectomy can be the safe definitive management.

Fibroids are benign estrogen dependant tumors of the uterine smooth muscles and connective tissue. 

Management of uterine fibroids in asymptomatic patients includes observation with regular follow-up regardless of the size of the fibroid. Surgery is indicated in cornual fibroids if it causes infertility or pedunculated fibroids (due to the risk of torsion). 

In symptomatic patients, medical therapy is done to shrink the fibroid. It acts as a preoperative adjunct. Surgical methods such as myomectomy, laparoscopic myolysis, hysterectomy, and endometrial ablation are tried for patients with persistent symptoms despite conservative management. Hysterectomy is done in postmenopausal women and in multiparous women who have completed their families or are not desirous of childbirth.

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted with complaints of fever, anorexia, vomiting, abdominal pain and dark urine since 6 days. On investigation, he had elevated liver enzymes and serology was positive for IgM hepatitis A antibodies. Which of the following liver enzymes is most specific for his condition?
questions.solution:
The enzyme most specific for his condition, acute viral hepatitis, is alanine aminotransferase (ALT).

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is predominantly found in the liver and therefore is a more specific marker for hepatocellular damage than AST.

Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) is found in various tissues. The AST/ALT ratio is very important.

  • AST/ALT <1 is seen in hepatocellular damage like in NAFLD, toxic hepatitis, paracetamol toxicity. In cirrhosis, the ratio becomes more than 1.
  • AST/ALT> 2 is suggestive while AST/ALT> 3 is highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease.

Other options: 

Option A: Alkaline phosphatase rise is seen in many liver diseases but more than fourfold rise indicates cholestasis.

Option D: GGT is used to identify occult alcohol use.

Related Pearl: Principal Serum Enzymes Used in Clinical Diagnosis

 Serum Enzyme Major Diagnostic Use/Location
Aminotransferases 
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST/SGOT) Liver function
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT/SGPT) Viral hepatitis
Creatine kinase
CK-MM Skeletal muscle, Muscle disorders
CK-BB Brain, Brain injury, meningitis, abnormal cell growth, severe shock, stroke, hypothermia, or restricted blood flow to the bowel.
CK-MB Heart and skeletal muscle, Myocardial Infarction, Muscular dystrophy
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
HHHH (I1)/LDH-1 Heart & RBC;Myocardial infarction
HHHM(I2)/LDH-2 Reticuloendothelial system
HHMM(I3)/LDH-3 Lungs
HMMM(I4)/LDH-4 Liver & Skeletal Muscles
MMMM(I5)/LDH-5 Liver & Skeletal Muscles; Liver diseases
Others
Amylase, Lipase and Acid Phosphatase Acute pancreatitis
Ceruloplasmin Hepatolenticular degeneration (Wilson disease)
γ-Glutamyl transferase Liver diseases (Alcoholic Liver Disease)
β-Glucocerebrosidase Gaucher disease
Alkaline Phosphatase (isozymes) Bone disorders, obstructive liver diseases

questions.text: You are assisting your attending in conducting a pulmonary artery catheterisation for a patient in the ICU. You are asked to explain your understanding of the procedure in brief. Which of the following statements would be incorrect?

choices.text: It involves direct measurement of left atrial pressure.
Cardiac arrhythmia is the most frequent complication.

questions.solution:
Left atrial pressure (LAP) is indirectly measured through pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP).

LAP has been the gold standard for evaluating mitral stenosis and decompensated congestive heart failure. 

Option B: Swan-Ganz catheter is used for pulmonary artery catherization.

Option C: Cardiac arrhythmias are the most frequent complication.

Option D: The catheter is incorporated with thermistors that can be used to measure cardiac output, from which a multitude of hemodynamic values can be derived.

questions.text: The severity of mitral regurgitation can be assessed by:
questions.solution:
The severity of mitral regurgitation (MR) can be assessed by the wide splitting of the S2. Due to severe regurgitation of blood, the pressure in the left ventricle falls rapidly, leading to the early closure of the aortic valve. 

Clinical findings that indicate the severity of MR is:

  • Reduced cardiac output
  • Palpable systolic thrill
  • Palpable S3
  • Wide splitting of S2

Note: The intensity of murmur does not always correlate with the severity of the murmur. Intensity may be diminished in severe MR caused by LV dysfunction, acute MI and periprosthetic valve regugitation.

Related Pearl: Mitral Regurgitation

Stages of mitral regurgitation:

Stage Valve prolapse and coaptation Hemodynamic changes
A
(At risk of MR)		 Prolapse- Mild
Coaptation- Normal		 Not seen 
B
(Progressive MR)		 Prolapse- Moderate to severe
Coaptation- Normal		 LA enlargement- mild
LV enlargement- absent
Pulmonary hypertension- not seen
C
(Asymptomatic severe MR)		 Prolapse- Severe
Coaptation- Lost/ flail leaflets		 LA enlargement- moderate to severe
LV enlargement- present
Pulmonary hypertension- +/- at rest

Stage C1- 
LVEF- >60%
LVESD- <40 mm

Stage C2-
LVEF- ≤60%
LVESD- ≥ 40 mm

D
(Symptomatic severe MR)

 Prolapse- Severe
Coaptation- Lost/ flail leaflets		 LA enlargement- moderate to severe
LV enlargement- present
Pulmonary hypertension- present

questions.text: A patient newly diagnosed with HIV is found to have a CD4+ count of 78cells/µL. Which of the following is not a function of these cells?
questions.solution:
CD4+ is a marker of T helper and memory cells. They do not produce immunoglobulins.

CD4+ T cells are activated when an antigen-presenting cell expressing MHC-II binds to them. The activated CD4+ T cell differentiates into T helper (TH) cells and regulatory T cells. The TH cells are further differentiated into TH1, TH2 and TH17 cells. Helper T cells have the following functions: 

  • Activation and proliferation of cytotoxic T cells
  • Regulation of monocyte-macrophage system
  • Activation of B cell to produce plasma cells
  • Production of interleukins 

Memory cells (Tm) have both CD4+ and CD8+ markers. They provide anamestic immune response and are thus responsible for immunogenic memory. 

Immunoglobulins are produced by the plasma cells.

Related Pearl: T Helper cells- Types and functions

Cell Type

T helper cell 1

T helper 2

T helper 17

Major cytokines produced

IFN-γ

IL-4, IL-5, IL-13

IL-17, IL-22

Cytokines that induce this subset

IFN-γ, IL-12

IL-4

TGF-β, IL-6, IL-1, IL-23

Immunological reactions triggered

Macrophage activation, stimulation of IgG antibody production

Stimulation of IgE production, activation of mast cells and eosinophils

Recruitment of neutrophils, monocytes

Host defense against

Intracellular microbes

Helminthic parasites

Extracellular bacteria, fungi

Role in disease

Autoimmune and other chronic inflammatory diseases (such as IBD, psoriasis, granulomatous inflammation)

Allergies

Autoimmune and other chronic inflammatory diseases (such as IBD, psoriasis, MS)

questions.text: You decide to start recombinant growth hormone therapy in a child with idiopathic short stature. The treatment primarily works by the activation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone primarily acts through activation of the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

Cytokines such as interferon-gamma and prolactin hormone also act by the JAK STAT pathway.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)

Cholecystokinin

cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
