Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Corneal transparency is maintained by______.
questions.solution:
Corneal transparency is maintained mainly by the endothelial layer of the cornea.

Endothelium possesses Na+/K+ ATPase, which keeps the corneal stroma in a relatively dehydrated state. This helps in maintaining the transparency of the cornea.

Other factors contributing to the transparency of the cornea are as follows:

  • Regular arrangement of corneal lamellae (Maurice theory)
  • Peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory)
  • Avascularity of the cornea
  • Balance between intraocular pressure (IOP) and swelling pressure

questions.text:
ABG analysis of a patient is shown below. What is the probable underlying acid-base disorder in this patient?

pH- 7.1

pCO2- 16 mmHg

HCO3- - 6 mEq/L

pO2- 78 mmHg

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis. 

Step 3: pCO2 is 16 mmHg indicating respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in pCO2 along with the decrease in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.

Step 4: The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula (Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2).

Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19 mmHg

A pCO2 level of 16 mmHg falls within the range given above. Hence, metabolic acidosis is associated with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

(pCO2 values above or below 15 - 19 mmHg would indicate mixed acid-base disorders)

Alternatively:

The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.2 mmHg decrease in pCO2 for every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate.

The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L

Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.2 = 22

Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22 = 18 mmHg (roughly = 16 mmHg since the standard values are approximations)

This method also indicates primary metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis. However, Winter's formula is more accurate.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is?
questions.solution:
The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is 4-8%.

The risk of genetic diseases in non-consanguineous marriage is 2-4%.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with irrelevant slurred speech. On examination, a dry mouth, dry and hot skin, and dilated pupils are noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Datura poisoning.

The two species are jimson weed (Datura stramonium) and angel’s trumpet (Datura candida).

Seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked. Poisoning leads to delirium, hallucinations, and seizures. Additionally, other classic anticholinergic effects, such as mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth and skin, blurred vision, urinary retention, and hyperthermia may present.

Gastric emptying is often delayed, and the small, plentiful seeds can become trapped among the gastrointestinal folds after ingestion. Thus gastric decontamination can be an important therapy.

Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholine esterase antagonist, is an effective treatment for severe anticholinergic poisoning.

In India, the root and leaves of Jimsonweed (Datura) were burned and the smoke was inhaled to treat asthma. Around the 1800s, British colonists observed this and introduced the belladonna alkaloids in western medicine for the management of asthma.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought with complaints of self-mutilating behaviour in which he bit off the distal end of his right ring finger and left thumb. For the past 6 months, he had decreased sleep, auditory hallucinations, social withdrawal, and disorganised behaviour. Investigations revealed neutrophilia and lymphocytosis. Serum uric acid level is 6 mg/dL. HGPRTase activity is normal. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of self-mutilation in a patient with schizophrenia is known as Van Gogh syndrome.

Van Gogh was a Dutch painter who suffered from schizophrenia. He cut off his ear during one of his psychotic episodes.

Pfropf syndrome is schizophrenia associated with mental retardation. 'Pfropf' is the German word for 'graft'. Pfrofp schizophrenia literally means schizophrenia grafted on preexisting mental retardation.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is characterized by neurological abnormalities, self-mutilative behavior, and the overproduction of uric acid. It occurs due to a complete deficiency of HGPRTase enzyme (hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase ).

Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome occurs due to a partial deficiency of HGPRTase, and is associated with hyperuricemia but no central nervous system manifestations.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with complaints of 7 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. Her ultrasound scan is shown below. What does the red arrowhead represent?
questions.solution:
The red arrowhead represents the yolk sac. The yellow arrowhead shows the double ring - outer decidua parietalis and inner decidua capsularis. 

It is referred to as the double decidua sign and is seen in the first trimester transvaginal sonogram. It is useful to confirm an early intrauterine location for the pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A patient presents with generalized exfoliative erythroderma. The peripheral blood smear shows the following cell. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a classical Sezary cell with cerebriform nuclei which points towards a diagnosis of Sezary syndrome. These are neoplastic T cells.

Sezary syndrome and mycosis fungoides are different manifestations of tumors of CD4+ helper T cells that are home to the skin.

Sezary syndrome is a variant presenting as generalized exfoliative erythroderma. It rarely goes into tumefaction and there is associated leukemia of Sezary cells.

In Mycosis fungoides, only the epidermis and upper dermis are infiltrated by neoplastic T cells with the characteristic cerebriform appearance. In the later stages of the disease, progression occurs to lymph nodes and bone marrow. Tumour cells are not seen in blood. The disease progresses through the premycotic phase, plaque phase, and tumour phase.

questions.text: A patient believes he is the most important person in the world and so his neighbours and family members are trying to harm him as they are jealous of him. His wife says otherwise and says he behaves like this only recently and before that he was working peacefully as a school teacher. He is most likely suffering from?

choices.text: Delusion of grandiosity, persecution and reference

questions.solution:
• Belief that he is the most important person in the world – Delusion of grandeur
  • Belief that his neighbours and family members are trying to harm him – Delusion of persecution
  • Belief that others feel jealous – Part of delusion of persecution

A scenario of this kind is most likely seen in manic patients with

  • Primary delusion of Grandeur (and)
  • Secondary delusion of Persecution

Delusion of reference:

  • Delusion in which events, objects, or other persons in one’s immediate environment have a particular and unusual significance in reference to the person experiencing the delusion.
  • Examples :
  • A feeling that people on television or radio are talking about or talking directly to them
  • Believing that headlines or stories in newspapers are written especially for them

questions.text: During the neurological examination of a patient, on shining light in his left eye, the left pupil does not constrict but the right pupil does. On shining light in his right eye, the right pupil constricts and left doesn’t. The defect is in:
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of left eye efferent (oculomotor nerve) defect.

The loss of pupillary light reflex (both direct and consensual) in the left eye associated with a preserved direct pupillary response in the right eye is characteristic of an efferent pupillary defect.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the serological tests of syphilis?

choices.text: Rapid plasma reagin test is a group specific treponemal test
VDRL test is the test of choice for response to therapy
VDRL is the test of choice for examining CSF
Treponemal tests are likely to remain reactive even after adequate therapy

questions.solution:
RPR is a non-specific test. It uses the VDRL antigen (cardiolipin) containing carbon particles. Hence, results can be seen by the naked eye, whereas VDRL requires a microscope for visualization of flocculation. 

The test of choice for monitoring response to treatment and for examining CSF is VDRL.

The test of choice for syphilis screening is RPR. 

After treatment, in early syphilis,

  • Non-treponemal tests- titers decline or become non-reactive 
  • Treponemal tests- remain reactive

For diagnosis of syphilis, a 2 test approach is used i.e., screening with an NTT (non-treponemal test) which includes either VDRL or RPR. Confirmation of syphilis is done by a treponemal test, most commonly by TPHA (Treponema pallidum hemagglutination test).

Follow-up is done using NTT (as treponemal tests remains positive for years after treatment).

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: Which of the following is an enrichment medium?
questions.solution:
The image 'A' represents alkaline peptone water, which is an enrichment medium used for Vibrio cholerae.

The other images represent:

Image B- Blood agar with P. aeruginosa colonies 

Image C- Loeffler's serum slope, which is used to isolate C. diphtheriae

Image D- Chocolate agar with F. tularensis colonies

Enrichment media suppress the growth of commensal bacteria and allow for the growth of certain organisms. These media are used for samples with mixed flora e.g. stool. They are always liquid media, like alkaline peptone water. Other examples include tetrathionate broth and selenite-F broth for Salmonella sp. and Shigella sp.

Enriched medium are those media to which additional nutrients such as blood, serum, or egg are added. They're used to grow bacteria with specific nutritional requirements. Examples include blood agar to test the hemolytic property of bacteria, chocolate agar for isolation of H. influenzae and Loeffler's serum slope for isolation of C. diphtheriae.

questions.text: A 16-year-old athlete was diagnosed with an isolated avulsion fracture of the lesser tubercle of the humerus. The forceful contraction of which of the following muscles​ causes this fracture?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, forceful contraction of the subscapularis muscle has caused the isolated avulsion fracture of the lesser tubercle of the humerus. 

The subscapularis muscle is inserted on the lesser tubercle of the humerus. Forceful contraction of subscapularis muscle to resist the abduction and external rotation of the shoulder may cause the isolated avulsion fracture of the lesser tubercle.

Rotator cuff muscles

Muscle Insertion
S: Supraspinatus Greater tubercle
I: Infraspinatus
T: Teres Minor
S: Subscapularis Lesser tubercle

questions.text: Which of the following clostridium species is non-motile?
questions.solution:
Clostridium perfringens is a non-motile bacillus.

All clostridia are motile, with a peritrichate flagella, with the exception of:

  • C. perfringens
  • C. tetani type VI.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presented with weight loss, decreased appetite, and iron deficiency anaemia. Chest X-ray was done and given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray depicts multiple, large, well-circumscribed, round pulmonary metastases that look similar to cannonballs. Hence it is known as cannonball metastasis. 

The most common primaries to result in pulmonary metastases in adults include breast carcinoma, colorectal carcinoma, renal cell carcinoma, uterine leiomyosarcoma, and head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

Other unusual patterns of metastases are endobronchial metastases, miliary metastases(from thyroid and renal carcinomas, bone sarcomas and choriocarcinoma) and tumour emboli.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is required for the only energy-requiring step of fatty acid oxidation?
questions.solution:
The only energy-requiring step in fatty acid oxidation is catalyzed by the thiokinase enzyme.

In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, the enzyme acyl-CoA synthetase or thiokinase catalyses the conversion of a fatty acid to acyl-CoA, the active form of fatty acid for oxidation.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in Fatty acid Transfer Across Mitochondrial membrane

Enzyme

Site of action

Action

Acyl-CoA synthetase (Thiokinase)

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Converts free fatty acid into Acyl CoA

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Transfers long-chain acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine.

Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Help Acylcarnitine to penetrate the inner membrane

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Along with carnitine palmitoyl transferase I oxidizes long-chain fatty acids in the mitochondria.

questions.text: Identify the marked bond:
questions.solution:
The marked bond represents a hydrogen bond between thymine and adenine.

The complementary nitrogenous bases of the 2 strands of the DNA double helix are linked by hydrogen bonds. Adenine and thymine are linked by two hydrogen bonds (A=T) whereas three hydrogen bonds are present between cytidine and guanine (C≡G). Van der Waals and hydrophobic interactions are present between the stacked adjacent base pairs.

A β-N-glycosidic bond is present between the nitrogenous base and deoxyribose sugar. C1 of deoxyribose/ribose sugar is joined covalently to N1 of pyrimidines and N9 of purines by β-N-glycosidic bond. An ester bond is present between the sugar and phosphate group of the same nucleotide. An acid anhydride bond is present between two phosphate groups.

A polymer of nucleotides is joined by 3’-5’ phosphodiester bond. The bond is present between the sugar of one nucleotide and the phosphate group of another.

questions.text: A young male presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. The small bowel is found to have a small infarcted area which is surgically removed. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen is given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the small bowel infarction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).

PAN affects small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically affects young adults. The patient may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement (most common) or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by involvement of gastrointestinal vessels.

Option A: Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. 

Option B: Cystic medial degeneration leads to dissecting aortic aneurysm.

Option C: Mönckeberg’s arteriosclerosis does not cause infarction.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of a mass descending PV. On examination, you note that the external os lies at the level of the introitus. What is the degree of uterine prolapse?
questions.solution: The given case scenario is suggestive of 2nd degree prolapse.

questions.text: In a patient with bacterial vaginosis, which of the following microscopic features would not be seen?
questions.solution:
An abundance of polymorphs is not a microscopic finding of bacterial vaginosis because it is not an inflammatory condition. It occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora.

A swab of the discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation is done using a gram stained smear. In bacterial vaginosis, this would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organ­isms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen. 

Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

questions.text: Which of the following dopamine receptor agonists has antioxidant properties?
questions.solution:
Pramipexole is a dopamine receptor agonist that has an additional antioxidant effect. 

Pramipexole has a possible neuroprotective effect by its ability to scavenge hydrogen peroxide and enhance neurotrophic activity.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric OPD by his parents with a history of headache, dizziness, and unsteady gait. Based on the provided scan image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI is suggestive of medulloblastomas. It is the most common malignant brain tumor of childhood, and it occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Irrespective of their histological or genetic characterization, medulloblastomas correspond histologically to WHO grade IV tumors.

Radiological findings include:

  • CT & MRI: CT shows a hyperdense midline vermian mass adjoining the roof of the 4th ventricle and causing hydrocephalus. MRI shows T2 hypointensity or isointensity compared to the grey matter. The CT and MRI findings also reflect the increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and densely packed cells of the tumor. 
  • DWI: restricted diffusion
  • MR spectroscopy: reduced N-acetyl aspartate(NAA) peak with an increased choline-to-creatine ratio.

The CT and MRI findings, supported by the presence of restricted diffusion on DWI, are the most reliable observations in differentiating medulloblastoma from ependymoma or other posterior fossa tumors.

Standard treatment for medulloblastomas includes surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Pilocytic astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults. These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The majority of neoplasms are located in the cerebellum. However, they can also appear around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres. Mural nodule, a contrast medium enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass, is seen on MRI. 

Option C: Ependymomas are tumours that arise from the ependyma-lined ventricular system, typically on the floor of the fourth ventricle. In adults, the spinal cord is their most common location; tumors in this site are particularly frequent in the setting of neurofibromatosis type 2. They are well-demarcated lobulated mass lesions that show calcifications on CT in over 50% and are of mixed signal intensity on MRI. 

Option D: Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has a bimodal age of presentation. These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man patient presents with anemia and abdominal pain. On examination, he has pigmented macules over the palms, soles, and oral mucosa. Further investigations reveal loss-of-function mutations of the STK11 gene. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome.

Loss-of-function mutations of STK11 cause the Peutz–Jeghers syndrome. The STK22 gene, also known as LKB1, encodes a serine/threonine kinase that is an important regulator of cellular metabolism.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder. It is associated with arborizing polyps of the gastrointestinal tract (small intestine > colon > stomach). It increases the risk of multiple epithelial cancers, particularly of colon, breast, lung, pancreas, and thyroid.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. He was recently diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly. His liver microscopy on Prussian blue staining is given below. What is the mode of inheritance of his disease?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary hemochromatosis. It is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that involves the HFE gene.

Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron accumulation that results in tissue damage. It consists of a triad of:

  • Micronodular cirrhosis
  • Bronzing of the skin
  • Diabetes mellitus

Diagnosis is by elevated levels of serum ferritin, serum iron, transferrin saturation, and confirmation by a gene assay.

Note: Autosomal recessive disorders include almost all inborn errors of metabolism.

questions.text: The urine microscopy of a young man admitted for the evaluation of renal stones shows the following finding. What type of stone is this?
questions.solution:
The urine microscopy shows the presence of hexagonal-shaped stones which are likely to be cystine stones.

These stones are commonly found in acidic urine. Recurrent stones are treated using D-penicillamine.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A 43 year-old-male patient came to the clinic with complaints of occasional hematuria and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Examination revealed tiny petechial hemorrhages over his lower limbs. The patient tests positive for the anti-proteinase-3 antibody. Which of the following is true about this major antibody?

choices.text: It is also known as p-ANCA
It shows perinuclear staining on immunofluorescence

questions.solution:
Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA / c-ANCA is triggered by certain infections as proteinase 3 shares similarities with many microbial peptides. This is the major antibody responsible for Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA). 

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are a heterogeneous group of autoantibodies directed against the constituents of neutrophils or monocytes. Many patients with vasculitis have circulating antibodies that react with neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens.

The two most important ANCAs related to vasculitis are: 

  • Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA - Directed against PR3 which is a neutrophil azurophilic granule constituent.
  • Anti-myeloperoxidase/MPO-ANCA/p-ANCA - Directed against MPO which is a lysosomal granule constituent involved in oxygen free-radical generation. MPO-ANCAs are induced by several therapeutic agents, particularly propylthiouracil. 

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

 Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of dribbling of urine from the vagina during micturition. She has a history of obstructed labor. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done, and the lowest swab gets stained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a urethrovaginal fistula.

Urethrovaginal fistulas have the following clinical features:

  • Continent and dry at rest
  • Urinary dribbling during micturition
  • Fistulous opening is seen on per speculum examination

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: The anomaly scan of a G3A2 woman is given below. Identify the sign.
questions.solution:
The given image shows banana sign.

An abnormal anterior curvature of cerebellum along with effacement of cisterna magna produces this appearance. It is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation.

Lemon sign: Axial USG image of the fetal head at the level of the biparietal diameter shows inward concavity of both frontal bones instead of the normally seen convexity. This gives the head the appearance of a lemon. It has a strong association with spina bifida and is very useful for detecting this condition.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A young girl with primary amenorrhea is being evaluated for the presence of a congenital uterine anomaly. What is the gold standard investigation to detect the same?
questions.solution:
Magnetic Resonance Imaging is the most accurate imaging technique for investigating and classifying congenital uterine anomalies and is hence considered to be the gold standard. Classifying congenital uterine anomalies is important as fertility outcomes and surgical management vary considerably.

Other options -

Option B: Computed Tomography and X-ray are not preferred, and in case of suspected pregnancy they are avoided. 

Option C: Ultrasonography is the primary/initial investigation done. However, not all uterine anomalies can be detected and classified.

Option D: Hysterosalpingography is also done, however, it cannot differentiate between a septate and bicornuate uterus, as only the uterine interior is visualized, leading to similar images on HSG.

questions.text: High affinity of HbF to O2 is due to_____
questions.solution:
Increased affinity of HbF to O2 is due to decreased affinity of γ chains of HbF to 2,3DPG.

HbF is the fetal variant of hemoglobin.

The β chains of adult hemoglobin (hemoglobin A) are replaced by γ chains in HbF. This modification results in increased affinity of hemoglobin for O2, a left shift of the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, and decreased P50.
The mechanism of the left shift is based on the binding of 2,3-DPG. 2,3-DPG does not bind as avidly to the γ chains of HbF as it binds to the β chains of hemoglobin A. When less 2,3-DPG is bound, the affinity for O2 increases and facilitates the movement of O2 from the mother to the fetus.

This increased affinity is beneficial to the fetus, whose PaO2 is low (approximately 40 mm Hg).

questions.text: What is the colour code of a 16F foley's catheter?
questions.solution:
The colour code of a 16F foley's catheter is orange.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below
